captions: To us Earth-dwelling humans, the speed of light is so fast that it appears instantaneous. But space is very very vast. So vast in fact that even at the speed of light the theoretical speed limit of the universe, which our spacecraft cant even begin to approach a journey through the cosmos becomes a snail-paced slog. It's a little hard to visualize, but James ODonoghue, a planetary scientist at the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) recently created an animation which shows, in the vastness of space, even light speed isn't that fast. Tap the link in our bio to check it out

These rules for space exploration would be great if there was any way to enforce them. Oh NASA... NASA just released a new set of voluntary regulations that it hopes will guide humanity toward a future of peaceful, collaborative space exploration. Unfortunately, it has no power to enforce them. Like other attempts at space legislation, adherence to the Artemis Accords would be purely symbolic and voluntary. Tap the link in our bio to read more about NASA's new space rules

Astrobiologists say we should gene-hack Mars colonists, and even, that to not do so, might be itself unethical. In a recent webinar, Lunar and Planetary Institute astrobiologist and geomicrobiologist Kennda Lynch argued it would be preferable to edit the human genome to survive on Mars rather than terraform it to be more hospitable. To hack or not to hack, the debate ultimately comes down to deciding what might give colonists the best chance of survival on the harsh Red Planet. Tap the link in our bio to read more about colonizing Mars

Scientists have a promising new idea to defeat the coronavirus. In order to find new treatments for COVID-19, scientists are probing how the coronavirus alters human cells when it infects and hijacks them. Most recently a research team at the Frankfurt University hospital announced theyve identified a number of compounds available in existing drugs including the metabolism-inhibiting cancer medication WP1122 that seem to stop the coronavirus from reproducing inside a host. The teams findings were published on May 14th in the journal Nature. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their research

Get ready gamers, Unreal Engine 5 is coming. Software developer Epic Games, the company behind Fortnite, just released the first look at Unreal Engine 5, the next generation of its popular game engine and it looks genuinely spectacular. Epic Games recently showed off a flashy tech demo titled "Lumen in the Land of Nanite" and claims Unreal Engine 5 could achieve photorealism on par with movie CG and real life. Of course, its easy to be taken in by a showy new demo. Back in 2016, we were wowed by a demo of Unreal Engine 4 that now looks well, not that impressive. Tap the link in our bio to see more of what Epic Games had to show off

Ok UFO hunters, here we go The Pentagon has released new information about a series of fascinating encounters between US Navy pilots and unidentified flying objects. The hazard reports include details about the size and shape of the unidentified aerial phenomena. It's an interesting twist after decades of denial from the US government. To be clear, the Pentagon confirming authentic UFO videos doesn't necessarily mean we've found aliens, but it does mean that we don't really have an explanation for these flying objects in the footage, hence UFO. While unusual aircraft can't be ruled out, it's entirely possible the objects seen in Navy videos might be drones, although no nearby drone operators could be located. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what the Pentagon had to say about these UFOs

According to a new report by The Wall Street Journal, Chinese and Iranian hackers are targeting US efforts to develop a coronavirus vaccine. China has long engaged in the theft of biomedical research, and COVID-19 research is the fields Holy Grail right now, assistant attorney general for national security John Demers told the WSJ. While its commercial value is of importance, the geopolitical significance of being the first to develop a treatment or vaccine means the Chinese will try to use every tool both cyber intrusions and insiders to get it. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Two new provisions tacked on to the Patriot Act would, if signed into law, grant the federal government far greater powers to probe citizens private lives online. Introduced by Senate GOP Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, the provisions would allow the FBI to collect any Americans web browsing and search history without a warrant. If the American government is determined to see just how much time I'm spending on Instagram, well that's their call, but the new provisions have many digital privacy advocates and even some other US Senators deeply concerned. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the new provisions

A team of research physicists at Princeton University may have found a new way to control fusion reactions an incremental step towards making fusion energy, the holy grail of energy production, a reality. Fusion power is a proposed form of generating electricity that works by using heat from nuclear fusion reactions. During the process two lighter atomic nuclei fuse together to make one heavier one, releasing energy as well. Most fusion reactors today use light elements in the form of plasma to generate power, but these can be incredibly hot, unpredictable, and difficult to control. That's why it's a pretty big deal that these Princeton researchers think they may have found a way to make fusion reactors more stable. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their process

Would you work with a bot for a boss? That's the premise of our next digital conversation! Automation of our workplaces has been a topic of discussion for years, but how are algorithms and automation innovating our working lives today? Come learn more and join the discussion in the latest, free digital salon in our next:Work digital event series. Tap the link in our bio to save a spot. Futurism bless

What does the future of work look like? Thinking about the future of the working world raises important questions. How will businesses shift as we move forward from a global pandemic? How will people find new ways to support their families, and how can technology help us to do that? If you're curious about the future, join us on Tuesdays and Thursdays for a free weekly digital salon series, next:Work! We've brought together experts from all backgrounds to talk about the future of work. Tap the link in our bio to see the full agenda or to reserve a spot

Get this, doctors are cloning COVID patients' antibodies to create a new treatment. When a person recovers from an infectious disease their immune system develops antibodies to help prevent them from getting sick again. A team of doctors and medical researchers from Mount Sinai Health System and the pharmaceutical company Sorrento Therapeutics are hoping to leverage those antibodies by taking them from recovered COVID patients and cloning them en mass. The antibodies would be turned into a "pharmaceutical cocktail" which could help keep someone healthy for up to two months. A vaccine takes time to generate immunity and not everyone will respond to a vaccine, especially the elderly and immune-compromised patients, Sorrento CEO Henry Ji told Futurism. A neutralizing antibody cocktail bypassed the need for a patient to respond to a vaccine and gives instant immunity upon injection. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the team's work

Scientists built a prototype jet engine that propels itself without fossil fuels. Air travel represents a small but not insignificant portion factor of climate change. With a prototype jet engine like this though planes might one day be propelled by nothing but electricity and the air around them. The device works by compressing air and ionizing it with microwaves, generating plasma that thrusts it forward, according to research published in the journal AIP Advances. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the work being done on this prototype

Tim Burton takes on outer space. Astronomers recently announced the discovery of a distant brown dwarf, a celestial body that resembles a star, thats covered in dark brown stripes. Sort of like a cross between Jupiter and something Tim Burton might draw, the discovery is rare but not entirely unheard of. What's even more notable, perhaps, is the technique used by the Caltech astronomers, known as polarimetry, which works similarly to the way sunglasses do and could prove a useful tool to astronomers exploring the cosmos. Tap the link in our bio to read more about polarimetry and this peculiar planet.

Ultimate tactical CyberTruck With the help of designer Jan Peisert, the YouTube channel Electric Future has come up with a terrifying new take on Teslas already well-armored Cybertruck. Right now the concept is little more than a series of flashy renders. But these renders feature a host of heavily military-focused add-ons that show how a CyberTruck could become quite a unit in any armed force. Tap the link in our bio to check out more of Peisert's renders, and Electric Future's video

That's right Futurists, the app is back! We've given our mobile app a tune-up and it's looking sharper than ever. It's the easiest way to stay up-to-date on all the science and technology stories from Futurism. You can browse by category and even save and share your favorites! Download it today in the App Store or Google Play Store, depending on your device. Just search for Futurism

Here lies the corpse of a planet, charred by its burnt-out star. The corpse of a planet may seem like a strange place to look for signs of life, but that's exactly what researchers propose doing. It takes a special kind of Earth-like exoplanet. One orbiting a white dwarf. This particular brand of exoplanet would have survived the death of its host star: white dwarves are the remnant cores of stars that exhausted all of their fuel and collapsed. Needless to say, any life that was on such a planet when its star collapsed would most likely long be dead, but the theory is that new life could still have emerged afterward. The next step for researchers is to create a catalog of such star systems so that every astronomer can know what to look for

BOOM! - For the first time, scientists built a rocket engine powered by spiraling explosions. The wild concept, called a rotating detonation rocket engine, would completely change the way we launch rockets. It propels itself through a continuous series of powerful explosions. Based on what the researchers found, they say it could make rockets both lighter and more environmentally-friendly. Rotating detonation rocket engines were first theorized back in the 1960s. But it wasn't until recently that researchers figured out exactly how they could make one work

NASA awarded three massive contracts this week for future lunar missions. It's all part of NASA's goal to put Americans on the Moon again. Among the big winners, SpaceX walked away with a massive $135 million contract to further develop the Super Heavy rocket-powered Starship. Starship, currently in development, is SpaceX's huge rocket which could one-day ferry passengers to destinations like the Moon or perhaps even further beyond. Tap the link in our bio to read more about SpaceX's plans, as well as two more lunar projects NASA is considering

Microsoft wants to put your brainwaves to work. An unusual new patent application from Microsoft details a system that would read users brainwaves in exchange for cryptocurrency like Bitcoin. But there's a catch! The system would monitor your brains waves to detect specific signals, such as if you were watching an advertisement. Then the system would use those signals to mine cryptocurrencies. Nothing comes free, right? Tap the link in our bio to read more about Microsoft's patent

Money, money, money (money!) Pandemic? Arguably not so great. Unless you happen to be one of several billionaires who, even now, are making more money. In fact, billionaires in the U.S. have increased their wealth by a combined $282 billion, Fast Company reports. Thats a ten percent increase over where the billionaire class stood at the beginning of March. Tap the link in our bio to read more about who's getting richer, and why.

We all know what happens when matter and antimatter meet... Since the two forms of matter destroy each other, it's long been a mystery how there's any matter left in the universe to form the stars and planets. Now, a team of scientists says they're getting closer to figuring out why, but it's just a first step. We dont call it a discovery yet, Stony Brook University researcher and T2K team member Chang Kee Jung told SciAm. Still, if more evidence can be found to support their theory, called leptogenesis, it could provide some answers as to why our universe is the way it is. Tap the link in our bio to read more about leptogenesis

When artificial intelligence development company OpenAI created the text-writing algorithm GPT-2, it initially said it was too dangerous to release into the world. Maybe so. But since GPT-2 was released it hasn't caused the flood of misinformation its creators feared it would. Instead, it's been repurposed as an AI dungeon master and, now, used to write college papers! We caught up with Tiago, a student pursuing a Master's degree in business who says he's using GPT-2 to automate his term paper writing. He was willing to share his story and copies of his AI-generated essays on the condition that Futurism didnt share identifying information beyond his first name. Tap the link in our bio to read our exclusive interview with Tiago

Every day we learn a little more. An international team of researchers say that the coronavirus doesnt just attack lungs it also assaults blood vessels throughout the body. This virus does not only attack the lungs, it attacks the vessels everywhere, University Hospital Zurich researcher Frank Ruschitzka, who worked on the research, told the South China Morning Post. It enters the endothelium, which is the defense line of the blood vessels. So it brings your own defense down and causes problems in microcirculation. The finding, published in the prestigious medical journal The Lancet, could explain why patients with conditions that affect their blood vessels like high blood pressure, hypertension, and heart disease are in more danger from the COVID than the rest of the population. As researchers learn we're sharing their work in our reporting at Futurism. Tap the link in the bio to read the latest in our ongoing coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic

2I/Borisov isn't like *other* comets... Actually, it's dramatically different than most comets we've seen before. In 2019, astronomers made an incredible discovery: a comet from a different star system making a close approach to the Sun at an extremely unusual trajectory, which was later named 2I/Borisov after the amateur astronomer who discovered it. Now, a new study by an international team of researchers led by NASA has revealed something highly unusual: gas emanating from the comet contained unusually high amounts of carbon monoxide up to 26 times higher than that of the average comet. The fact that they found any carbon monoxide isnt in itself unusual. Its one of the most commonly found molecules in space. But the extremely high concentration puzzled the researchers. You can read more about 2I/Borisov and other cool "space stuff" on our website, Futurism.com. As always, link in the bio

Talk about losing steam this giant exoplanet completely ran out of gas. A distant exoplanet named TOI-849b has completely lost its gassy outer layers. What this means is that, by studying its strange state, astronomers have a rare opportunity to better understand our solar system's gas giants like Jupiter and Saturn because this exoplanet appears to be the exposed core of a similar gas giant. The most obvious explanation for why only the core of TOI-849b remains? Its atmosphere may have been incinerated away from its close proximity to a star, or a collision with another exoplanet... or maybe it's just a late bloomer! Tap the link in our bio to read more

There's no way around it: Our ocean's ecosystem is on the brink of a total collapse. And the global ecosystem is in far greater danger than scientists previously thought, according to a new study and thats really saying something. The research predicts that without dire action to reverse global climate change, entire ocean ecosystems could suddenly collapse this decade. Its a dire warning: as various organisms face temperatures higher than anything they have before, the study predicts sudden, massive die-offs. The world is currently rightly focused on tackling the global health emergency, Mark Wright, science director of the U.K. branch of the World Wildlife Fund, told The Guardian. However, this new research reinforces that, after we are through this extremely difficult time, we will need renewed ambitious action to address the climate and nature crisis. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the devastating ripple effect this could have on our planet

In a letter to world leaders, Pope Francis himself argued in favor of a global universal basic income. The idea that has recently gained more traction through the likes of Andrew Yang, previously a US presidential candidate, who formed his platform around the idea. And Yang himself was impressed with the Popes call to action. Wow, he tweeted on Sunday. Game-changing. The idea of a universal basic income is to hand out sums of money, either fixed or dependent on a number of socioeconomic factors, on a regular basis, providing the populace with enough funds to meet basic needs to help people achieve financial stability. The Pope said that many workers, including street vendors, recyclers, carnies, small farmers, construction workers, dressmakers, the different kinds of caregivers were being excluded from the benefits of globalization, while the lockdowns are becoming unbearable. Tap the link in our bio to hear more from the Pope's letter

We know you're getting pretty lonely in social isolation, but it may have to continue on a bit longer than expected even for the next few years according to scientists. In a new study, a group of Harvard researchers argue that prolonged or intermittent social distancing may be necessary into 2022 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. After analyzing computer models of several scenarios, they concluded that lifting current restrictions too quickly or too early could end up delaying the epidemics peak and possibly make consequences even more dire down the line. But the researchers also noted that their models arent meant to be hard and fast rules and that a long-term isolation could have other damaging societal effects. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the research

This new device from MIT is essentially like "Inception" but uses a power glove instead of a dream-inducing, serum-filled briefcase. Confusing enough for you? Don't worry, it's more simple than that. Essentially, a team of researchers at MITs Dream Lab are working on an open source wearable "glove-like" device that can track and interact with dreams in a number of ways including, hopefully, giving you the ability to control the content of your own dreams. No, seriously! The teams radical goal is to prove once and for all that dreams arent just meaningless gibberish but can be hacked, augmented, and swayed to our benefit. The glove-like device is called Dormio, and it's outfitted with a host of sensors that can detect which sleeping state the wearer is in. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the glove works to control dreams

NASA spotted the mother of all "dragons" in space and of course, they found it on Mars The lighter, reddish channel is the floor of Mars Melas Chasma, a massive canyon that cuts through what is thought to be the remains of an old lake bed. NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter has been sending back troves of information about the Red Planet's surface since it first reached Martian orbit back in 2006 including this image that "resembles a fabled Chinese dragon," as noticed in a tweet by the University of Arizonas HiRISE program, which took the photo from a camera attached to the orbiter. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what we've learned about the Mars from the orbiter's journey

A surprisingly simple technique is saving the lives of patients with COVID-19: positioning them on their stomachs. So why does this work so well? "Prone positioning" as it's called, may seem counter-intuitive to easy breathing, but the position actually helps patients get more oxygen to their lungs and opens up the chest. Were saving lives with this, one hundred percent, said Mangala Narasimhan, the regional director for critical care at Northwell Health in New York City, to CNN. Its such a simple thing to do, and weve seen remarkable improvement. We can see it for every single patient. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this simple, life-saving flip helps save lives in intensive care units

Here's what happens when someone coughs near you in the grocery store. Even an aisle away, after about a minute, the particles of their cough have dispersed through the aisle and traveled over the shelves into your aisle. More than sixty seconds and you're surrounded by infectious particles. A new 3D-rendered simulation by Finnish researchers shows exactly how aerosol particles travel in an indoor environment, like a grocery store, and how easily coronavirus can spread terrifyingly far in close quarters. Someone infected by the coronavirus, can cough and walk away, but then leave behind extremely small aerosol particles carrying the coronavirus, explained Aalto University assistant professor Ville Vuorinen in the statement about the research. These particles could then end up in the respiratory tract of others in the vicinity. Tap the link in our bio to watch the short simulation yourself and see how important it is to wear a mask and protective clothing when you go into public spaces

This might seem like nothing but if you're an astronomer, this blur is a really big deal. So here's what we're looking at: This is a screen capture from a video of a supermassive black hole spewing a brilliant jet of particles from a new research paper published in the journal Astronomy & Astrophysics this week. The video shows a distant quasar called 3C 279 in the Virgo constellation about five billion light-years away from Earth blasting out twin fire-hose-like jets of plasma." These jets leave the black hole at 99.5 percent of the speed of light, thanks to the immense forces involved in the black hole sucking up matter. Tap the link in our bio to watch the incredible video yourself .

New research out of China shows that as many as one in five COVID-19 patients experienced cardiac damage, heart failure and, in some instances, death while suffering from the virus. We've known that the coronavirus severely impacts patients lungs, so the focus has largely been on respiratory problems and the need for ventilators to support COVID patients which is still very true today, as there continues to be a dire ventilator shortage in hospitals. But now, cardiologists are racing to figure out if existing treatment methods for COVID-19 have to be adjusted based on how the virus is affecting the heart. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what doctors are learning from researchers from China and Italy

NASA caught a new angle of Jupiter's swirling, tumultuous surface and the results are glorious. NASA just released a dramatic image that its Juno spacecraft took of Jupiters northern regions during a close flyby in February from a distance about twice the size of the diameter of Earth. The beautiful close-up of the gas giant showed the scientists hazy "thin bands" that are running across the planet. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what astronomers think these mysterious streaks could be from

This patch the size of a Band-Aid is filled with 400 microneedles and it's the key to a promising new COVID-19 vaccine. Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine announced today that early animal trials of the potential vaccine have shown promise so far, with human trials still in the planning stages. The vaccine dubbed PittCoVacc (Pittsburgh Coronavirus Vaccine) works in the same basic way as a flu shot: by injecting lab-made pieces of viral protein into the body to help it build an immunity. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the patch works, and how long it may take for FDA approval and testing on humans

What's on your mind? Researchers have built a new system that could answer that question without you saying a word by translating your brain signals directly into text. You could say it's a bit of mind reading, but not the kind you're used to from sci fi movies. The translation of thought to text works by collecting information from electrode arrays implanted in the brains of subjects. First, the scientists asked them to read sentences aloud while picking up their neural information, and then used that dataset to train an algorithm to understand what they were saying even when the subjects weren't reading aloud. Tap the link in our bio read more about how this technology could help those who've lost the ability to speak find their voice again through a computer, otherwise known as "speech prosthesis

Don't try this one at home. An astrophysicist in Australia ended up in the hospital, not with the coronavirus, but because he had four small magnets stuck up in his nose. Um... so how did this happen? Daniel Reardon, the physicist in question, was actually working on building a contraption that would stop you from touching your face a big no-no when preventing COVID-19 but somehow during the build, things got... a bit turned around. Tap the link in our bio to read more about his device

Listen up: Those DIY face masks you see people sewing and selling online are, unfortunately, ineffective at preventing the coronavirus. Knitting enthusiasts are hard at work filling a giant, gaping hole in the nations supply of face masks for healthcare workers. But despite the good intentions of the "sewing army" as the New York Times called them, the simple fact is that home-sown cloth masks are nearly useless in protecting against the virus and should only be a very last resort for practitioners in the field. So what are to do when medical professionals are in desperate need of protection? Donate money to your local hospital so they can afford to buy proper gear, leave the respirator masks at the store and dont hoard them for yourself to make sure that healthcare practitioners on the front lines have access to them instead. And above all, if you can: Stay. Inside. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what the CDC says about homemade masks. (And, obviously, don't try any of the terrible DIY masks you see in this photo

Watch out: Bosses are trying to spy on their employees more than ever now that people are working from home. Due to the coronavirus pandemic, many employees are working remotely but does that mean managers and business leaders let up with their bizarre, over-reaching workplace surveillance? Not a chance. Bloomberg reports that workplace-surveillance software is flying off shelves and being forced on people working in their own homes a massive breach of trust and privacy. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Bill Gates is angry that we didn't do more to stop the spread of the coronavirus and he has a lot to say on the matter. In an interview with Chris Anderson, the curator of the famed TED Talks series, Gates opined "we shouldve done more... everybody should have taken notice back in January. During their discussion, Gates seems to take aim at U.S. President Donald Trump, who has been suggesting that society ease off the shelter-in-place guidelines which are crucial to keeping new infections at bay, but are hurting the economy. Its hard to tell people during an epidemic that they should go about things knowing their activity is spreading this disease," Gates said. Tap the link in our bio to watch the full interview

Move over Mars scientists think there could be life on Mercury. In a new study published last week, researchers argue there's a minuscule chance that Mercury, our Suns closest neighbor, has all it needs to host life. It is possible that as long as there was water, the temperatures would be appropriate for the survival and possibly the origin of life, the study's co-author, Jeffrey Kargel from the Planetary Science Institute, told The New York Times. The idea of life on Mercury is still a long shot, but the researchers are hopeful. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the planet may have what it takes

Can't handle two weeks stuck inside your house? Try a year isolated in space. Self quarantine can get pretty lonely especially if youre used to spending a lot of time around other people on a daily basis. But theres one group who are real pros when it comes to isolation: astronauts. Orbiting the Earth with nothing but empty space around you can give you a lot of time to figure out how to be alone. So now, its time to listen to the experts. Tap the link in our bio to hear advice from 5 astronauts on how to get through social isolation. If they can survive months, if not years, aboard the International Space Station, you can survive a couple of weeks locked up in your apartment. Good luck

Doctors think they may know one of the first telltale symptoms of the coronavirus and, as you may have guessed by now from this image, it has to do with your sense of smell. For many patients, the first symptom of the bug, before a telltale cough or fever, could be losing your sense of taste, smell, or both and a fascinating new story in The New York Times found evidence that those subtle symptoms could in many cases be harbingers of a coronavirus diagnosis. Almost everybody who is hospitalized has this same story, said Italian doctor Marco Metra, whose hospital is treating hundreds of COVID-19 patients. You ask about the patients wife or husband. And the patient says, My wife has just lost her smell and taste but otherwise she is well." A prominent group of American head and neck doctors has now asked for the loss of taste and smell to be added to the list of screening criteria for COVID-19. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this new update

Listen, things are getting ruff out there, and socially isolating at home gives people a lot of time to get... creative. But we've still gotta do what we've gotta do! Including taking our dogs out for a quick . (I'm sorry, I know that rhyme was terrible, but we all need a laugh. Oh, you didn't laugh? Okay. ) But one man, Vakis Demetriou, found a way to follow the World Health Organization's instructions to stay home and still get his dog some outdoor time by coming up with the brilliant idea of walking his pup using a drone. Now, don't try this at home. It might have worked for a little pup like this one, but your fully-grown Doberman will definitely yank that drone to the ground and get loose. But keep being creative, everyone! Tap the link in our bio to watch a video of the doggie drone in action

What if you could print anything you wanted? Yes, anything! Enter: the nanofabricator. By the middle of this century, maybe even as early as 2042, our world could be drastically redefined by this new device. So, here's how it works. Nanofabricators are like tiny factories, and at first, they'll be large like early computers were but soon enough youll be able to buy one that can fit on a desk. Youll pour in some raw materials perhaps water, air, dirt, and a few powders of rare elements if required and the nanofabricator will go to work, manipulating materials at the atomic level to create anything you'd like. It sounds like science fiction although, with the advent of 3D printers in recent years, less so than it used to. But we're close to making that fiction a reality. Tap the link in our bio to read more from our friends at @singularityhub scientists

Scientists really really (really!) want a nuclear fusion power plant in the United States and more than 300 researchers have signed on to a report asking to prioritize it. In an ambitious push to develop and implement nuclear fusion power, the report lays out exactly what the scientific community needs and what it should prioritize to get the ball rolling. The main goal is to develop a shared, functional nuclear fusion power plant in the U.S. by the end of the decade the most ambitious and concerted call-to-arms for nuclear physicists, arguably, that the field has seen in years. But theres a lot that needs to happen before that pilot fusion plant can be built. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Within a day of each other, South Korea and the United States confirmed their first cases of the coronavirus two months ago, and since then, the two countries have had very different responses to national outbreaks but only one worked. Why? Let's unpack it a bit. Ever since the coronavirus pandemic hit South Korea, the country went into a state of full mobilization. While the country quickly developed tests and sent them out to nearly 300,000 of citizens over the past seven weeks, officials in the U.S. have still only issued about 60,000 tests. Meanwhile, Trump repeatedly lied about the outbreak and downplayed the danger the new coronavirus posed. But South Koreas health agencies acted as soon as the virus emerged within the country. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what lessons can be learned about these two approaches to the coronavirus COVID-19

Researchers took a closer look at the groundbreaking first-ever image of a black hole and what they found could make the next image way crisper. Last April, the international coalition of scientists who run the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT), a network of eight telescopes from around the world, revealed the first-ever image of a black hole. The EHT image was able to catch the black holes photon sphere or photon ring, a region around a black hole where gravity is so overpowering, it forces photons to travel in orbits. But as it turns out, theres even more to the original image: the black hole actually contains a nested series of rings. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what this means

Researchers took a closer look at the groundbreaking first-ever image of a black hole and what they found could make the next image way crisper. Last April, the international coalition of scientists who run the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT), a network of eight telescopes from around the world, revealed the first-ever image of a black hole. The EHT image was able to catch the black holes photon sphere or photon ring, a region around a black hole where gravity is so overpowering, it forces photons to travel in orbits. But as it turns out, theres even more to the original image: the black hole actually contains a nested series of rings. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what this means

In what could be a major inflection point in the global coronavirus outbreak, scientists are now testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine on volunteers in Seattle. This work is critical to national efforts to respond to the threat of this emerging virus, said Lisa Jackson, a senior investigator at a Kaiser Permanente research facility whos leading the trial. Jackson and her colleagues plan to enroll 45 adult volunteers to take doses of the potential vaccine over the course of six weeks, and evaluate whether or not the doses are safe and effective at inducing an immune response. But experts warn that any one potential vaccine may well end up being a dead end, and that bringing any new vaccine to market, especially when millions or billions of doses are needed, could take months or even years. Tap the link in our bio to read more

United we stand, divided fall! Chinese billionaire Jack Ma has pledged to donate 500,000 COVID-19 testing kits and one million face masks to the United States. Ma, the founder of Alibaba, also gave materials to other afflicted areas in Japan, Korea, Italy, Iran, and Spain. In January, Ma also donated $14.5 million towards a coronavirus vaccine. At this moment, we cant beat this virus unless we eliminate boundaries to resources and share our know-how and hard-earned lessons, Ma wrote in the statement. United we stand, divided fall! Tap the link in our bio to read more

Next time someone tries to tell you to stop playing so many video games, tell them it's educational! There's a new way to read the news, and it's by booting up Minecraft. (Yes, Minecraft!) As governments around the globe crack down on journalistic freedom and censor their national press, Reporters Without Borders is working to deliver uncensored news to the public through an unlikely channel: an enormous library housed inside the popular block-building video game Minecraft. The massive digital library made from more than 12.5 million Minecraft blocks contains articles from journalists who have been censored in their own countries, including Russia, Mexico, Egypt, Vietnam, and Saudi Arabia. But those repressive governments can't stop us from cracking open the pixelated books in a Minecraft server! Tap the link in our bio to read more and to download the beautiful map for yourself to play around in

Even after recovering from the coronavirus, some patients are still dealing with long-term health effects. After analyzing 12 patients who recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, doctors at the Hong Kong Hospital Authority found that several of them now have significantly reduced lung capacity. They gasp if they walk a bit more quickly, Owen Tsang, medical director of the HKHAs Infectious Disease Center, said in a press conference. Some patients might have around a drop of 20 to 30 percent in lung function. Tap the link in our bio to read more on what else the doctors learned about the coronavirus's impact on patients. EDIT: For more context, please read our note below in the comments. vvvvv

This might be just the thing you need to get through a 14-day self quarantine: a $1,200 gaming bed. The cozy bed concept developed by Japanese company Bauhutte somehow has enough room for a dual monitor setup, oversized cupholders, a desk lamp, and even a retractable phone holder so you dont have to go through the pain of holding your phone with your hand. (Make sure you disinfect that phone first, too!) The coronavirus is no match for social distancing, and if this bed helps you avoid social contact for the next few weeks, all the better! Plug in, lay down, and tune out. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this futuristic furniture

Science has significantly progressed since history's worst pandemics and outbreaks but historians say that our global leaders are making the same mistakes they did in the past. When a mysterious new coronavirus started to spread out of Wuhan, China, last year, fear began to grow that it would turn into a new global pandemic. Now, months after reports of an outbreak began, the coronavirus has infected more than 120,000 and killed over 4,500 people around the world a rapid spread in which some historians see parallels to deadly historical diseases like the Spanish Flu. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what mistakes society made in the past, and what we can do now to slow the spread of COVID-19

If we dont improve our pace of progress, Im definitely going to be dead before we go to Mars." Elon Musk is anxious to get humanity to Mars even if it's literally the last thing he ever does. So, how far off are we? Musk has been closely supervising his space companys progress in constructing the first-ever functional prototype of the Starship, a 400-foot stainless steel rocket that could one day ferry up to 100 passengers to distant locales including the Moon and Mars. And his timeline for the Starship is ambitious: If all goes according to plan, he wants to establish a one million people-strong city on the Red Planet as soon as 2050 using a fleet of Starships. But despite progress towards those lofty goals, Musk still sounds pretty worried. Unless we improve our rate of innovation dramatically, then there is no chance of a base on the moon or a city on Mars, Musk said. This is my biggest concern. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about his plans for SpaceX

Youre Likely to Get the Coronavirus. Back in February, James Hamblin preventive medicine M.D., published book author, and staff writer for The Atlantic published a story about the COVID-19 outbreak that made this claim right in the headline. And it may have seemed extreme then, but now we know that COVID-19 cases are spreading rapidly across the globe. As workplaces tell employees to stay home, and local governments scramble to figure out their response plan, we spoke with Hamblin to discuss: What should we expect in the next few weeks of a global coronavirus outbreak? Tap the link in our bio to read the full interview

"Nothing Really Matters." That's the title of a newly published physics paper (or the potential title of a really sad breakup ballade) in which physicists argue that extradimensional holes known as bubbles of nothing could cause the universe to consume itself from the inside out. Well.. that's grim! But don't worry: For now, it's all theoretical. Physicists have long thought that most of our universe is made up of nothingness, or vacuum, but that it's relatively stable. But now, they're questioning this conclusion. Maybe it's just a false vacuum" prone to... self-induced destruction via "nothingness bubbles." It's a bizarre theory, but tap the link in our bio to learn more about what this theoretical cosmic destruction could teach us about our universe

Elon Musk is pretty pissed and honestly, wouldn't you be, too, if your rocket exploded? Early last week, Musk tweeted a video showing a Starship prototype dubbed SN1 exploding in a massive cloud of gas at the companys Boca Chica facilities. (It pretty much crumpled like an empty can of soda. Can of pop? Whatever, just yell at us in the comments...) Its fine, Musk tweeted afterward. Well just buff it out. Sounds like he might have been able to shake it off, but... not so much. Musk later told Ars Technica that I told them that, in the future, you treat that rocket like its your baby, and you do not send it to the test site unless you think your babys going to be OK." Tap the link in our bio to read more about how SpaceX's rapid recent hiring could have contributed to the screwup

Something is weirdly warping our entire galaxy and it involves a galactic collision. Astronomers have known for years that the edges of the Milky Way warp, ripple, and wobble like a bowl of Jello but nobody knew why. Until now! A new study using data from the European Space Agencys star-mapping satellite Gaia has given us some answers: The disc of our Milky Way, made up of hundreds of billions of stars, is being warped as it slowly collides with a smaller neighboring galaxy. (Neighbors are always the worst even on a galactic level!) Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this warp will change our galaxy

"EEEAAAAAAEEEEEAAAAAA!" Okay, that's as close to the sound of a bat screeching as we can get. And also, it's now the sound made by a drone developed by Purdue University engineers. So, why give a drone the ability to screech? The engineers are taking a page out of a bats playbook by attaching a rig to the drone that allows it to chart out its surroundings using echolocation. Using a speaker and an array of four microphones, the drone was able to accurately map out the rooms walls and avoid collisions. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this technology could potentially help lead to better car backup cameras or help people with disabilities navigate

For the first time (ever!) doctors have attempted to cure blindness by gene-hacking a patient with CRISPR technology. A team from Oregon Health & Science Institute injected three droplets of fluid into a patient's eyeball and inside those drops was CRISPR-edited DNA fragments. And once those cells in the eyeball are edited, doctors say it's permanent, and that the new cell should persist "hopefully for the life of the patient." Tap the link in our bio to read more about this groundbreaking procedure, and the rare genetic condition this will hopefully help cure

See that asteroid? It might be worth, wait for it... a staggering $10,000 quadrillion. (!!) NASA is planning a mission to the asteroid Psyche, and it needs SpaceX's help to get there. The metal-rich asteroid orbits the Sun between Mars and Jupiter (so not *too* far away from us) and NASA plans to send out a probe to it, launched onboard a Falcon Heavy in 2022. Despite the unbelievable value of the asteroid's resources, NASAs goal, though, isnt financial. Instead, its hoping that new data about Psyche will help explain the early history of the solar system. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Can you solve this equation? 2* = Here, let us spell it out for you: A team of physicists is working on building a functional wormhole. And what will it take to get there? Oh, you know, just two quantum entangled black holes. Conventional wisdom tells us: Nothing ever escapes from a black holes immense gravitational pull. But, according to theoretical research, two fully-entangled black holes should be able to transmit quantum information between them rather than destroying it like they usually would after it passes ones event horizon. And that would essentially create quantum teleportation. (Meaning... functional worm holes!!!) Listen, we know it's complicated. So that's why we wrote a whole article about it. Tap the link in our bio to read more

The Trump administration really wants to control coronavirus information so much so, its even censoring its *own* infectious disease expert. So why the tight lip? It took several days for the White House to figure out who was in charge (it's VP Mike Pence). And moving forward, any government official who wants to talk about the COVID-19 outbreak will need Pence's explicit approval. Regardless of your view on politics, it's a troubling move for a few reasons: It mirrors how the Chinese government initially responded to news of a viral outbreak which involved censoring and silencing experts rather than giving the public crucial information and now all of the information will be filtered through Pence, whose regressive policies led to an HIV outbreak during his tenure as governor of Indiana. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this policy could effect the U.S. response to the coronavirus

Astronomers just detected a big bang but not, you know, *the* Big Bang. Researchers at the International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research discovered an explosion emanating from a supermassive black hole at the center of the Ophiuchus galaxy, which is about 390 million light-years from Earth. And it was such a violent explosion that it literally cut a hole in the cluster plasma, which is the hot gas that surrounds black holes, as spotted through X-ray telescope observations. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what this unprecedented blast can teach us about our universe

We promise this isn't what it looks like! This might seem like a bloody scene, but it's actually... algae. So here's what's up: That green building is a research station, situated on an island just off the coast of Antarcticas northernmost peninsula. And that "Blood Snow" you're seeing isn't blood at all: It's a bright red, microscopic algae called Chlamydomonas nivalis. So you might wonder: Where did all of this come from and why are we seeing so much of it? Well, the algae thrives in freezing cold water, and so, as Antarctica suffers a record-breaking warm summer and more of its ice melts, we may be seeing more scenes like this. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this bizarre, bloody algae bloom and how climate change is drastically effecting the continent of Antarctica

Big news for possible Planet B: Astronomers found a massive exoplanet capable of holding liquid water in livable conditions. I know a lot of you might say, "Why are we looking for Planet B when we should be taking care of Planet A, our very own Earth? And you're not wrong! But this is a pretty exceptional find by NASA and it's right in our cosmic back yard, only 124 light-years away. So, let's take a closer look at its potential. Called "K2-18b," the exoplanet is 2.6 times the radius of Earth and orbits its star within the habitable zone the region in a star system where liquid water can exist as determined by a brilliant team of astronomers from the University of Cambridge. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their findings

If a war begins in space, who do you want sitting in the briefing room? Looks like the U.S. Space Force definitely wants Elon Musk there. As the Space Force evolved from a vague Trumpian thought to a full-fledged branch of the U.S. military, questions surfaced about what exactly it would do and who would be involved in decision making with NASA and the Air Force. Lieutenant General David Thompson, the Space Forces second-in-command, said they've begun working closely with Elon Musk's SpaceX. The Space Force plans to scan for hostile missile launches and other surveillance missions, as well as maintaining communication, GPS, and military satellites. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about how SpaceX would could help keep the peace in the stars

BILL! BILL! BILL! Bill Nye the Science Guy has a pretty strange theory: Humans may be descendants of ancient Martians. The TV personality and public science advocate made an unusual pitch for NASA funding this week: We should fund research at the space agency to study whether humankind's origins actually began on the Red Planet. This might sound totally out there. (As far out there as, say, Mars! Sorry, bad joke.) But, as head of the influential Planetary Society, Nye's main priority is garnering funding for NASA's upcoming Mars rover mission which will attempt the first-ever feat of sending Martian rock samples back to Earth. And those little rocks will teach us a lot of important information about Mars. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Listen, we all have needs. Even astronauts. And being stuck in space for a year can leave some things to be... desired. Let's not be coy: Astronauts need to satisfy their sexual desires, just like the rest of us. An essay published last week in The Conversation argues: NASA needs to do more to prepare for crew members' human needs. Even the dirty ones. Astronauts may face undue psychological and mental strain due to space-enforced abstinence, which could potentially be solved by bringing high-tech sex toys on the space station (Claire Denis's "High Life" anyone?) or, even AI-enabled sex robots that could act out the role of a partner. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of space sex and the very real psychological toll space abstinence could have

If there's life on Mars () it's probably going to be underground. At a recent conference about astrobiology on Mars, almost all attendees agreed: Life on Mars isn't just going to be waiting for us on the harsh surface. We're going to have to look deep inside the Red Planet. This summer, NASA plans to launch the most sophisticated Mars rover in history a 2,260-pound behemoth which, if all goes well, will eventually send samples from the Red Planet back to Earth and get us one step closer to finding that Martian life force. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the surface of Mars is such a bad place to look for life

Have any of you out there *actually* beaten the computer in online chess? (It's really hard, okay!) And even reigning global Chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov agrees with that. Twenty-three years ago, IBMs Deep Blue AI beat Kasparov at chess sending shockwaves through the worlds of chess, computing, and conspiratorial technophobes. Obviously, Kasparov was pretty upset, but now he's finally come to terms with it. "We all make mistakes. We lose," he said. "Whats important is how we deal with our mistakes, with negative experience." Tap the link in our bio to read more about the battle between humans and AI that's playing out on chessboards

Grimes really wants to go to Mars but by the time it happens, she might just be a brain in a jar (or, more like a consciousness on a computer chip). In a recent interview, the singer and artist was asked: Would you rather for to Mars, or upload your consciousness to the cloud? And her answer is... a little bit of both. With a baby on the way and her new album released just today, she's got a lot on her plate but still claims that going to Mars is one of the "main things I'm trying to do." (Maybe love interest Elon Musk will help her get there.) Would you want to store your consciousness in order to live on after you die? What if it meant you could walk around on Mars? Let us know what you think in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more about Grimes' futuristic vision

Meet Greta Thunberg! (on left... Yes, we mean the snail!) While on an expedition in Bruneis Ulu Temburong National Park, a team of researchers and citizen scientists discovered a never-before-classified species of snail. After taking a vote, they decided to name it Craspedotropis gretathunbergae after teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg. The snail is incredibly sensitive to changes in weather and temperature, according to its discoverers. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about why they chose Greta as a namesake

Doctors just performed successful brain surgery on a woman while she played the violin which is, like, *exactly* the same plot as an episode of Grey's Anatomy. The brain is a delicate instrument, and any neurosurgery risks permanently altering a patients cognitive capabilities. So, when the doctors discovered the tumor was near the region of the brain responsible for controlling the violinists's left hand, they knew they'd have to be extremely careful not to damage her playing ability. This process, known as intraoperative brain mapping or simply awake brain surgery, is not a totally uncommon practice but that doesn't make it any less miraculous. Tap the link in our bio to see a video of the incredible (musical!) surgery

We cannot do it." Tesla's competitors are totally blown away by the auto giant's computer hardware and they just can't seem to catch up. Japanese business newspaper Nikkei Asian Review recently conducted a teardown of a Tesla Model 3, and the engineers were shocked at how advanced the electric car's onboard computer technology was. The current generation of Teslas Hardware 3 chips installed in the cars starting last year have enough computational power to enable Teslas to fully drive themselves, according to CEO Elon Musk himself. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the others guys just can't seem to measure up to Tesla's hardware

Hold on It's not what you're thinking. Dr. Kevin Debiparshad is talking about leg extension surgery: a controversial elective procedure to permanently increase your height by a few inches. So how does it work? Here are the grisly details. (That was your content warning beware!) First, Debiparshad an orthopedic surgeon and founder of the LimbplastX Institute in Las Vegas cuts through patients femurs or tibias with a bone saw. Next, he forces the bones in your legs to separate with metal implants. After that, he sends you home to heal. Eventually, new bone cells will grow, reconnecting the pieces and effectively making each leg up to three inches longer. But don't sign yourself up just yet. Experts and bioethicists are arguing that cosmetic leg extension is indefensibly frivolous and shouldn't be performed unless patients have been psychologically evaluated and taught the risks and limitations of the procedure. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the concerns over the controversial surgery

Want to protect yourself from germs, but still be able to unlock your phone with your face? This might be the product for you. No, but seriously. A startup is trying to cash in on the surge of people buying protective medical masks in attempts to defend against the COVID-19 coronavirus by developing a product that solves a very first world problem: phones that unlock with facial recognition. The bizarre-looking masks, printed with the smiling mug of the wearer underneath it, are the work of newly-launched design firm Resting Risk Face, which advertises its wares as trendy dystopian products. Oof! If you enjoy late stage capitalism, facial recognition respirator masks will retail for $40 per mask, reads the websites FAQ. They are still in development. But is this all just a brilliant commentary on modern society? Or a PR stunt for a new futuristic product? Tap the link in our bio to read more

There are 11 nasty space rocks that could level entire cities so how come NASA hadn't flagged them yet? A team of researchers at Leiden University in the Netherlands have developed a neural network called Hazardous Object Identifier that they say can predict if an asteroid is on a collision course with Earth. The AI found 11 asteroids that were not previously classified by NASA as hazardous, and which were larger than 100 meters in diameter big enough to explode with the force of hundreds of nuclear weapons if they impacted Earth. But luckily, none of the 11 are an imminent threat: not only are their chances of ever hitting Earth astronomically slim, but they are making their flyby between the years 2131 and 2923 hundreds of years from now. But with this technology, we'll be ready to discover them when they do. Tap the link in our bio to read more

When we're all finally living on Mars, how will we communicate with those we've left behind on Earth? NASA has a pretty good idea: lasers. To lay the groundwork for the space agency's ambitious timeline to get to the Red Planet by the mid 2030s, NASA has begun building a huge dish in California which will be able to pick up on the Martian laser communications (Sidebar: Isn't it cool that we'll be able to call those future, off-world humans Martians?) Anyway, back to it. Using lasers to communicate will increased our "data rate from Mars by about 10 times what you get from radio, said Suzanne Dodd, the director of the CA program Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the dish will work

A mysterious signal from deep space has been repeating every 16 days and this Harvard professor thinks it could have an alien origin. Earlier this month, Canadian researchers discovered a powerful radio signal emanating from a distant galaxy, but at a very specific pattern: arriving in bursts every 16 days. So, there are... many possible sources of these signals. But Avi Loeb, the chair of Harvard Universitys astronomy department, told Futurism this week that he thinks one possibility is that the signals are coming from an alien civilization. But Loeb also acknowledged that the signals (fast radio bursts, or FRBs) could be generated by young neutron stars called magnetars or by another, yet-undiscovered natural phenomenon. (like, maybe alien stuff!) Tap the link in our bio for more of Loeb's theories on the source of the strange signals

30 years ago today, Voyager 1 snapped this remarkable photo just before powering down its cameras forever. Whats so remarkable about it, you may ask? Zoom in on the bottom right. Spoiler: that little blip in the corner? That's Earth baby! As seen by Voyager 1 as it looked back on our solar system for the last time, the Earth appears so alone against the emptiness of space. This historic photo, popularly known as the Pale Blue Dot photo, really puts things into perspective, doesn't it? You can read more about the history behind this snapshot at the link in our bio

Juuling: Not 4 Kidz! You may have been confused about that, considering the advertisements Juul allegedly marketed on gaming websites aimed at young children, and even more insidiously tot-friendly TV websites including Nickelodeon and Cartoon Network. In an aggressive new lawsuit, Massachusetts prosecutors are attempting to truly nail the company to the wall for what they say was a longstanding pattern of attempts by Juul to woo lucrative underage users. The suit claims Juul even schmoozed with teen-friendly celebs and influencers ranging from Miley Cyrus and Cara Delevingne, to Robert Pattinson and Kirsten Stewart (not RPatz & KStew!!!!) Tap the link in our bio to see the ads in question and decide for yourself

Think you have what it takes to be a NASA astronaut? Okay, prove it. NASA is officially accepting applications for astronauts to travel to the Moon as part of its Artemis mission maybe even as soon as 2024. Were celebrating our 20th year of continuous presence aboard the International Space Station in low-Earth orbit this year, and were on the verge of sending the first woman and next man to the Moon by 2024, NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine said in a statement. (That could be you he's talking about!) Tap the link in our bio to see what they're looking for in a perfect candidate. Get your rsums ready! You can send in your own application, if you think you have what it takes, between March 2 and 31

Hey gamers: Researchers want your brain waves. You know, for... science-y reasons. A team of artificial intelligence researchers at the University at Buffalo want to study the brain waves and eye movements of around 25 people while they play a video game. And what will they do with that data? Use it to train advanced AI that could coordinate the actions of an entire fleet of autonomous military robots. Yea, seriously. We know that sounds like a big jump, from gaming to robo-soldiers, but tap the link in our bio for an explanation on the research which just received $316,000 from U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, better known as DARPA

The situation for those quarantined in Wuhan has become even more worrisome: The Chinese government has instructed Wuhan authorities to round up the sick and put them in "mass quarantine camps," as the New York Times reports. Its an extreme, authoritarian move: rounding up and isolating thousands of residents in makeshift shelters and isolated hospitals that are being hastily assembled per the governments order. Sun Chunlan, who is leading the governments response to the 2019-nCoV epidemic, told officials to go door to door and test people. Set up a 24-hour duty system, Sun said, according to NYT. During these wartime conditions, there must be no deserters, or they will be nailed to the pillar of historical shame forever. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the implications this could have for the people quarantined in Wuhan

If you could see your deceased loved one again, but it was only in a virtual world, would you do it? One woman in South Korea said yes, and got to "see" her seven-year-old daughter again, years after she had died from an incurable disease. In a special documentary called "I Met You," the mother, Jang Ji-sung, can be seen reaching out for her lost daughter's digitized self a heartbreaking moment illuminating the power of VR to deliver us experiences we could never have in real life. But what implications does this technology have for the future of mourning? Is this just another terrifying, Black-Mirror-esque tech or could this help support people through the grieving process? Tap the link in our bio to see the virtual reunion for yourself

Want to hitch a ride on a SpaceX rocket? Better start saving your coin now. SpaceX has officially launched an online booking tool that lets you reserve space on a Falcon 9 rocket for a cool $1 million dollars. But don't get too excited yet; that million won't get you a seat into space, but it will give companies the opportunity to send a few hundred pounds of payloads into space, like small satellites. Tap the link in our bio to read more

She's back! But not before setting an incredible space record. NASAs Christine Koch spent a total of 328 days aboard the ISS making her the new record holder for longest-ever single spaceflight by a woman (her trip lasted 39 days longer than previous record holder Peggy Whitson). On Thursday, Koch parachuted safely back down to Earth with two other astronauts. As for what shell miss the most about her time in orbit, Koch said that would be her fellow astronauts and the fun of bouncing around in microgravity. But now that shes back on Earth? She's going to walk her dog on the beach, stick her toes in the sand, and take a long swim. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video of Koch being pulled out of the capsule and throwing a thumbs up to the waiting cameras

Here's something that will really make your skin crawl: Researchers have grown "yarn" from human skin cells. (Yes, this is an image of someone "knitting" with skin. Lab made! But still...) Researchers at the French National Institute of Health and Medical Research in Bordeaux have grown yarn from human skin cells that they call a human textile and they say it could be used by surgeons to close wounds or assemble implantable skin grafts. Okay, you might have already scrolled away because this creeped you out, but this innovative new medical breakthrough could be a game changer for surgeons. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how they made the thread

Do you want the good news or the bad news first? Here's both anyway: There's not a cure for coronavirus, but encouragingly, doctors have found other medicine to help treat patients with the virus. Doctors in Thailand have had some success treating coronavirus patients with a mixture of existing drugs more commonly used to treat HIV and influenza. The treatment rapidly improved multiple patients conditions. One 70-year-old woman tested positive for the coronavirus for ten days straight, but was cleared 48 hours after doctors tried the experimental treatment. If more medical teams confirm that the drugs help, health officials could have a valuable new weapon in their arsenal against the global 2019-nCoV outbreak. Again, it's not a cure, but it's something really positive which we could all use at the start of another week of coronavirus news. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Today's the big day! It's Super Bowl Sunday and whether or not you have an opinion on who wins, this AI hive mind sure has an idea who will take the trophy at Super Bowl LIV. Unanimous A.I., a startup founded by Stanford computer scientist Louis Rosenberg, combines the opinions of a lot of humans with artificial intelligence to make remarkably accurate predictions and that included the likely winner of today's game. Tap the link in our bio to see which team the smart money is on. (We know one of you is just going to copy and paste the answer and put it in the comments which is totally fine. Go right ahead! We'll even like it.) Edit: Turns out the hive mind was right

Listen up: The World Health Organization has now formally declared that the global outbreak of the coronavirus is a public health emergency of international concern. Previously, WHO said the outbreak wasnt yet a global emergency but still considered it highly alarming. So far, the vast majority of confirmed cases and all confirmed fatalities occurred within mainland China. But since the virus has spread to so many countries around the world, WHO decided to reverse its previous decision. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what went into WHO's serious decision and how it might affect you. For an explainer on what we know about coronavirus so far, head to our IG profile and click on our "Coronavirus" highlight

Wow, this blew up! Check out my SoundCloud! Elon Musk, probably. SpaceX and Tesla CEO Elon Musk just dropped his very own EDM song on SoundCloud. No, seriously. Were not making this up! Ok, but the laser edit on this image was added. (Sorry, we had to.) Musk dropped a link to the heavily auto-tuned track titled Dont Doubt ur Vibe on his Twitter late last night. And... you need to hear this. Tap the link in our bio to listen for yourself. But don't forget to come back after and comment your response to it. Is it a banger? Or a flop

Alright, take your best guess: What is this an image of? Maybe you think it looks like caramel popcorn, or a microscopic close up of some cell formations. But would you ever guess that this is what the surface of our very own Sun looks like? Yep, this caramely goodness is the most high resolution image of the Sun we've ever seen, thanks to the National Science Foundation's Inouye Solar Telescope in Hawaii (the largest telescope in the world!). Each of these individual cells is about the size of the state of Texas. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the scientific process that causes the patterns in the turbulent plasma

Welcome to the space hotel! Rooms are spacious, and oxygen comes free of charge. (But intergalactic continental breakfast is not provided.) NASA announced Monday that its chosen private space station manufacturer Axiom Space to build the first commercial launch destination read: space hotel for the super wealthy and attach it to the International Space Station. The goal is to help grow an economy in low-Earth orbit, according to NASA. And what will a room with a really good view cost you? About $50 million dollars, according to Axiom CEO Mike Suffredini. Its a bargain! Suffredini added. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Now this took some heart to do: Researchers in Japan have just successfully completed a first-of-its-kind heart transplant on a patient. Here's why it was so unique. Rather than replacing their patients entire heart with a new organ, researchers from Japans Osaka University placed degradable sheets containing heart muscle cells onto the hearts damaged areas and if the procedure has the desired effect, it could eventually eliminate the need for some entire heart transplants. I hope that [the transplant] will become a medical technology that will save as many people as possible, as Ive seen many lives that I couldnt save, researcher Yoshiki Sawa said at a news conference. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about how the process works

Now this took some heart to do: Researchers in Japan have just successfully completed a first-of-its-kind heart transplant on a patient. Here's why it was so unique. Rather than replacing their patients entire heart with a new organ, researchers from Japans Osaka University placed degradable sheets containing heart muscle cells onto the hearts damaged areas and if the procedure has the desired effect, it could eventually eliminate the need for some entire heart transplants. I hope that [the transplant] will become a medical technology that will save as many people as possible, as Ive seen many lives that I couldnt save, researcher Yoshiki Sawa said at a news conference. Over the weekend, reports of the coronavirus extended to every inhabited continent of the Earth (that's excluding only Antarctica). Officials in Australia confirmed the continents first case of 2019-nCoV, the pneumonia-like virus that emerged from Wuhan, China last month and by Monday, Australia had confirmed five total cases. And more could soon be confirmed: There are also suspected but yet-unconfirmed coronavirus cases in both Brazil and the Republic of Cte dIvoire. If those are confirmed, that would mean the viral pandemic has now spread to 6 out of 7 continents, after making its way to the U.S. and France last week. But before you scroll on, some context: Though the number of confirmed cases has tripled to nearly 2,900, about 2,840 of these cases remain within the borders of mainland China. Every other country affected by 2019-nCoV has confirmed *fewer than ten cases* each. For more on the newest coronavirus reports, tap the link in our bio

*sniff sniff* Um, something is smelling... really dank in this small town in Michigan. (Yeah, it's weed.) Bessemer, MI, is spending $3,400 on a bizarre-looking device called a Nasal Ranger in hopes that it will solve a growing problem: the stench of marijuana plants. The city of Bessemer stinks, city council member Linda Nelson said during a town meeting. You can smell marijuana everywhere. Weve got people who cant sit in their backyard because the smell from their neighbor is so bad. Tap the link in our bio to see how this bad boy works at sniffing out the strongest strains

Hey, I think I can see my future Martian house from here! Elon Musk says he'll put a million people on Mars by 2050. In a series of evening tweets, Musk revealed new details about his plans to colonize Mars: In theory, 1,000 Starships could eventually send maybe around 100k people per Earth-Mars orbital sync, Musk tweeted. Musk envisions these ships departing Earth orbit over a 30-day period, the window of time when Earth and Mars are best aligned to make the trip, every 26 months. And once humans arrive, there will be plenty to do. There will be a lot of jobs on Mars! Musk added. Tap the link in our bio to learn how many megatons of cargo will be needed to built a civilization like the one in this image

This Boeing satellite may be about to explode. Here's what's going on. DirecTV, the company that owns the Boeing-built satellite, has asked the FCC for permission to conduct emergency operations to move a satellite that may be about to blow up due to a battery malfunction. The company said that once sunlight is no longer available and the satellite can't use its solar charging, the satellite will have to resort to using its damaged batteries risking a catastrophic battery failure. An explosion in an already-busy orbit chock full of other satellites could spell disaster: a cascade of orbital shrapnel. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Scientists may have figured out where 2019-nCoV, the virus behind Chinas growing pandemic, came from and it may have started with snakes. The viral outbreak began at a seafood market in Wuhan, China that sold both butchered meat and live animals. A team of Peking University of China researchers suspects that the original culprit wasnt one of the fish arguing instead that an infected snake likely set the whole thing off. But despite the progress of new research, it's still too soon to know exactly where the virus originated. Each day at Futurism, we strive to report the newest updates on the mysterious virus, but the story is often updating, and news can change often. For our most up-to-date stories, tap the link in our bio to see an updating list of our newest reporting on the 2019-nCoV virus

What if there aren't aliens piloting UFOs but actually time-traveling humans from the future? At least, that's what a new book from Michael Masters, a professor of biological anthropology at Montana Technological University, suggests. We know were here. We know humans exist. We know that weve had a long evolutionary history on this planet. And we know our technology is going to be more advanced in the future, he says. Masters isnt the first to float this idea. But in his new book, he attempts to support it by drawing on his expertise in anthropology. Tap the link in our bio to read more

20/20 vision is so yesterday. How about a contact lens with a computer in it? A startup called Mojo Vision unveiled a working prototype of what it claims to be the worlds first true smart contact lens" complete with a teensy tiny display screen that you can wear in your eye. The company says it could provide directions, sports scores, or even let you see in the dark. People cant tell you are wearing it, so we want the interaction to be subtle, done using just your eyes, said the startup's senior vice president of product and marketing Steve Sinclair. Tap the link in our bio to see more of the exciting eyeball innovation, like how many thousands of pixels they were able to pack into it

IT'S ALIVEEEEEEEE! No, but really, this concrete is like... sort of actually alive. Scientists at the University of Colorado, Boulder have created what The New York Times calls a living concrete, teeming with photosynthetic bacteria, that can grow itself and regenerate itself much like a living organism. The concrete is a mixture of gelatin, sand, and cyanobacteria that cools similarly to Jell-O (but don't eat it please!). The resulting biostructure can regenerate itself three times after being cut apart by researchers an incredible breakthrough in the young, but rapidly growing, field of self-assembling materials. Tap the link in our bio to read more. (Don't be scared! No Frankensteins inside futurism

Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa wants to Starship and chill with a special someone on a trip around the Moon and he has about 20,000 applicants for the position. In September 2018, SpaceX announced that Maezawa would be a passenger on the companys commercial Starship rocket as it makes its way around the Moon and back some time in 2023, and it turns out he's looking for a special someone to keep him company on the voyage. Earlier this month, Japanese video streaming website AbemaTV announced its planning to follow Maezawa on his hunt to find a life partner, as part of a reality TV show called Full Moon Lovers, and over 20,000 women have applied. Tap the link in our bio to read more about his galactic search for love

NASA wants to grow a Moon base out of mushrooms. Now that's some futuristic fungus. Scientists at NASA are exploring a peculiar strategy for building biological off-world structures that could be grown onsite out of living shroomies. If the research pans out, it would allow future astronauts to construct off-world settlements without needing to carry expensive, heavy building materials with them all the way from Earth a game-changer in the plan to colonize space. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how scientists might grown fungus in the foreign soils of space

That selfie filter giving you dog ears isn't as innocuous as you might think. On Wednesday, the United States House Oversight and Reform Committee held a hearing on facial recognition technology. During it, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez closed her remarks by comparing the tech to the dystopian sci-fi series "Black Mirror." AOC noted how mobile apps help bolster facial recognition systems by collecting data unbeknownst to users through seemingly innocuous filters. "I think its really important that everyone really understand whats happening," she said, "Because this is happening secretly, as well. Tap the link in our bio to watch the full video of her statement

Here's some explosive new research: The Earth's oceans are warming at the rate of five atomic bombs being dropped on the planet *per second*. Let's put that number into context. When the U.S. dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945, that atom-bomb exploded with an energy of about 63,000,000,000,000 Joules. New research from an international team of scientists has found that the amount of heat we have put in the world's oceans in the past 25 years is equivalent to 3.6 billion (yes, billion) Hiroshima atom-bomb explosions. That's a staggering influx of heat 228 sextillion Joules worth. That number may seem unfathomable to you, but tap the link in our bio and we'll explain the study's math
