This is a photo of intense determination. Last weekend, a man named Adam Gorlitsky broke the world record time for completing a marathon while wearing an assistive robotic exoskeleton. Gorlitsky who is paralyzed from the waist down completed the Charleston Marathon after walking for 33 hours, 50 minutes, and 23 seconds straight (he didn't even stop to sleep). That put him just shy of a three-hour lead over the previous record-holder Simon Kindleysides Ive been attempting to break Simons record for about a year now, Gorlitsky said. And now that I have, the second I crossed that finish line, I have a whole new level of respect for him." Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

It's raining laser beams! China wants to mount laser cannons onto its fighter jets. China is reportedly working on a laser attack platform that can be attached to its militarys aircraft, the South China Morning Post reports, and such an airborne laser weapon could be used to intercept missiles or even shoot down enemy aircraft at close range. China isnt alone in its efforts to mount lasers on planes; Both Russian and the United States have worked to develop similar tech as well. Tap the link in our bio to read more

It's the other *other* white meat: Impossible Foods has finally revealed its plant-based take on pork. Impossible Pork can be steamed, baked in an oven, charbroiled, grilled on a flat-top or sauted, much like the real thing but without using animal products. But is it any good? Some who've tried it say that although the texture wasnt quite right, the taste was basically accurate, and it does look pretty similar to real ground pork. But how do you think the faux pork looks? Would you consider saying goodbye to real pork and trying it for yourself? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more

Helen Sharman, the UK's first astronaut, gave an interview with The Observer detailing everything from her experience in space to her belief that extraterrestrial life definitely exists and it might already be here on Earth with us. Sharman doesnt claim to have seen any extraterrestrial life during her jaunts to space. Like many others, she believes that the universe is just too massive for Earth to reasonably be the only place where life exists. There are so many billions of stars out there in the universe that there must be all sorts of different forms of life, she says. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Want to breathe clean air in the future? You're going to have to cough up some cash for it. A startup called Ao Air announced their $350 air purification mask designed to protect its wearer against air pollution, like city smog or smoke from wildfires. The expensive accessory circles the lower half of the face and provides fresh air for its wearer. Now, breathing clean oxygen can become the latest fashion trend! (That was sarcasm.) In other words, it could be seen as a blatant attempt to profit from the effects of climate change. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this worryingly futuristic gadget

What you're seeing here are the glorious remains of an exploded star. But this is just one perspective on it; Now, we've got a 3D image of the miraculous event. It took a village of brilliant people to bring us this visual: A team of astronomers from the Space Telescope Science Institute, Caltech and Harvard have combined data from three different NASA observatories the Chandra X-ray Observatory as well as the Hubble and Spitzer space telescopes to create the 3D visualization. Whew, that's a lot of smart people and strong telescopes. And what their work shows us is a 3D visualization of the Crab Nebula, the remains of a star that exploded in a supernova thousands of light years away. Tap the link in our bio to watch the stunning 3D video yourself

Could an AI detect cancer even better than a human radiologist could? Google thinks so. A team of UK researchers at Google Health and Googles AI lab DeepMind has created a tool that can successfully identify breast cancer in X-ray mammograms. Its so successful, according to the paper published in the journal Nature this week, that it could one day rival or even outperform human radiologists. (Compared to human radiologists, the AI model flagged 9.4 percent fewer false negatives and 5.7 percent fewer false positives in the US dataset.) Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope about how this AI could reduce our dependence on human radiologists : This image depicts a microscopic close up of breast cancer cells, colorized.

Sorry, no more mango Juul pods for the time being: The FDA has officially banned all flavored vape pods except tobacco and menthol. The FDA has been under pressure to tackle the epidemic of teens getting hooked on nicotine-containing products, and the department's answer is to get rid of fruit and mint flavored options. The news comes after the FDA officially raised the legal age to buy any tobacco products to 21 last week. But the department claims the move is unrelated to the recent outbreak of a mysterious vaping illness that over 50 people have died from as of late December. Tap the link in our bio to read more

If a killer asteroid is headed straight to Earth, what can we do to survive? We could try to destroy it, sure or we could just get out of its way. An astrophysicist named Matthew Caplan has designed a "stellar engine" that could theoretically move Earths entire solar system from one part of the Milky Way to another. If it works, it could theoretically push the Sun from its current location to a new one at a speed of about 50 light years per one million years. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this fascinating (and Earth-saving) invention would work : This image from NASA represents a solar flare on the Sun.

Astrophysicist Ron Mallett believes hes found a way to travel back in time theoretically, that is. The tenured University of Connecticut physics professor believes its possible to twist time into a loop that would allow for time travel into the past and hes even built a prototype showing how lasers might help achieve this goal. By studying the type of gravitational field that was produced by a ring laser, Mallett says, this could lead to a new way of looking at the possibility of a time machine based on a circulating beam of light. As optimistic as Mallet might be about his work, though, his peers are skeptical that hes on the path to a working time machine. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how his theory could work

Gotta catch 'em all? Eh, maybe avoid the ones on military bases. CBC News has obtained hundreds of pages of documents detailing the Canadian militarys efforts to overcome an unexpected adversary: Pokmon Go. Within days of the games July 2016 launch, players reportedly began wandering onto military property in pursuit of its virtual creatures and landmarks and the unexpected intrusion left the military hilariously out of its depth. We should almost hire a 12-year-old to help us out with this, one security expert wrote in an email. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the invasion of the Pok-Snatchers

Okay, what is going on with this mysterious swarm of drones flying over the U.S. at night? Officials are baffled: Fleets of up to 17 drones, each with an estimated wingspan of six feet, had been spotted flying over Colorados Phillips and Yuma counties at night for more than a week. Since then, the sightings have expanded to six counties in Colorado and Nebraska, with as many as 30 drones spotted in the sky at once and, ominously, no one seems to know who they belong to. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the mysterious swarm (and how Michael Crichton's book "Prey" is maybe, probably about to come true. Kidding... or are we

China just quietly confirmed the birth of a third gene-edited baby but not without revealing that the researcher responsible for it has been sentenced to three years in prison. He Jiankui has been charged with illegally practicing medicine, which is not a particularly surprising update considering China condemned Hes controversial research almost immediately after he announced the births of the CRISPRed twin babies. Theyve crossed the bottom line of ethics in scientific research and medical ethics," read the court report. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

Hubble who? This giant folding space telescope could be the key to helping us find Earth 2.0. The Habitable Exoplanet Observatory HabEx for short would have a four-meter-wide mirror, compared to the Hubble Space Telescopes 2.4 meter one. The mirror will grant it greater ability to scan space for new exoplanets and distant Earthlike worlds and then better determine whether they can support life, or even future human settlements. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this amazing exoplanet hunter

Russia just became the first nation on Earth to posses an operational hypersonic weapon a new class of nuclear weapon against which other militaries currently cannot defend themselves. The United States and Russia have been working on hypersonic weapons for years, and the news that either country has built one especially before figuring out how to defend against them is a particularly troubling sign for the future of warfare. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the speed and power of Russia's new weapon, the Avangard

A scientist decided to do something drastic to change his life: he let surgeons drill holes in his skull and insert electrodes into his brain. The reason? To "cure" his severe alcoholism. World-renowned infectious disease specialist Frank Plummer once drank 20 ounces of whiskey every night before bed a habit that led to chronic liver failure and an organ transplant in 2014. But a new experimental addiction treatment gave him hope that he could give up the habit for good, but it would take a bunch of technology installed in his brain to do it. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this experimental treatment on Neoscope

I'm looking through you all with the help of new ultrasound technology that can see into the human body from a distance. Scientists at MIT have developed a system of lasers that can probe inside the human body, much like an ultrasound but it can accurately take an image of whats going on inside a persons body from six centimeters away (that's a lot for a technology that usually needs direct contact). The system uses two lasers to work: one to generate sound waves that bounce around inside the patients body, and the second to detect them as they reflect back. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this fascinating new medical technology on Neoscope

Did you know an eel can generate enough electricity to light your Christmas Tree? Well, now you do! The Tennessee Aquarium has found a shocking (lol) yet wholesome way to celebrate the holiday season: the aquariums electric eel, Miguel Wattson, can control the lights on his very own Christmas tree. The display isnt just jolly, either its also educational. (Yeah, you're going to learn something on Christmas, okay?) According to aquarist Kimberly Hurt, the duration of the trees illumination corresponds to Miguels current status. Little blips here and there? He's casually swimming around. More powerful flashes? He's excited or eating! (Disclaimer: Please don't go and try to find your own eel to save on electric.) And before you scroll on, Happy Holidays from all of us at Futurism. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video of this very jolly eel charging up a Christmas tree

Put down the holiday treats, we have something even better: planets made like cotton candy. Scientists just revealed new information about a bizarre type of exoplanet so light that they have roughly the same density as cotton candy. (But no, it's not made of cotton candy. And yes, we know that the picture *does* show cotton candy floating through space... that's for dramatic effect!) Anyway, the ultra-light worlds have been nicknamed super-puffs by the scientists analyzing them, according to a European Space Agency press release, invoking their Kirby-esque fluffiness and new data from the Hubble Space Telescope suggests how they might have formed. Tap the link in our bio to learn more

This eight-year-old earned $26 million in 2019 and he did it by unboxing and reviewing toys on YouTube. (You might want to set up the camera for your own holiday unwrapping!) Ryan Kaji, YouTube vlogger superstar, has been the top earner on the site for the second year in a row. But Kaji wasnt the only minor to make the cut this year, either. YouTubes third-highest earner is Anastasia Radzinskaya, a five-year-old Russian with cerebral palsy and seven YouTube channels. An additional five of YouTubes top earners arent kids, but they are gamers who often showcase content popular with youngsters, such as Minecraft and Fortnite. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the young YouTubers raking in cash for their videos

Russia desperately wants its own quantum computer. The Russian government just launched a new initiative to catch its quantum computing program up to those of other global powers, and over the next five years, Russia plans to pump about 50 billion roubles thats around $790 million into programs that, hopefully, will result in a functional quantum computer. While the investment shows that the government is serious about quantum tech, the program is also a bid to rebuild and revitalize Russias science programs. Tap the link in our bio to read more

It's a bird... it's a plane.... it's......a dude in a crazy looking jetsuit! Jet wing pilot and daredevil Yves Rossy just shared a video of himself taking off and hovering over lake Geneva in Switzerland with his jet-powered wingsuit and it's a pretty incredible sight. Its a stunning display of the improved suits abilities it no longer needs its pilot to jump out of a plane or helicopter to get up to speed. With the aid of his especially engineered jetsuit, Rossy, who calls himself Jetman, can fly at speeds of more than 350 km/h (217 mph) at altitudes of up to 6,000 meters (almost 20,000 feet). Tap the link in our bio to see the video

You think weather is bad on Earth? Check out these crazy storms on Jupiter. Even putting its Great Red Spot aside for the moment, Jupiter is a bizarre place covered in gigantic, swirling storms. NASA recently discovered another storm this one the size of the United States on the planets south pole, joining an array of six others that were already swirling around in a beautiful hexagonal pattern. Tap the link in our bio to read more about NASA's new discovery

Hey Santa, recalibrate your compass: Something really weird is happening with the North Pole. We know that Earths magnetic North Pole doesnt quite line up with the North Pole on a world map its wandered, at a glacial pace, about 1,400 miles since its first discovery in 1831. But what scientists didnt expect is that the magnetic North Pole has been wandering towards Siberia at an increasing pace it even crossed into a different time zone! Tap the link in our bio to read more about this strange phenomenon

Here's some more not great news for you vapers out there (if you haven't heard enough warnings already): A first-of-its-kind health study has yielded bad news for e-cigarette users and even worse news for those who both vape and smoke conventional cigarettes. A team of researchers from the University of California, San Francisco tracked the tobacco use of more than 32,000 American adults from 2013 to 2016 noting any new lung disease diagnoses they received. And what they discovered? You're a third more likely to develop chronic lung disease if you vape. Worse so, they found that the vast majority of e-cigarette users don't fully give up smoking cigarettes and using both forms of tobacco more than triples a person's risk of developing lung disease. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the research

We already know that our Milky Way is home to one black hole but now astrophysicists think good ol' reliable Sagittarius A* may actually have a companion black hole. Here's what we know: For nearly two decades, scientists have been monitoring the dense cluster of stars that orbit Sgr A* which can reveal a lot about the supermassive black hole itself. But now, UCLA astrophysicist Smadar Naoz and her colleagues believe there may be a second black hole nearby that is at least 100,000 times the mass of the Sun. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how they're going to test their theory. Edit: sorry if this gives you a headache to look at

Russia is working on a plan to blow up any killer asteroids that are on a collision course with Earth. Russian space agency Roscosmos is creating a center devoted to monitoring meteors, comets, and asteroids to ensure they dont collide with Earth even it means having to blow them up in space. But before Russia can blast any dangerous asteroids out of the sky, itll need to do a lot of research. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the country's plan

As it stands, world leaders are way off track to prevent the worst effects of global climate change. A new report published by the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) concludes that national governments and businesses need to take far more drastic action than they have been, especially when it comes to the conservation and preservation of natural environments. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how WWF says we can take action

It may be easy for you to tell which face in this picture is a real person and which is a duplicate, but for facial recognition software, that mask is as good as reality. Researchers at the AI firm Kneron were able to easily fool facial recognition systems at a variety of high security locations including banks, border crossing checkpoints, and airports using a high quality mask. This suggests that anybody with the capability to create such a mask could easily fool these systems as well a grave reality check for widespread facial recognition tech. Tap the link in our bio to read this story and more of our recent coverage on facial recognition

Well, we've had a good run! But now, this futurist says automation will lead to the end of the world as we know it for the average person. Here's the bad news: As jobs are automated out of existence, the division between the very wealthy and the very poor will grow and any notion of a comfortable middle class will vanish. This is all according to Roey Tzezana, a future studies researcher at Israels Tel Aviv University. But his prediction stands in contrast to the common argument that new jobs will emerge as others vanish, painting a grim picture for the workforce and global economy. As for the good news? Uh... there is none. But one prediction doesn't mean this terrible vision of society will come true. What do you all think about the future of the workforce? Will automation help workers become more efficient, or will it just replace us all together? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more

Talk about getting high... SpaceX is rocketing some cannabis straight up into space. Agri-tech company Front Range Biosciences announced plans to send cannabis to the ISS but no, its not to get astronauts high. Instead, itll send plant cultures of hemp, the legal cannabis strain with low levels of compound THC. So, why are they sending some of that sticky icky into space? Tap the link in our bio to read more

After years of viewing horrific content for Facebook, former moderators are suing the social media giant for causing them psychological trauma. As moderators, their job was to watch child abuse, animal torture, and executions disturbing imagery that left their mental health in shambles, and lead many to be diagnosed with PTSD. There are 40,000 people doing this shit, said Chris Gray, one of 12 former content moderators listed as plaintiffs in the lawsuit. If I can get them better working conditions, better care, then that also improves the quality of the content moderation decisions and the impact on society. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the trauma experienced by social media moderators and how they're holding Facebook accountable

Target: Autonomously acquired. Christoffer Heckman, a DARPA-funded computer scientist at the University of Colorado Boulder is calling for scientists to stop developing autonomous weapon technology. If we want to prevent the rise of autonomous weapons like killer robots that can pull the trigger without needing a humans approval then engineers will actually need to stop working towards them. Sounds easy, right? It may sound like an obvious solution, but sometimes it's hard for researchers to predict how their work might get used or abused in the future. In theory, a weapon that puts human soldiers out of harm's way could be a great idea. At its worst? We've built an autonomous death machine that could go haywire at any moment. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of military tech

The key to discovering alien life could lie in the tiny hands of microbes that like to eat meteorites. A microbial descendant of some of Earths earliest life can survive, and seemingly thrive, on eating space rocks a finding that could help us detect signs of past life throughout the universe. Here's how that would work: Using an electron microscope, researchers are able to see which specific meteorite metals bacteria gobbled up the most, which could help trace biosignatures for the search of life elsewhere in the Universe. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these meteor-hungry microbes

Is it possible to teach your brain how to focus? A new study from MIT may have found the answer. Researchers taught test subjects how to manipulate their own alpha brain waves, thereby improving attention at a given task. The key: give the participants live feedback of their brain activity. The team of scientists found that by suppressing alpha waves in one half of their parietal cortex the lobe responsible for touch, spatial sense, navigation, as well as attention subjects were better able to pay attention to objects on a screen. The only problem? None of the test subjects has any idea *how* they controlled their own brain waves. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

What do you get when you cross a pig with a monkey? Well, you get a pig-monkey chimera and it could one day help scientists grow organs for transplants. This isn't just a hypothetical: The first ever piglets with cells from monkeys have been born in a Chinese lab after researchers grew a monkey cell culture, derived embryonic stem cells from it, and injected them into pig embryos four days after fertilization. The researchers final aim for the hybrid animal? To be able to grown human organs inside of them, which could revolutionize organ transplantation. But is it unethical? Let us know what you think in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

This weekend, a bunch of super-strong mice are hitching a ride on SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft and getting sent out to space. You may be asking yourself, "What do muscular rodents need to go to space for in the first place?" You may also be asking yourself, "Do they look like the Hulk-ish rodent in this Instagram?" to which the answer is no. But! The mighty mice will help researchers study muscle loss in microgravity, which could eventually help ensure future astronauts stay healthy while in space. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the fascinating research plan

Bad news, stoners: Marijuana use seems to be linked to testicular cancer. A massive new study has linked frequent weed smoking to an increased risk of testicular cancer, but scientists say they'll need to conduct more specific research before they can definitively unravel the complicated health implications of marijuana. And to be fair, the kind of heavy use analyzed in the study is the equivalent of smoking a full joint every single day for a decade, so unless that sounds like you, odds are you dont need to panic. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

The medicine your doctor prescribes you shouldn't be decided based on a fancy dinner or free tickets to the game but that's just how Big Pharma drug salesmen swayed doctors to choose their products for patients. One doctor, Shahram Ahari, has decided to spill the beans on what he did as a pharmaceutical sales representative for a major drug manufacturer. He had one primary objective: to convince doctors they should write more prescriptions for the companys drugs at whatever cost, bribing them with expensive meals and gifts. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Big Pharma's role in the opioid epidemic

Do you think AI could ever surpass the human ability to make art? Last week, indie pop singer-songwriter Grimes made an appearance on astrophysicist Sean Carrolls Mindscape podcast. During the segment, the pop singer, who studied neuroscience before pursuing her music career, opined that humanity is at the end of art, human art AI, in Grimes mind, will soon master the arts and sciences, surpassing humans in the ability to produce superior works. In a since-deleted tweet, critically acclaimed singer-songwriter Zola Jesus called Grimes comments the voice of silicon fascist privilege, likely alluding to Grimes relationship with Elon Musk. Tap the link in our bio to read more

If we only focus on moving to Planet B, like Mars, it's going to be the death of Planet A (the one we currently live on). There are many ambitious goals for the off-world future of humanity like Elon Musk's plan to build a city on Mars, and Jeff Bezos wanting orbital space colonies but these plans are misguided according to York University anthropologist Kathryn Denning. Denning said the idea of building a colony to which humanity could escape if the Earth becomes uninhabitable is not only an unrealistic idea, but a dangerous one as well. "How can we be enthusiastic about the human capacity to explore while maintaining our focus on what needs to happen here on this planet?" Denning said. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism : This image from NASA of the surface of Mars represents the ancient ocean that once covered the planet based on research from NASA's Goddard Space Flight center using isotopic measurements. The ocean once covered approximately 20 percent of the Red Planet, and represents a possible future for what Mars could look like if we're able to make the planet habitable for humans through terraforming.

When you sit down to eat Thanksgiving dinner today, there'll be another celebration about 408 kilometers, or 254 miles, above your head: a group of NASA astronauts aboard the space station are planning to have a Thanksgiving dinner of their own. The International Space Stations official Twitter account shared a video of the three NASA astronauts onboard talking about what Thanksgiving means to them and sharing their plans for the best meal of the year. When we think of Thanksgiving, we think of friends, family, and food, astronaut Andrew Morgan said in the video. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video and see what's on their menu. (Hint: it's a lot of food from pouches

Welcome to the Mootrix. In a bid to get more and better milk out of their cows, Russian farmers have taken to strapping specially-modified virtual reality headsets on their cows heads and giving them relaxing, pleasant virtual experiences. Its not clear whether the milk improved as a result, but the cows seemed happier while looking at a VR field than they were while faced with the grim reality that they were trapped in a crowded farm. And if that doesnt work, maybe the farmers could try letting the cows roam around an actual field. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

CENSORSHIP ALARMS ACTIVATED Instagram keeps deleting the accounts of sex workers and porn stars for seemingly no reason even when their content meets the site's guidelines and restrictions. The people reporting us dont understand that peoples incomes are affected, or they dont care, said Ginger Banks, an adult performer and sex workers rights activist. They think that we shouldnt be doing this job or it shouldnt exist. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why Instagram is discriminating against, and censoring, sex workers

You can't just CTRL+Z life to undo your mistakes. Or can you? Ohio University deleted a press release that supposedly provided evidence of life on Mars. But then the news just... disappeared. Entomologist William Romoser from Ohio University claimed last week to have spotted evidence of insect-like creatures living on the surface of Mars, pointing to blurry photographs as evidence. There has been and still is life on Mars, Romoser said in a press release about his presentation. But after broad backlash, the press release has since been disappeared from Ohio Universitys site. OU... where'd it go? Tap the link in our bio to read more about the science community's response to the controversial research

A new wave of shady startups are asking for your money and your DNA. The companies claim to deliver insights ranging from personalized diets and wine pairings, to personality traits and mental health diagnoses. But experts told our reporter that the results can't trusted. At least, not until science is able to catch up to what these scammy companies are claiming to offer. If you could learn anything about yourself from your DNA, what would you want to know? And how much would you be willing to pay to find out? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more

For some people, male contraceptives can be a hard pill to swallow but luckily, this one's just a shot. Women have a number of options for contraception, from pills to implants to injections. But aside from condoms, men have just one: sterilization, which isnt always ideal given that it involves surgery and can be difficult to reverse. That could soon change, though, as researchers in India have completed testing on a male birth control injection and the only thing now standing in its way is regulatory approval. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

Tesla CEO Elon Musk finally revealed the companys long-awaited Cybertruck" and its, uh, a conversation starter. The outrageous Blade Runner-style pickup truck, starting at a price of $39,900, is a pretty killer deal. But some are having a visceral reaction to its brutalist design. "Seriously it's like a Delorean mated with a Pontiac Aztek," said Twitter user Tom Giles. The absolute unit of a truck is meant to be armored and fully bulletproof, but during Musk's big reveal, something went... a bit wrong, and the "impenetrable" truck's window shattered. But Musk is undeterred! He tweeted Friday that a future iteration of the electric pickup may even have solar panels to keep you going before the next recharge. There's a lot to learn about the new Tesla release, and we're keeping up with the latest news on Futurism. Tap the link in our bio to read all of our cybertruck coverage

Do you know what's at the edge of our solar system? Take your guess, then click to learn the answer... It turns out, at the outermost edges of our solar system lies a barrier of super-hot plasma a giant wall of fire from the Sun that defines the edge of interstellar space. So just how hot is it? As Voyager 2 began its journey into interstellar space in late 2018, it recorded temperatures as high as 49,427 degrees Celsius (89,000 degrees Fahrenheit). While the space probe seemed to come out unscathed, this scorching plasma shield around our solar system could pose quite a problem for NASA as it plans more missions into interstellar space. Tap the link in our bio to read more, and scroll down to learn more about this image in the comment below

It's like a horoscope reading for your health and just as untrustworthy. A wave of startups are claiming to find a wealth of data in your DNA tests ranging from ludicrously specific personality traits like "social communication problems" and "loneliness" to medical conditions like allergies. The problem? Experts say it's a complete scam. Make no mistake: DNA tests and genomic assessments can provide doctors with valuable information about patients health. But thousands of people turn over their genetic data to private companies every day, and they could make significant health decisions based on the results. In the case of some startups, DNA tests are blurring the line between entertainment and medicine with potentially dangerous consequences. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the scammy startups of DNA testing

The Earth is singing an eerie song and it's all thanks to the Sun. (Don't worry... this is scientific.) During a solar storm, the Sun releases electrically charged particles, which bombard the Earth with energy temporarily distorting the shape of the Earths magnetic field. A team of scientists from the University of Helsinki used data collected by the European Space Agency to map out the strange song that the shockwaves from this event create and you can hear it for yourself. Tap the link in our bio to "listen" to the otherworldly music the Earth creates

An engineer has found a creative way to filter unwanted cells from blood: magnets. The technology works similarly to dialysis: first, it removes a patients blood and then infuses it with magnetic nanoparticles designed to bind to a specific disease. The magnets are then able to draw the "bad blood" out before pumping the good blood back into the patient. In theory, you can go after almost anything, engineer George Frodsham said. Poisons, pathogens, viruses, bacteria, anything that we can specifically bind to we can remove." Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

Even winning the Nobel Prize doesn't guarantee that you have all the answers. (But it does give you some perspective.) Nobel-winning cosmologist James Peebles has a bone to pick with the scientific community: he wants the world to stop referring to the earliest moments of our universe as the Big Bang. His main qualm? We simply don't have a good way to test whether such a thing actually happened. But not everyone agrees with him. Tap the link in our bio to read more

The U.S. military is really interested in bacteria. But not just any bacteria this is bomb-sniffing bacteria. Okay, it can't really... sniff... but it does help identify where a bomb may be hidden. Detecting underground explosives is difficult because, well, you cant see them buried underground. But by genetically engineering bacteria to "glow" when it detects a bomb, the military hopes it will help save the lives of the soldiers, dogs and even robots that were tasked with the dangerous job beforehand. And DARPA is funding the research. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how it works

Fig. 1A: This is a brain on Neuralink. Elon Musk, CEO of the mysterious neurotech startup, made an appearance on a podcast where he claimed the companys brain-computer interface technology would be able to solve neurological diseases. In the past, Musk has promised the tech would be able to eliminate serious conditions like Alzheimers disease and schizophrenia, but now hes added a bizarre new example to the list: autism spectrum disorder. But there's a big problem with Musk's pronouncement: autism is considered a developmental disorder, not a brain disease that can, or necessarily should, be cured. Listing it as a disease to be solved as Musk did risks further stigmatizing a community pushing for better treatment and representation. Tap the link in our bio to read more . . : Pictured is a schematic of the sewing machine method for inserting electrodes into a rodents brain.

Five million years ago, a supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way yeeted away one poor, unfortunate star at millions of miles per hour. The star, recently spotted by Carnegie Mellon University astronomers, is on its way out of the galaxy at 3.7 million miles per hour a speed so high that it will never return. "It is a visitor from a strange land," one of the researchers said. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about why the star suffered such a disastrous fate. R.I.P. little buddy : This image is an artist's concept from NASA depicting the shifting corona of a supermassive black hole, and includes a color filter. It is not a photograph of the black hole or star mentioned above.

It was love at first sight err, we mean, love at first AI-generated message. Redditor u/levonbinsh wrote a post explaining their adoration for OpenAI's GPT-2 text generator, claiming the AI makes them feel like someone whom is cared about. Weve seen examples of people falling in love with AIs before, in both fiction like the movie "Her" and reality. In a world where human connection is increasingly occurring over the internet, it's understandable that speaking with a human-like neural network could help stem the tides of loneliness. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how love can be found in the most hopeless, or humanless, of places

Finally. The U.S. government is pretty sure its learned what's behind the mysterious "vape lung epidemic" that's spread across the country. A compound called vitamin E acetate has been found in all 29 lung fluid samples taken by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (They first identified it as a possible cause back in September.) While this is a big step in helping us understand what may be causing these injuries, these findings do not rule out the potential for other compounds or ingredients as contributing factors, said public health expert Scott Becker. There may be more than one cause of the outbreak. So, why is vitamin E acetate so dangerous in vapes? Tap the link in our bio to read more

Elon Musk really wants to build a sustainable city on Mars but he's going to need 20 years and 1,000 Starships to do it. In true Musk fashion, the CEO has set himself an aggressive timeline to start making trips to the Red Planet, with the goal of sending astronauts by 2024. Musk said he would load up Starships with 100s of tons of supplies, and ship them back and forth to the Red Planet year after year like an assembly line ferrying 10 million tons of payload to orbit per year. But is Musk's exciting and ambitious plan even plausible? Will he get astronauts to Mars by 2024? Tap the link in our bio to read more

Want to live on Mars? Let's mess with your DNA, first. The radiation in space is way too dangerous for humans to handle, so scientists think they've found a creative way to help us protect our measly human bodies from the dangerous cosmic rays. Weill Cornell University geneticist Chris Mason wants to gene-hack humans with the DNA from tardigrades that enables the weird little creatures to survive harsh radiation. Tap the link in our bio to read how it would work

More than 11,000 scientists from 153 nations just declared a global climate emergency and we should probably listen to them. The authors' claims are supported by decades worth of hard data and scientific analysis, and they propose swift and concrete actions for humanity to take to preserve our planet. The climate crisis has arrived and is accelerating faster than most scientists expected, the authors wrote. It is more severe than anticipated, threatening natural ecosystems and the fate of humanity. Tap the link in our bio to read more from their statement

Have you ever heard of astronomy's "three-body problem"? Let's give you a quick lesson. When three celestial bodies for instance the Earth, Moon, and Sun orbit each other, their gravitational pulls produce a peculiar, and seemingly unpredictable, system. And figuring out how to predict where each celestial body will be in space and time at any given point is a problem that's been stumping astronomers for like... 300 years. (We have Sir Isaac Newton to thank for formulating the theory in the first place.) But now that we have a beautiful invention called a neural network, researchers claim they can solve the three-body problem faster than ever before. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Have you ever wondered what would happen if our planet collided with a black hole? If you listen to the movies, you might think everything sucked into a black hole will turn into an impossibly flat pancake, or maybe it would release a massive, blinding explosion. But one physicist have been working on calculating what would *actually* happen, in reality. (You know, just so we can be prepared.) A new online tool called the Black Hole Collision Calculator, developed by particle physicist lvaro Dez, will quantify just how destructive the cosmic collision of Earth v. Black Hole would be. Tap the link in our bio to play around with inventing your own apocalypse

When life gives you s, make pink lemonade. Deutsche Telekom, T-Mobile's parent company, is suing a New York-based insurance provider called Lemonade. The offense? @lemonade_inc dared to use the pinkish color magenta in its ads in Germany, and Deutsche Telekom says it owns the legal rights to the shade. Lemonade tried to capitalize on the bizarre lawsuit with a social media movement but so far results seem mixed. The suit is becoming a fantastic spectacle, but also illustrates the extent to which megacorporations can use the legal system to snuff out perceived threats, regardless how frivolous and has striking similarities to the legal conflicts between vantablack, licensed to artist Anish Kapor and the pinkest pink developed by artist Stuart Semple

The univ The univ The univ Oops, sorry the universe is skipping hold on a second. There, that's better. The universe may actually be a loop like walking off the edge of an old video game just to pop back up again on the other side, or like the audio tape in a cassette player. That question of whether the universe is open, continuing on infinitely, or closed like a loop is causing a possible crisis for cosmology, according to a new paper published in the journal Nature Astronomy. Tap the link in our bio to read more about one of the oldest debates in the history of astrophysics

*wink wink* This realistic robot is actually a clone of a real human (or, at least it looks like one). A Russian startup called Promobot is selling autonomous androids made to look like any person on Earth. Like, literally anyone you want: "Imagine a replica of Michael Jordan selling basketball uniforms and William Shakespeare reading his own texts in a museum," the startup's press release reads. It's a futuristic immortality, or very uncanny taxidermy. Would you want to "live forever" as an android clone of yourself? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more

MORE BLACK HOLE NEWS INCOMING! A team of astronomers from Ohio State University claims to have discovered an entirely new and previously missing class of black holes and they're super tiny. At least... relatively tiny. One they found was only about 3.3 times the mass of the Sun, but usually they're at least five times the Suns mass (or much, much larger). If this discovery is confirmed, current theories would have to take into account an entirely new class of black hole forcing us to rethink how we understand the way stars and other kinds of celestial objects are born and die. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism

NASA is planning a two week staycation on the Moon for four lucky astronauts. But before we get to that: NASA just shared fascinating new details about the agencys upcoming planned Moon mission. Two astronauts will post up on the Moons surface for 6.5 days twice as long as any NASA astronauts before them and take water samples and observe the lunar surface. But, not to be outdone.... by itself.... NASA is already looking beyond that to a future crewed mission to the Moon, with plans to send a team of four astronauts to the lunar surface for 14-day-long missions before 2030. Tap the link in our bio to read this story and more of our recent NASA coverage

Double check the expiration dates on your mint JUUL pods. According to a lawsuit filed by former a JUUL executive, the vape manufacturer knowingly shipped more than a million contaminated pods and then he was fired for questioning the decision. Siddharth Breja, JUULs former senior vice president of global finance, alleges that 250,000 contaminated mint-flavored refill kits went out to retailers. And he says that wasn't the first time JUUL looked the other way on corrupted products. Breja also voiced his concerns over selling pods that were over a year old a valid worry, which Burns brusquely shoos away in this quote from the court documents. Tap the link in our bio to read more, and click the link in the first sentence to view the lawsuit in full

Space can be spooky sometimes just check out this ghoulish galaxy spotted by the Hubble Space Telescope. The two glowing ghastly "eyes" you see are actually the cores of two colliding galaxies. "The universe is a bubbling cauldron of matter and energy that have mixed together over billions of years to create a witches' brew of birth and destruction," said NASA's surprisingly poetic press release. Galaxy collisions are relatively common, but usually, they aren't a "head-on smashup," as NASA called it, like this one is. (Note: we added that orange tint, but the original image is just as spooky.) Tap the link in our bio to see more, and let us know in the comments what you'll be dressing up as for Halloween

By the year 2069, what advancements do you imagine we'll make in the realm of artificial intelligence? In honor of the 50-year-anniversary of the first computer-to-computer message the precursor, arguably, to todays internet Pew Research Center and Elon University asked hundreds of tech experts to imagine how the internet might evolve over the next 50 years. And one of those experts envisions a future in which software has gained personhood. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of software with a "personality." Let us know in the comments what your predictions are for 2069

*shudder* It seems that cherry picking your very own super-smart designer baby won't work, according to a new study from the American Society of Human Genetics. Determining a baby's smarts before they're born is seemingly still impossible. Today, having fertilized embryos undergo genetic testing prior to implantation is a fairly common option for people using in-vitro fertilization, and allows them to ensure a viable pregnancy without complications. But in November, a company called Genomic Prediction claimed to have developed a method for "scanning" embryos for their intelligence through genetic testing and assigning them a "polygenic score." If it was accurate, it would allow parents to pick and chose only the embryos with super smart "scores" but it turns out the accuracy of the tech may have been debunked. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

They finally did it; after weeks of speculation, Google is claiming to have achieved quantum supremacy. It's an incredible accomplishment, but some of you may be wondering: Why should I care? And what is quantum supremacy in the first place? Lets take a couple steps back. In a recent paper, a team of Google AI scientists claimed their quantum computer called Sycamore was capable of completing a task involving the verification of the randomness of large numbers in just three minutes and twenty seconds. The most powerful supercomputer in the world, they said, would need 10,000 years to accomplish the same task. Tap the link in our bio to continue reading about why quantum supremacy matters on Futurism

This is Hygiea, an object in the asteroid belt that just got a major promotion. Turns out, scientists think the asteroid deserves reclassification as a dwarf planet making it the smallest one yet identified in the entire solar system. To be classified as a dwarf planet, an object must meet four requirements: it must be spherical, it must orbit the Sun, it cant be a moon and it must not have cleared the neighborhood around itself, which would make it a proper planet. So how does Hygiea measure up? Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte

What's the strangest type of meat you've ever tried? Maybe you're a foodie with an exotic palate, or maybe you're a vegetarian who skips meat altogether. Either way, you can look forward to a future where a smorgasbord of fake meat offerings will allow you to try a bite of chicken, beef, even elephant or giraffe all grown ethically from stem cells in a lab. No killing of animals required. What strange meat would you want to try first? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more about the startups working on exotic fake meat substitutes

Two star-crossed lovers, 300 light-years away from Earth, violently collided and totally obliterated each other. Two exoplanets recently crashed into each other, leaving a trail of dust and debris in their wake. The universe is a violent place, and space stuff collides with other space stuff pretty frequently. These shattered exoplanets give astronomers a rare glimpse into what happens when already-formed worlds collide. But something about the shrapnel they left behind surprised scientists. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

Scientists may have finally come up with a way to detect traversable wormholes that is, assuming they exist. Theres never been conclusive evidence that traversable wormholes portals between two distant parts of the universe, or two universes within a theoretical multiverse are real. But if they are, a team of scientists think they know what that evidence might look like, breathing new life into a far-out theory that could finally achieve faster-than-light travel. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

For sale: human organs, lightly worn. People in dire need of cash have found an unusual way to make ends meet: putting their own kidneys up for sale on Facebook and law enforcement agencies are struggling to keep up with it. Often, it seems, people are selling their kidneys to try and scrape together enough money for hospital bills or for other unexpected expenses. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this murky online marketplace

What does this beautiful blob look like to you? Maybe you think it resembles cotton candy, or the colorful swirls of an exploding bath bomb... or maybe you're really smart and you immediately knew this is the cosmic explosion named Tychos Supernova. This supernova has long been a source of disagreement among astronomers trying to explain its bizarre clumps and fluffy appearance, but with new x-ray data and simulations, NASA may have finally settled the debate. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Life is tough but life as a sentient bodyless brain might be tougher. Some neuroscientists working with lab-grown human mini brains worry the brains could be experiencing an endless horror: a conscious existence with no body. Mini brains give scientists the opportunity to study neurological development and conditions in something more human-like than an animal model but is it crossing an ethical line if the brain could be suffering? Let us know what you think in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte

This star has been annoying the s#&t out of astrophysicists for decades. Here's why. According to multiple observations and studies, the star HD 140283 appears to be older than the universe itself. Which is, like, completely impossible. But still, scientists date the star to be about 14.27 billion years old (best estimates say the universe itself has only been around for about 13.8 billion years, but that number is still up for debate as well). So what's the explanation? Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this frustrating mystery

Russian biologist Denis Rebrikov is one step closer to creating CRISPR babies. The journal Nature reported that Rebrikov claimed in an email that he had already used the gene-editing tech to tinker with the genetic code of donated humans eggs a critical piece of his plan to edit human embryos to prevent children from inheriting their parents deafness. But some would argue that the controversial technology shouldn't be used to "delete" deafness, as millions of people who are deaf can live happy, healthy lives without the risk of gene editing. Tap the link in our bio to read more about CRISPR

Sometimes, you just need to get a new perspective. On Tuesday, a six-year-old boy named Ethan disappeared in Minnesota, prompting more than 600 people to form a search party. Numerous law enforcement agencies and even a state patrol helicopter contributed to the search but it was a heat-seeking drone operated by a local photographer that led to the boys rescue, 10 hours after he went missing. Tap the link in our bio to read where they found him

Get your reusable tote bags ready to shop at a Martian farmer's market because it might not be too far in our future. It turns out Martian and Moon soil is surprisingly fertile, and new research suggests it may someday be possible to harvest crops grown at off-world colonies. Wageningen University scientists tried to grow ten different crops in soils developed by NASA to mimic that found on Mars and the Moon, nine of them grew edible parts and viable seeds. Tap the link in our bio to find out what a Martian diet might look like

Scientists want to grow babies inside of giant, liquid-filled balloons and it could totally revolutionize prenatal healthcare. Premature birth is a leading cause of death among newborns, but a device that dramatically improves premies chances of surviving may be just five years away. Designers Lisa Mandemaker and Hendrik-Jan Grievink teamed up with medical researcher Guid Oei to design a device that closely mimics the conditions found in the biological womb and it could lead to safer pregnancies and childbirths for mothers and babies alike. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

Posting a photo to social media could have cost this woman her life. It sounds like a horror story your parents might tell you to warn you about the dangers of posting your photo on the internet: Last month, Japanese pop star Ena Matsuoka was attacked outside her home by an obsessed stalker who found her by analyzing the reflection in her eye in a selfie. He studied the bus stop and trees outside her windows, even noting the angle at which sunlight hit her eye, and compared it to Google Maps. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on the Byte

Are we finally close to inventing a compact nuclear fusion reactor? Salvatore Cezar Pais, U.S. navy researcher and engineer, was granted a patent for a compact nuclear fusion reactor capable of generating anywhere from 1 billion to 1 trillion watts and it's so small it could allegedly fit inside a vehicle. Thats far more powerful than any of Americas operational nuclear power plants, but there's a catch: its not clear how much, if any, of the patent represents feasible tech. Here's another catch: Pais has a quasi-facetious reputation for working on UFO-like technology. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Welcome to a world where every single day, the Earth is under fire from a constant barrage of catastrophic asteroid hellfire. At least, according to this tabloid it is. We've found the absolute worst science journalism on the planet (and no, internet trolls in our comments, it's not Futurism.) The British tabloid The Daily Express publishes an average of three stories a day warning, or heavily implying, that a deadly space rock is about to annihilate civilization. But don't take them at their word none of the space rocks came anywhere close to actually hitting us. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the hundreds of potential "apocalypses" we've just barely avoided

A 17-year-old teenager in the U.S. has died from the mysterious vaping illness the youngest to die from vaping nationwide. Despite the growing number of severe pulmonary illnesses related to vaping, scientists, doctors, parents, and government officials are still scrambling to pinpoint what about vaping is causing such severe damage to the human body. Here's what we know so far: - The damage vaping causes to the lungs resembles a toxic poison or a chemical burn, according to doctors from the Mayo Clinic. Some vapes were even found to contain cyanide. - Black market cartridges can be very dangerous to vapers, but it's not just unregulated THC that's causing "vape lung." A study published Monday found that vaping nicotine caused lung cancer in mice a worrying look at the future health impact nicotine vapers will face, and an argument for more research on humans. There are still gaps in our understanding of how a life of vaping will impact on the human body. At Futurism, our coverage is ongoing as we continue to report on the newest updates on vaping illnesses. To stay up to date, tap the link in our bio to read our recent coverage on vaping

Weve spent decades and billions of dollars to answer one simple question: is there life on Mars? But according to former NASA scientist Gilbert Levin, we may already have found evidence of Martian life in 1976 during NASA's Viking mission. The smoking gun, according to Levin: the mission detected positive results during the Labeled Release life detection experiment, which he spearheaded. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how they came to this conclusion by testing the Martian soil

It seems every day there's a new deepfake of a celeb pasted into a movie they never starred in but it turns out, these fun face swaps make up a small percentage of all deepfakes. The most popular targets for new deepfakes? Porn stars. According to the report, 96 percent of manipulated videos out there are placing celebrities, actresses, and musicians into porn. But this isn't just a harmless hack. The incredibly realistic videos violate the privacy of their faux subjects and unsurprisingly, the pornographic deepfakes analyzed in the study targeted only women. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Should we gene-hack animals to make them smarter? This is a question scientists are asking themselves as technology like CRISPR continues to push the boundaries of biological ethics including the potential to hack new traits into animals that could enhance their intelligence. In March, scientists altered monkey brains to be more humanlike, seeing an immediate boost in the animals memory and cognitive skills. While doing so is still impossible, the developments raise the question of whether humanity could someday, far in the future, make animals as smart as humans. Let us know what you think in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more

Lift up foot, insert into mouth. Elon Musk regretted calling Vernon Unsworth a child rapist in an email to BuzzFeed, a court document filed by the British diver reveals, when Musk thought he was "off the record." (Pro tip: you can only say something is "off the record" if you've already agreed on those terms with the other party beforehand.) And in case you need a refresher: Musk suggested sending a mini-sub to rescue a group of boys from a flooded cave in Thailand in 2018. Unsworth said it was likely a PR stunt. Musk shot back and called him a pedo guy and a child rapist. This prompted Unsworth to sue Musk for defamation. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the case on The Byte

That's one hungry black hole and it's ready to feast on some stars. Scientists running the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) just announced plans to capture real-time video footage of Sagittarius A*, the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way, gobbling up stars and planets. The EHT first captured that groundbreaking image of a black hole back in April. But now the team is getting more ambitious, and plans to capture actual video of a black hole. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

Put down the Juul while you read this one: the mysterious vaping illness is causing injuries similar to those caused by mustard gas and other poisons. A team of researchers from the Mayo Clinic analyzed samples of lung tissue taken from 17 vape lung sufferers and all 17 cases showed a pattern of injury in the lung that looked like a toxic chemical exposure or a chemical burn injury. Officials still arent sure whats causing vape lung, but theories range from the oils in vaping cartridges to fumes from the vaping devices themselves THC and tobacco vapes alike. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

If you give a bunch of people free money, what do you think they'll spend it on? Maybe you assume they'd blow it all on frivolous shopping purchases and luxurious steak and lobster dinners. At least, that's what critics of a universal basic income (UBI) argue. But it turns out, if you give people a monthly stipend, they'll use it on groceries, utility bills, and the "necessities" according to data from a test program of UBI in California. For 18 months, 125 people in Stockton, CA, received $500 a month to spend on anything they wanted and most used it to cover the expenses of their home and families. No lobster dinners to be found. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism

Let's all be upfront with ourselves: there's a lot humans still don't understand about the universe we live in. And one of the biggest, ahem, gaps in our knowledge revolves around black holes. New research from a pair of University of Hawaii scientists argues that some of the black holes floating around our universe might actually be blobs of dark energy that mysterious theoretical force thought to be pushing the universes outward expansion. If their work holds up, it could completely rewrite our understanding of the cosmos. Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte

Ashes to ashes, and from dust to... Facebook Live? This doctor had an oddball idea: start broadcasting human autopsies on livestream for grieving families and medical students alike to watch. Dr. Ben Margolis offers clients usually family members of the deceased who want answers or closure the distinctly 21-century option to have their loved ones autopsies recorded or broadcast live on Autopsy.Online, Margolis' streaming website. And many are taking him up on the offer. Would you opt for a live autopsy for a family member or even yourself? Tap the link in our bio to read more

It's a bird! It's a plane! It's... an alien spy probe? A physicist whos on the hunt for extraterrestrial life says theres a chance that an ancient alien civilization has been spying on Earth for millions of years. James Benford, a physicist and independent SETI researcher, isn't suggesting they walk among us, but that an advanced civilization could have traveled close enough to launch an expedition into our solar system. We know there are a lot if "what ifs" and "maybes" to what he's proposing. But Benford's research suggests that while a surprise visit from some extraterrestrials is extremely unlikely it's possible that some alien tech was left behind on another rock co-orbiting our Sun, waiting to be uncovered by some humans from Earth. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

So, there's a lot going on with black holes lately. First, NASA released a stunning simulation of how a black hole distorts its appearance by skewing the matter around it. Next, astronomers discovered that a black hole or even a number of them could be orbiting our Sun right now, way beyond Neptune. And now, a team of NASA scientists discovered three supermassive black holes that are about to collide together. We're learning more about black holes than ever, but the mysterious voids keep teaching us new and surprising things about our universe. Tap the link in our bio to read some of our recent articles about black holes

What do you get when you cross a labrador with a poodle? Apparently, the answer is Frankensteins monster. At least, that's according to dog breeder Wally Conron, the inventor of the labradoodle breed. Conron said that creating the labradoodle may be his life's greatest regret citing strange behavior, health concerns and unscrupulous breeders imitating his work with little regard for the dogs welfare. He claims the pups are either "crazy" or have major hereditary problems. Do you have a labradoodle? Let us know in the comments if you've got a happy pup or a freaky Fido, and tap the link in our bio to read more

"I just want to live." These are the words of 43-year-old IT consultant Malakkar Vohryzek. He has a genetic condition with no name and no cure but he wants to use CRISPR gene-hacking technology to find a solution. What Vohryzek wants is to insert an entirely new gene into his DNA which is likely beyond the scope of current gene-hacking technology. The radical tech still has many unknowns, and requires more research before medical professionals will sign off on it so Vohryzek is volunteering to become a CRISPR guinea pig. "If I die because of an experimental treatment, it will at least help science," he said. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Neoscope

Kaboom. Six galaxies just suddenly ignited into voracious quasars a process that *should* have taken thousands of years. Researchers have spotted six previously quiet galaxies suddenly transforming into quasars a transition that could force astronomers to revisit what they thought they knew about one of the brightest, most energetic types of objects in the universe. Theory suggests that a quasar should take thousands of years to turn on, researcher Suvi Gezari of the University of Maryland said in a press release, but these observations suggest that it can happen very quickly. It tells us that the theory is all wrong. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

Way at the bottom of the deep blue sea, there's... still a ton of toxic oil and it's mutating the sea creatures. About 6,000 feet below sea level at the site of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, the seafloor remains all-but-lifeless an eerie, oil-coated wasteland populated largely by tumor-laden nightmare crustaceans. Video footage from a 2017 expedition resurfaced, showing a the hellish glimpse of the seafloor. It confirmed scientists worst suspicions: The Gulf of Mexico is still far from recovering from the catastrophic 2010 oil spill and the area may even have suffered permanent devastation. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these mutated mollusks on The Byte

This laser could tear through the very fabric of space and time" if only it weren't just hypothetical. The prestigious academic physics journal Physical Review Letters published a paper last week about cutting-edge laser tech and it could have some wild ramifications. The paper itself is dry and technical, but the tech described in it is fascinating: it could theoretically pulse a laser through the fabric of the Universe. But the problem with super-powerful lasers? They tend to shred anything you would use to focus the beam. So how could we control it? Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte

Take a look at this absolute unit of a neutron star. A team of astronomers from West Virginia University claim theyve discovered the most massive neutron star to date packing in more than double the mass of the Sun into a sphere thats only 15 miles across. With the catchy name J0740+6620, the star is the corpse of a massive celestial body that was once between 10 and 29 times the mass of the Sun but collapsed in on itself in a supernova explosion. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism

The Navy is taking UFO sightings seriously. Very seriously. And now there's video footage showing unidentified aerial phenomena," captured on film by the military, which was never meant to be shown to the public. First published on a blog dedicated to exposing government secrets, three videos showing UFOs have been confirmed by the U.S. Navy to be authentic. But keep in mind: unidentified aerial phenomena are simply just that unidentified and unexplained and are not necessarily floating alien ships piloted by little green men. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism

You know the common refrain, "rolling over in their grave?" Well, there may be truth behind it after all. Gruesome new research has revealed that corpses actually thrash around for about a year after we die. You might be imagining a graveyard full of dancing zombies but the movement is really more subtle. As bodies decompose, they tend to slowly-but-surely writhe around as the body mummifies and the ligaments dry out. To catch a glimpse of the corpse wiggling, a team of Australian scientists photographed a mans corpse every half hour for 17 months, according to the research published last month in a new journal called Forensic Science International: Synergy. The bodys arms started down along its sides, but ended up outstretched a troubling find that could also have far-reaching implications for forensic investigators. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

Here's what happens when you hit the eject button on your journey into space: In the event of an emergency, SpaceX's Crew Dragon module can engage its own thrusters to quickly escape the danger. The spacecraft is outfitted with eight SuperDraco engines, allowing it to cover half a mile in just 7.5 seconds during an emergency, reaching a top speed of 436 mph. Once the ejected module has safely escaped danger, parachutes are deployed to carry the craft gently back down to Earth. At least, that's the idea. SpaceX has been testing the Crew Dragon's abort system to ensure everything works in the event of an emergency but the tests don't always go as planned. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Is storming Area 51 in search of aliens worth six months in prison or even your life? This may or may not surprise you, but some people have been taking the "Storm Area 51" Facebook event which jokingly urges attendees to swarm the military base to see them aliens" very seriously, and it's already landed two people in jail. If "stormers" are lucky, they might find themselves joining them in the jailhouse. If theyre not so lucky, they could experience a run-in with Air Force personnel who are authorized to use deadly force against Area 51 trespassers. Tap the link in our bio to read more... and be careful out there

So... can you see it? (Turn your brightness up) Step aside, Vantablack, because MIT just "accidentally" invented the blackest material in existence. A team of MIT engineers created a material that absorbs 99.995 percent of light that reaches it making it even blacker than Surrey NanoSystems mind-bending Vantablack, which absorbs 99.965 percent of light. The MIT team has since offered up the material to any interested artists. But the substance could have many other applications, such as helping astronomers remove unwanted glare from telescopes. Tap the link in our bio to read more (if you can see it

As the vape lung crisis looms over the U.S., the White House wants to ban all flavored vape juice. The Trump administration is calling for a ban on flavored vape juice like the popular mango Juul pods arguing that companies like Juul where several former Trump staffers now work have made their nicotine more appealing to kids and teens. The Trump Administration is making it clear that we intend to clear the market of flavored e-cigarettes to reverse the deeply concerning epidemic of youth e-cigarette use that is impacting children, families, schools and communities, Alex Azar, the Health and Human Services Secretary, said in a statement. We will not stand idly by as these products become an on-ramp to combustible cigarettes or nicotine addiction for a generation of youth. Tap the link in our bio to read more
