So this is a first and it's a big deal. A team of researchers from the Institute for Research on Exoplanets at the Universit de Montral have detected water vapor and maybe even rain in the atmosphere of an exoplanet that's located in its star's habitable zone. Detecting liquid water on exoplanets suggests that they could harbor life and the more water worlds we spot, the closer we get to confirming that were not alone in the universe. The planet, named K2-18b and discovered by NASAs Keplers space telescope in 2015, is as far away from its star as Earth is from the Sun meaning it receives a similar amount of energy. Scientists dont know if life would be able to survive on K2-18b, but theyre hailing the discovery as a breakthrough. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte

Are you seeing what I'm seeing? We might soon be able to communicate telepathically, thanks to brain-computer interfaces. At least, thats the gist of a new report about neural implant technology by the Royal Society, a UK scientific organization. Not only thoughts, but sensory experiences, could be communicated from brain to brain, the report reads. Someone on holiday could beam a neural postcard of what they are seeing, hearing or tasting into the mind of a friend back home. Which means, if you ever wanted to share your sensory experiences with your mates, you may soon have your chance. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism.com

Five deaths. So far, there have been five deaths from the mysterious vaping-related respiratory illness that's sweeping the United States. Listen up: health officials are urging vapers to give up their e-cigarettes and vape pens at least temporarily. Researchers in Utah claim theyve identified a new connection between sufferers of vape lung and it could help health officials finally get to the bottom of the strange sickness. The researchers discovered lipid-laden macrophages, a type of immune cell containing oily droplets, in the lungs of all six patients treated for vape lung at Salt Lake Citys University Hospital. Tap the link in our bio to read more

The vaping-related illness sweeping the U.S. may have been caused by a chemical that's relatively harmless for humans except when you smoke it. The FDA believes vitamin E acetate could be the culprit for the vaping related deaths. The vitamin is present in many foods, from almonds to olive oil, and its acetate form is often ingested as a nutritional supplement and used topically in lotions and skin treatments. But while it might be safe to eat or apply to ones skin, experts arent entirely sure what vitamin E acetate does to the human body when vaporized and inhaled. Lungs are designed to exchange gas molecules but theyre not meant to process other chemicals. Tap the link in our bio to read more

He's baaaaaaaaaaaack. Do you remember the doctor who wanted to inject patients with young blood in the hopes of reversing aging? Back in February, the FDA shot down the procedure, warning that transfusions of youthful blood as anti-aging treatments were likely scams and based on dangerous pseudoscience. The warning spelled doom for Ambrosia, LLC, a young blood transfusion clinic founded by Stanford graduate Jesse Karmazin, which shut down soon afterward. Now, he's back, and ready to start injecting people again. But keep in mind: The procedure has no scientifically proven anti-aging benefits, it's a minimum of $8,000, and the FDA doesn't endorse it. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this vampiric science

This is the story of a cloned cat named Garlic. Heartbroken after the death of his beloved Garlic, Chinas Huang Yu made a bold decision: he would have the cat cloned. Sure, Garlic 2.0 wouldnt necessarily have the originals personality, but at least Huang would be able to look at the new animal and see his beloved Garlic looking back at him... right? That was the idea, anyway. But $35,000 and one cloned kitty later, Huang's new and improved Garlic... isn't quite what he expected. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Who wants a bite of this space sandwich? Equipped with new data, astronomers hoped to make better sense of the Fermi Bubbles: a giant pair of high-energy blobs that sandwich our galaxy and appear to originate from the black hole at the center of the Milky Way. But they didnt quite find the answers they wanted. Even ignoring the high-energy beams that the bubbles seem to give off, scientists are still struggling to explain where the Fermi Bubbles came from in the first place. Its possible that theyre giant cosmic burps given off by our galaxys central black hole, or they might be the result of a massive chain of stars going supernova at once. Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Pre-order our book "Cartoons from Tomorrow" for more! Link in bio.

Should we put nuclear weapons in the hands of artificial intelligence? Researchers associated with the U.S. Air Force want to hand over nuclear launch codes to an AI, which would decide when to launch the first strike. The researchers cowrote an article with the ominous title America Needs a Dead Hand arguing that the United States needs to develop an automated strategic response system based on artificial intelligence. In other words, they want to give an AI the codes to the nukes. And yes, as the authors admit, it sure sounds a lot like the Doomsday Machine from Stanley Kubricks 1964 satire Dr. Strangelove. But should we trust an AI to know when to mount a nuclear attack? Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism

Could a trip to space help cure cancer? That might sound ridiculous, but hear us out. A team of doctors has a new idea in the fight against cancer: ship tumors up into space. Thats based on a recent finding that most cancer cells subjected to microgravity in a lab died off without any other treatment. The team of doctors from Australias University of Technology Sydney wants to test the fringe theory by sending samples up to the International Space Station to further test the bizarre idea. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

How would you like to create your own wormhole? Here are some DIY instructions. Some assembly required. Oh, also, it's all just totally theoretical. So heres a simple how-to on how to construct a traversable cosmic wormhole that could send your spaceship to the furthest reaches of space: take two charged black holes, place them back to back, and thread two cosmic strings through both. Stretch both strings to infinity and presto! Youve got yourself a traversable wormhole. Confused yet? A team of astrophysicists dreamed up this solution, which could technically send travelers to a distant corner of the universe, in a preprint paper on arXiv earlier this month and Ohio State University astrophysicist Paul Sutter published a terrific breakdown of the concept. Tap the link in our bio to read more

You're either going to think this is really, really cool or really, really gross. The future of brain surgery could involve worm-like robots wriggling through the veins in your brain. A team of researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have invented this little wiggling guy to be steered through the tiny arteries in the human brain using a magnet opening new doors for minimally invasive brain surgery by accessing places in the brain that have thus far remained unreachable. It could treat lesions and help unblock blockages in the brain that could otherwise result in aneurysms and strokes. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

So....... humans........ talk........ pretty slowly. At least, according to artificial intelligence we do. When scientists finally crack the code of superhuman AI, verbal communication between us humans and the machines may be a total wash, according to SpaceX and Tesla CEO Elon Musk. Musk thinks the main problem will be the different speeds that humans and computers process information with us humans moving at a glacial pace, comparatively. As computer engineers continue to build blazing-fast processors, our puny mortal brains won't be able to keep up with the future of AI. But Musk thinks Neuralink could help bridge the communication gap between AI and humans. Do you think we'll be able to keep up with AI? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte

What happens when TV's iconic "Westworld" actress @evanrachelwood and the world's most famous real-life humanoid robot, @realsophiarobot, have a chance encounter in a swanky NY hotel bar? Find out in "SophiaWorld", premiering September 4th only on Futurism.com

Here's some sweet news: the inside of Saturn might flow like honey. Using the data from the final transmission of the Cassini spacecraft which plunged itself into Saturn in 2017 scientists have made a remarkable discovery about the gas giant: its liquid interior might be viscous, flowing like honey. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what we learned from Cassini's "death dive

A newly proposed kind of space elevator could actually work. Researchers from Columbia University and Cambridge University published a new document which proposes the creation of "the Spaceline" which would link the Earth and the Moon. It could drastically cut the cost of space travel. The Spaceline would be tethered to the surface of the Moon and dangle down into geostationary orbit around the Earth like a plumb bob, waiting for astronauts to latch on and ride into the cosmos. It could even be built from materials that exist today, putting the cosmos virtually within reach of our fingertips. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism.com

A mysterious disease affecting people who vape is sweeping the U.S. but experts still have no idea what's causing it. The illness has now claimed its first life, igniting an urgency at the CDC to investigate why there's now a surge in reported cases. If vaping were a brand-new practice, the illnesses might make more sense. But e-cigarettes and vapes have been around for years. So why are so many people experiencing serious vaping-related health issues now including death over just the past few months? Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

We probably should have seen this coming: kids are becoming emotionally attached to robots. Todays toddlers and preschoolers are growing up surrounded by friendly-looking, sometimes humanlike robotic devices and educational tools a phenomenon that scientists warn could be confusing. While young children tend to understand that the robotic helpers all around them arent truly alive, toddlers tend to form emotional ties with the bots a phenomenon that has some researchers concerned. Researchers advise parents to be mindful about the way they talk about robots. Don't ascribe the bot a gender, and remind impressionable children that their toys are merely machines. Tap the link in our bio to read about this and more on Futurism.com

Full steam ahead! Scientists are working on a new low-cost, efficient way to get satellites up into space. Instead of launching rockets from the ground, a team from the Finnish Meteorology Institute is investigating whether satellites could be lifted up into orbit through steam-filled balloons and launched from there. Tap the link in our bio to read more of the latest stories in science and technology

This steampunk bionic heart uses maglev tech to pump blood and it could keep patients alive until their donor organs arrive. A team of engineers from private medical company Bivacor have been working hard since 2001 on building a bionic heart that can allow cardiac patients to stay alive without a real human heart. The steampunk apparatus works by harnessing the power of magnetic levitation to spin a disc at extremely fast speeds to pump blood to the body and return oxygen-depleted blood to the lungs. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this fascinating piece of biotechnology

Super-intelligent AI could totally crush humanity if it wanted to. As tech corporations like Facebook and Google, and government research firms like the Pentagons DARPA or Russias Advanced Research Foundation try to create super-powered artificial general intelligence, precautions must be taken to prevent an AI takeover from happening. But is anyone really working on this? Wim Naud, a professorial fellow at the United Nations University, argues that the government needs to step in, both to make sure artificial general intelligence benefits the public at large and to make sure nobody unleashes a malicious algorithm on humanity. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Get rekt scrub. YouTube is suing a man who allegedly swatted a Minecraft streamer. But that wasn't until after he tried to extort money from them. On Monday, YouTube filed a lawsuit against a Nebraska man for allegedly abusing the platforms copyright takedown process. According to the suit, Omahas Christopher Brady filed false copyright notices against at least three popular Minecraft streamers. He then attempted to extort money from the YouTubers and even launched a swatting attack (a form of criminal harassment in which a person contacts emergency services to falsely report a serious crime) against one. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism.com

Cyberwarfare may seem like a problem for only big tech companies to worry about, but the impact of an attack can have devastating real-life consequences for society. Jeremy Straub, an assistant professor of computer science at North Dakota State University, argues that a cyberattack can be just as damaging as a nuclear weapon, wreaking havoc on transportation, health, and communications and could even lead to deaths. What do you think? Do you worry about your cybersecurity? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte

We finally have a cure for the deadliest strain of the most common infectious cause of death on Earth: tuberculosis. The Food and Drug Administration just approved the third and final part of a new drug regimen shown to cure the deadliest strain of tuberculosis, XDR, in 90 percent of people. Patients take five pills every day for six months straight, but thats nothing compared to the existing treatment, which requires 40 pills every day for two years. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope

*monch, monch* Looks like Jupiter may have eaten one of its planet siblings. Jupiters core is a bizarre mix of solid rocks mixed with a diffuse bubble of hydrogen gas. And the story of how it got that way has long eluded explanation. But now scientists think theyre on to something, suggesting that the gas giant absorbed another protoplanet during a head-on collision some 4.5 billion years ago when our solar system was forming. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the origin story of our solar system's largest planet

Kaboom. This is the explosion of the most massive star to ever detonate into a brutal supernova that scientists have ever witnessed. Like, ever. The European Space Agency scientists spotted the stellar explosion, dubbed SN2016iet, back in 2016 but it took three years of analysis and follow-up investigations for them to comprehend they had seen. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this stunning explosion

Woof. This doggie monstrosity named "Astro" is the stuff of nightmares. Researchers from Florida Atlantic University (FAU) set out to build a robodog that combined all the best parts of Siri, 3D-printing, and nimble, next-gen robots like Boston Dynamics SpotMini. Unfortunately, Astros engineers added an extra component to the bot: horrible, human-like eyes. Tap the link in our bio to see the strange pup in action

In the future, weapons may be able to target us using only our DNA. Humanity can't afford to wait when it comes to defending ourselves against biological weapons. According to a new report out of Cambridge University, world governments have failed to prepare for futuristic weapons based on advanced technology like artificial intelligence and genetic manipulation or even a killer pathogen designed to kill only people of a particular race. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Sometimes, people are just too funny, and too clever for their own good. One cybersecurity expert learned this lesson the hard way when he tested a galaxy-brain plan to hide his car from license plate readers and ticketing systems by registering the vanity license plate NULL. His plan worked, sort of the NULL plates definitely caused a problem within the system. But they also caused a citation processing center to send the guy, who goes by Droogie in the cybersec community, $18,000 worth of parking tickets and other fines. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Who knew mice could be such great listeners? The future of deepfake detection could be in the tiny paws of mice like this one. The rodents seem to have impeccable hearing when it comes to detecting deepfaked audio. Researchers at the University of Oregon believe they can train mice to listen for irregularities in recorded speech, the kind that can crop up in audio deepfakes and so far, the rodents seem to show promise as organic deepfake detectors. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these tiny detectives

I spy with my bionic eye... Researchers from visual prosthetics company Second Second Sight Medical Products have created a new bionic eye system that sends electrical signals to the wearers brain via an implant, allowing them to see again. They say that not only will the devices grant improved fields of visual depth, but could also give wearers infrared vision. Talk about "eye-opening" insights! Tap the link in our bio to read this and more stories on Futurism.com

If you ever wanted to live off noodles, here's your chance. Nissin, the company behind one prominent line of instant ramen noodle packets, is poised to launch a new All-In Noodles product that, it says, fully satisfies a typical persons nutritional requirements. Nissin isnt the first company to try its hand at cheap, easy meal replacements but if you've ever wanted to try your hand at living off an all-noodle diet, there's no time like the present. Tap the link in our bio to read more stories like this on Futurism.com

It's back... After being removed by Facebook, the event called Storm Area 51 has been resurrected. But no advanced extraterrestrial technology was behind the move: according to a spokesperson for Facebook, the event was removed by mistake. Oops... The resurrected Facebook event still has more than 2 million loyal followers enlisted to join the fray. While there's never been a shortage of "Area 51" paraphernalia, popular events like this have encouraged the creation of all kinds of official "Storm Area 51" merch. Tap the link in bio to read this and more on Futurism.com

Finally, just what we needed, a robotic tail you can wear. Scientists at Keio University built a robotic tail called Arque with built-in artificial muscles and vertebrae. The tail uses a pneumatic system to bend and move along with the wearer, acting as a smart counterbalance as they lean over or sway. Practical applications are... uncertain. While the robot tail is still fairly limited in functionality, its an unusual glimpse into the future of human-augmenting technology. Tap the link in our bio to see a video of the tail in action

"You got to do what you got to do to protect your child." For parents in America, back-to-school shopping this year is about more than buying notebooks and binders its about giving their child the best possible chance of surviving a school shooting. Sales of bulletproof backpacks have sharply increased, but unfortunately, the backpacks arent quite as bulletproof as their name implies they're not effective against bullets from rifles. Tap the link in our bio to read more

It may sound like a paradox, but some icy planets could be warm enough to support life. Hear us out. New research by a team of astronomers at the University of Toronto suggests that extraterrestrial life could survive on icy planets which, until now, were thought to be too cold. They ran thousands of simulations to explore the temperature fluctuations of planets inside habitable zones and found large unfrozen areas of land where life could persist. Tap the link in our bio to read more

This blurry blob of a planet is basically Hell in the shape of a football. An international team of astronomers has found a distant exoplanet thats being deformed into the shape of a football by the brutal gravitational pull of its host star. A paper about the bizarre planet that was published today in the Astronomical Journal, explaining that these planets are so heavily irradiated by their host stars, theyre almost like stars themselves. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this strange misshapen discovery

Can we build robots that are indistinguishable from humans? An artificial intelligence first passed the Turing Test in 2014, and now, a team of researchers from Staffordshire University has taken it one step further by creating a way to test whether a machine can act just like a human, as well as think like one. They call it a "Multimodal Turing Test," and they hope it will one day help answer the question posed above. What do you think? Can we do it? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more

The future of warfare is a mysterious AI with a "brain." The U.S. military has been developing a top-secret artificial brain military AI system that they named seriously Sentient. Newly released confidential and classified documents describe the Sentient Program as a fully-integrated intelligence system that can coordinate satellite positions and may soon be used to manage battlefield operations during military engagements. That means algorithms, with all their dangerous built-in biases, could be directing military conflicts in the near future. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Animal embryos + Human cells = the future of organ transplants? A Japanese scientist from the University of Tokyo just got permission from the government to create animal embryos that contain human cells ethically perilous work that could lead, eventually, to growing human organs in animal hosts for the purpose of transplantation. Would you accept an organ you needed if it was grown inside an animal? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more

Some of the design features used on social media are so addictive that even Silicon Valley parents dont want their kids using the services they create. A new bill before the Senate aims to ban social media and tech platforms from implementing addictive designs and features including autoplaying videos or endless scrolling. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Women have been integral to space travel from commanding the ISS to calculating the math to send us into space safely. And now NASA says the next astronaut to touch down on the Moon will "likely be a woman." But not everyone agrees with this plan. Retired NASA astronaut and former International Space Station commander Peggy Whitson is rebuking NASAs plan, saying she doesnt think gender should have anything to do with the Moonwalker decision. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Mmm... nothing better than the smell of a crispy, plant-based meat substitute frying on a griddle. Beyond Meat, the successful plant-based meat company, has a new faux-meat product on the horizon and it might just be your favorite breakfast food. Arguably the king of animal product-based breakfast foods, fake bacon could eventually make its way into staple breakfast menu items like breakfast sandwiches. Would you try it? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more

Whew, that was a close one. A space rock that could have leveled an entire city just hurtled right past Earth, coming within six Earth diameters of smashing into our home planet. Astronomers didnt spot the city killer asteroid until days before it careened closer to the Earth than the Moon at about 61 times the speed of a commercial jet. And if it had hit us? It would have exploded with more energy than a nuclear weapon. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Headstones and eulogies are about to get a lot more interesting. The future is filled with exciting new possibilities including horrible new ways to die. When will the first person die from a vengeful sex robot? What about a leak in your off-brand spacesuit? For that matter, wholl be the first person to escape the traditional age of death living to be 1,000 years old, or even far longer? Tap the link in our bio to read our predictions for the future of death, and let us know in the comments which futuristic way to die sounds the worst

A strange pair of dead stars rapidly orbiting each other's corpses could shed light on everything from black holes to the birth of our universe. Every three nights, the California Institute of Technologys Zwicky Transient Facility uses its massive 576-megapixel camera to scan the entire sky, leading to the detection of hundreds of asteroids, comets, and supernovae. But the survey may have just made its strangest discovery yet: a binary white dwarf system called ZTF J1539+5027. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this bizarre bunch

A tiny implant about the size of a penny could revolutionize the future of HIV prevention. Today, people with a high risk of contracting HIV can choose to take a daily medication called pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) which can prevent them from catching the virus. But just like some people have trouble remembering to take their birth control pill every day, theres a chance a person might forget to consistently take their PrEP, which makes it far less effective. Now, global biopharmaceutical company Merck thinks its found a solution to this problem: an implant that delivers a years worth of HIV-preventing medication gradually. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the future of sexual health

RT: and I oop! Chris Wetherell, the guy who built Twitters retweet function, wishes he hadnt. Before 2009, people had to manually repost other peoples tweets onto their own accounts, something that required at least some amount of conscious effort and thought. With a retweet button, sharing and amplifying content online became more impulsive and less thoughtful a shift that led to an explosion of disinformation online. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Where in the world is John McAfee? The man who wants to be the next U.S. president is missing and therell be hell to pay if he doesnt turn up soon. McAfees campaign manager sent several tweets from his bosss account claiming he now has good reason to suspect that McAfee who has been running his campaign in exile since January to avoid charges of tax fraud has been detained. And if he doesn't show up soon? McAfee allegedly has "secreted data" hidden across the globe to be released upon his disappearance. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what might be in these mysterious "data payloads

As if colonizing space wasn't hard enough, one scientist claims that babies born in space won't even be fully human. Evolutionary biologist Scott Solomon says childbirth in space will be incredibly difficult, making cesarean deliveries the norm for space explorers which could lead to babies evolving larger, alien-like heads. Eventually, people living in space could evolve to be different enough from people on Earth that we would consider them to be different species, Solomon says. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the evolutionary changes facing future human space colonists

Astronomers have a new theory about the formation of supermassive black holes. Long-dead celestial objects called "dark stars" may have become today's supermassive black holes. Extremely bright objects that first appeared close to the birth of the universe theoretical objects called dark stars could have seeded supermassive black holes over millions of years, according to a new "Astronomy" story about University of Michigan physicist Katherine Freese. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the formation of these galactic behemoths

Red pill, blue pill, or pill 3D-printed specifically to contain every medicine you are prescribed? Personalized pharmaceutical products company Multiply Labs envisions a future in which patients can finally say goodbye to swallowing a cocktail of different pills organized in a plastic divider case. The startups promise: a single, 3D-printed daily capsule tailored around the needs of each patient. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of medicine.

Scientists made mice hallucinate by shining light at their brains, and now they're wondering why humans aren't hallucinating all the time. Unless you suffer from a neurological disorder, such as schizophrenia or like to dabble in psychedelics chances are you dont spend much time worrying about seeing things that arent there. But now, a team led by researchers from Stanford University believes its found a way to make mice, and therefore potentially humans, hallucinate and what they discovered has left them wondering why humans arent hallucinating all the time. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

"Digital fur technology" will transform the star-studded cast of the upcoming cinematic remake of the Broadway show Cats." Increasingly complicated software and algorithms have slowly been helping Hollywood to tackle challenging animated effects. Detailed fine fur, for example, is very difficult to animate because of its complexity. Now "digital fur technology" is being credited with creating more realistic looking human-cat hybrids than we've probably ever seen before. Tap the link in our bio to read more and see a behind the scenes clip

Ready or not, bionic enhancements are coming. Will they change what it means to be human? Theoretical neuroscientist Vivienne Ming has focused her professional career on exploring ways to use tech to maximize human potential but in a fascinating new Quartz essay, she details how she has also channeled her inner mad scientist for an intensely personal reason. According to Ming, after her son was diagnosed with autism, she put her expertise to work to build a face- and expression-recognition system for Google Glass designed to interpret others facial expressions in real-time, a skill which most neurotypical people are born with but one that may seem like a superpower to someone with autism. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

There may be fundamental flaws with our understanding of the universe. A new attempt by scientists to calculate the Hubble Constant which represents how rapidly the universe is expanding outward has revealed some troubling gaps in our understanding. The discrepancy in scientists' numbers calls into question not only our idea of how old the universe is, but also our ability to fundamentally understand the physics that drive its behavior. Tap the link in our bio to learn more

Careful out there. The guards of Area 51 are fully prepared to defend it against intruders. Over 1.3 million Facebook users have clicked "Going" to a tongue-in-cheek Facebook event called Storm Area 51, They Cant Stop All of Us with the goal of storming the secret Air Force base in the Nevada desert in search of aliens. But be warned: those defending Area 51 are authorized to use deadly force," if necessary. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Mark your calendars. Elon Musk's mysterious neurotechnology startup, Neuralink, is finally going to break its silence this Thursday. The company, founded in 2016, is focused on finding a way to directly link the human brain to computers and soon we might finally learn what they're achieved these past few years. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Don't worry, mommy is here to tuck you in. It turns out robots really could take over all jobs including being a parent. According to author and AI ethics expert John C. Havens, bots could become very efficient caregivers, good enough to one day steal the right to raise children away from humans. What do you think? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more

Are you ready to join the front line in the search for extraterrestrial life? Almost 300,000 people say they're going to storm Area 51 to look for aliens at least that's according to who has RSVP'd to a Facebook event called Storm Area 51, They Cant Stop All of Us. The page has amassed an army of memers, schemers and tinfoil hat-wearing conspirators who are ready to raid the top-secret Air Force military base in the middle of Nevadas desert. Tap the link in our bio to read more

"Its really a life-changing thing. Australian surgeon Natasha van Zyl has dramatically improved the lives of 13 people who suffered total paralysis in all four of their limbs after sporting and traffic accidents. By moving around the nerves in their appendages using a technique known as "nerve transfer," van Zyl restored the patients ability to extend their elbows and grasp and pinch with their hands and she thinks many others could experience the same benefits. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Here's Jimmy! Someone has finally done it: they used machine learning to superimpose the face of Jim Carrey onto Jack Nicholsons character in Stanley Kubricks iconic 1980 adaptation of Stephen Kings The Shining. In terms of mapping Carreys face onto Nicholsons complex performance, it's one of the most impressive deepfakes weve seen. Lets be real, though you just want to see it. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video and read more

Should we risk experimenting on humans especially when the intervention is not necessary to save their lives? This is the question scientists are asking themselves about Denis Rebrikov the Russian biologist who wants to use CRISPR to create more gene-edited babies. Rebrikob has five pairs of Russian parents eager to let him gene-edit their embryos for a very controversial reason: to prevent the offspring from inheriting their parents deafness. But are the benefits of hearing worth the risks of gene editing? Let us know what you think in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more

Sorry to disappoint, but that big floating space rock 'Oumuamua wasn't sent by aliens. In 2017, an asteroid came barreling past the Earth. And not only did it hail from outside our solar system, but it also had a weird shape and spin, plus it accelerated in an unexpected way while passing the Sun. Astronomers dubbed the strange asteroid Oumuamua, and soon, speculation swirled that the object was sent by aliens but a new study sheds some light on its true origins. Tap the link in our bio to read more

We may never know when the third CRISPR-edited baby is born. The Chinese government has kept quiet in the face of news that a third CRISPR birth is expected soon. Either theres no news to report, or the Chinese government is closely controlling the information surrounding the massive scientific controversy. Tap the link in our bio to read more

This is big. Really big. For the first time ever, researchers have eliminated HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, from the genomes of living animals a major accomplishment along the path to freeing the world of this deadly disease. While the researchers are optimistic, they're also aware that there's a lot of ground to cover between mice and humans. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this amazing breakthrough

Calling all of Earth's citizens! Scientists want to know how you think humanity should react if aliens come calling. Every movie about aliens arriving on Earth tends to show only politicians and scientists deciding what to do. But the UK Seti Research Network thinks the average person should have a say in how Earth responds if aliens ever decide to say hello to humanity. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Your Fourth of July fireworks have nothing on these stunning photos from Hubble. Roughly 7,500 light-years away from Earth is a double star system called Eta Carinae. In 1838, one of the systems two stars underwent a near-death experience astronomers dubbed the Great Eruption, and for nearly two centuries, scientists have been watching the stunning aftermath of that event. NASA and the ESA released new photos of Eta Carinae captured by the Hubble telescope and the most extravagant July 4th firework display won't hold a candle to this cosmic one. While you're celebrating, tap the link in our bio to read more

If you have the money, these Rent-a-Friends have the time. Lots of people think they know how to address the loneliness epidemic sweeping the globe. But this is the strangest effort we've seen yet. Long before loneliness epidemic was even a term, entrepreneur Scott Rosenbaum was already attempting to help people feel less socially isolated by renting friends to them by the hour. Tap the link in our bio to read more (but check out the fine print on that dollar, first

When in doubt, just go to the post office. At least, that would have helped the two men in Southern California who used the dark web to sell more than $8.8 million worth of methamphetamine they marketed as Adderall. The operation appeared to be chugging along quite nicely until the dark web drug dealers made a fatal mistake. The men mailed drugs to undercover federal agents using pre-printed postage purchased online and the feds were able to track that back to them. Tap the link in our bio to read more

We cant travel billions of years back in time at least not yet, anyways. So, until then, one of the best ways to understand how our universe evolved is to create computer simulations of the process using what we do know about it. An international team of researchers has built an AI that can quickly generate highly-accurate, three-dimensional simulations of the universe but somehow, it seems to know more than it's been taught. Tap the link in our bio to read more

"Hmm... Do I detect an apple?" By embedding engineered bacteria into the fingers of a robot arm, researchers have created a biohybrid bot that can taste using its hands and they think it could lead to a future in which robots are better equipped to respond to the world around them. "We are closer to future breakthroughs like soft biohybrid robots that can adapt their abilities to sense, feel, and move in response to changes in their environmental conditions, one researcher said. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Europe is on fire figuratively and, in the case of Spains Catalonia region, literally. A town in southern France called Villevieille just reached the countrys hottest-ever recorded temperature of 45.1 degrees Celsius that's 113 Fahrenheit and its hotter than the recorded highs in the Saharan desert. Some are saying the extreme weather is directly linked to climate change. To others, its a warning shot of whats still yet to come. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Check your pulse or this laser might do it for you. The U.S. Special Forces are developing a device that can detect a persons unique cardiac signature using an IR laser from a distance. Nicknamed Jetson, the tech can work from at least 200 meters away by analyzing tiny vibrations on the surface of the skin to detect a heartbeat even through a layer of clothing. When a biometric facial recognition system fails to get a good view of a targets face, the laser could help correctly identify targets by their pulse. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Forget what you think you know about the universe or at least one dimension of it. A two-dimensional universe may still be able to support life. That statement runs in stark opposition to whats called the anthropic argument, which states that if the fundamental properties of our three-dimensional universe were tweaked, life would no longer be possible. Its a bold claim, but University of California physicist James Scargill did the work to back it up, sharing his theory in a new paper that upends many assumptions about the requirements for life as we know it. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Bitcoin is back from the dead. The popular cryptocurrency has reached the highest value it's had in more than a year and Facebook is likely to blame. The social media giants recent unveiling of its own cryptocurrency called Libra seemed to bolster investors confidence in crypto across the board. Though Bitcoin never really recovered from its massive crash in late 2017, the recent resurgence is a sign that the cryptocurrency isnt quite fading away as some believed. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Apparently, most people in the USA don't really care about getting to Mars. U.S. President Donald Trump recently made it clear he wants NASAs attention on Mars instead of the Moon. But the American people think the space agency should focus on a different planet: Earth. Most of the people polled called monitoring asteroids and comets that could hit the Earth very/extremely important for NASA, but only 27 percent said the same thing about sending humans to Mars revealing a stark disconnect between the priorities of Americans and the administration governing them. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Want to control a robot with your mind? You currently have two options. You can get a brain implant in which case your control over the robot will be smooth and continuous or you can skip the risky, expensive surgery in favor of a device that senses your brainwaves from outside your skull, but your control over the bot will not be nearly as precise. A team from Carnegie Mellon University is narrowing the gap between those two options, creating the first noninvasive mind-controlled robot arm. Tap the link in our bio to read more

3D-printed organs that mimic real flesh and blood could become critical practice tools for doctors and surgeons preparing for complex surgeries like transplants. I just wanted something that looks like a kidney that bleeds, one doctor said, and as 3D printing gets cheaper, rehearsing a surgery on a printed replica of a specific patients organ could become the norm rather than the exception. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Ready to go under the knife in pursuit of the perfect selfie? In 2018, researchers coined the term Snapchat dysmorphia to describe the phenomenon of clients undergoing surgical procedures to look more like themselves or, at least, the heavily filtered versions of themselves theyd often share on social media. According to a new report it seems that "snapchat dysmorphia" and social media in general are driving more teens and young people to go under the knife sometimes in pursuit of downright impossible results. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Three U.S. senators just received a closed-door Pentagon briefing about UFO sightings. The meeting was about a series of sightings by Navy pilots of unidentified aerial phenomenon yet another sign that Congress is starting to take the matter more seriously. The news, reported by Politico, comes after information emerged in April that the Navy is working on new guidelines for its personnel to report sightings and other encounters with unidentified aircraft." Tap the link in our bio to read more

It used to be that you needed to actually discover something in space if you wanted the thrill of naming it but a new competition is ensuring astronomers dont get to have all the fun. The International Astronomical Union recently announced a competition giving every country on Earth the opportunity to name one exoplanet and its host star. (And the pair will be visible to citizens using a small telescope.) Participating countries will have until November 2019 to decide on a name but Planety McPlanetface wont make the cut. Tap the link in our bio to read more

There are dangers caged within the surface of Arctic ice but the Earth's rising temperatures are threatening to release them. Alongside the ancient fossils now peeking up from the melting permafrost lie frozen toxins, nuclear waste, and enough sequestered carbon to double the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere today. Its a dire situation failing to address global climate change has turned the Arctic into a ticking time bomb. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Death comes for us all even galaxies. Astronomers believe our universe is home to at least 100 billion galaxies. And just like us, each of those massive collections of stars and other space stuff will eventually die. But also like us, galaxies go through a host of phases between birth and death. Now, a researcher from the University of Kansas has discovered one scientists never knew about before. She calls it the cold quasar phase and it could completely upend our understanding of how galaxies die. Tap the link in our bio to read more

What would happen if a robot like Dolores from @westworldhbo met Sophia the Robot? That's the premise of our new short film, SophiaWorld, starring @evanrachelwood and @realsophiarobot! From @futurismstudios, SophiaWorld is premiering Sunday, 6/16 at the @mauifilmfest. Keep an eye on our story highlight for behind the scenes and more information.

We feel the need, the need for... well, maybe some ear plugs. An investigation has has revealed several major problems with the US military's F-35 fighter jet including spikes in cabin pressure that cause pilots to experience severe ear and sinus pain. Some pilots also cant fully control the aircrafts pitch, roll, and yaw after completing certain maneuvers and in some conditions, the aircrafts night vision camera displays green horizontal lines that make it difficult for pilots to see the horizon. The F-35 is supposed to play a major role in the future of the U.S. military but the trillion-dollar program may be in even worse shape than the public knows. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Its hard to imagine anything that could kill a black hole. The ultra-dense celestial vacuums consume everything in their paths but that cosmic appetite could theoretically be their undoing as well. Thats according to research from the Israel Institute of Technology. A new model shows that a steady diet of bizarre particles with negative energy could gradually chip away at the immense mass of a black hole until it vanishes into nothing. RIP. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Sorry to disappoint, but alien life is probably way rarer than we thought. Researchers at the University of California, Riverside say that thanks to excessive toxic gases, more than half of the planets we initially thought could harbor alien life are probably dead zones or at least couldnt host life as we know it. But even though those planets are out of the running, it does help narrow down where to look. Tap the link in our bio to read more

"I think I'm crazy enough to do it." These are the words of Russian biologist Denis Rebrikov, who told the journal Nature that he's planning to use CRISPR to gene-edit human embryos and bring them to term as soon as later this year. Rebrikov is following in the footsteps of Chinese researcher He Jiankui, who gene-edited a pair of human babies shocking scientists and researchers across the world, who are calling for a moratorium on similar experiments. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this contentious topic

The Moon has a mystery hidden under its surface and it's the size of an entire island. A team of astronomers found a large excess of mass under the Moons largest crater, the Aitken basin likely a relic from an ancient asteroid impact event, but perhaps something much stranger. Imagine taking a pile of metal five times larger than the Big Island of Hawaii and burying it underground, said lead author Peter B. James from Baylor University in Waco, Texas in a statement. Thats roughly how much unexpected mass we detected. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Hey! Down in front! There's something blocking the view of the black hole in our Milky Way. Scientists just got their best look yet at the accretion disk a halo of gas swirling around the supermassive black hole at the core of the Milky Way. Existing X-ray observations have shown that our black holes accretion disk includes an inner layer of superhot gas. But new research confirms for the first time that theres a cooler, outer layer of gas in the accretion disk that hides the rest of the halo from view and it could help explain how black holes behave. Tap the link in our bio to learn more

Alan Turing, who during World War II helped the Allies break Nazi codes and later came to be regarded as a pioneer in computing and artificial intelligence, finally got a proper sendoff in the form of a New York Times obituary. Not only did Turing help decrypt seemingly-unbreakable Nazi codes during WWII, but he also helped kickstart the entire field of artificial intelligence. But in spite of his scientific contributions, Turing died by suicide in 1954 after the British government convicted him of homosexuality a crime in the U.K. until 1967 and chemically castrated him as punishment. Were sorry. You deserved so much better, said then-Prime Minister Gordon Brown in 2009. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Your next vacation could be out of this world! Literally. NASA just announced that it will officially allow regular citizens, not just certified astronauts, on board the International Space Station but tickets to the ISS wont come cheap. NASA will be charging private companies about $35,000 a night for use of the stations facilities. And thats not including what the companies will charge individuals for transportation to and from the Space Station. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Can you guess what's in this image? Here's a hint: nothing can escape it and it recently had its first official portrait taken. It's a black hole! Or, at least, a simulation of one. Its been less than two months since scientists released the first actual image of a black hole, but astronomers have been studying the strange phenomena for more than a century. One modern tool is helping: computer simulations that allow researchers to visualize black holes in otherwise-impossible detail. Tap the link in our bio to see more

Found: Schrdingers cat, alive and well. It might be the most famous feline that never lived. Or that never died, depending on your perspective. In 1935, physicist Erwin Schrdinger concocted a thought experiment to illustrate a pair of strange quantum physics phenomena: superposition and unpredictability. The experiment became known as Schrdingers cat, and for more than 80 years, its served as a cornerstone of quantum physics. But in a newly published study, a team of Yale scientists essentially destroys the premise at the center of the experiment groundbreaking work that could finally allow researchers to develop useful quantum computers. Tap the link in our bio to read more

The technology to create believable deepfakes computer-generated media depicting real people doing or saying things that never occurred is already here and widely accessible. And yet, as America moves towards its 2020 presidential election, Axios reports that not a single candidate can point to measures theyve taken to prevent the spread of this potentially-dangerous media. Tap the link in our bio to read more

A new flying-v plane would put passenger seats in the wings of the plane. Airlines are testing all sorts of ways to make planes less of a drag on the environment. Virgin Atlantic recently used recycled waste to power a commercial flight, while Boeing and JetBlue have backed an effort to create hybrid electric planes. The Netherlands KLM Royal Dutch Airlines is taking a different approach. It just partnered with a university to develop a radical new airplane designand it could decrease the amount of fuel needed for flights by a substantial 20 percent. Tap the link in our bio to read more. :KLM / TU Delft

Scientists say it's more important than ever to regulate CRISPR or we risk its use to create gray-market enhanced human beings. Chinese researchers have found a way to nearly triple the efficiency of a tool designed to edit genes in human embryos, and their method should be ready for clinical use soon, with gene-edited babies available in another year or two, says Yang Hui, the lead researcher behind the project. But even she is concerned that her teams technological breakthrough could have dire consequences. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Have you seen an extra sparkle in the night sky? Maybe not without a good telescope. But some scientists have been seeing weird flashes of light on the moon. Several times a week, short bursts of light appear on the surface of the Moon and so far, scientists have only been able to guess as to why. But a team of German astronomers has a new theory and it could provide crucial information for humans who want to settle the Moon. Tap the link in our bio to read more

We know you love Fluffy, but cloning your pet might not be a great idea. Today, anyone can have their dog cloned for $50,000, and that price drop means the service is now starting to hit the mainstream. But experts say pet cloning is overhyped and borders on animal cruelty: All cloned animals have shorter life spans and many more health problems than non-cloned animals. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why you should not See Spot Cloned

Its no secret that DeepMinds artificial intelligence has become a champion at video games like StarCraft II and Dota 2. But now, the AI has figured out how to ace cooperative multiplayer mode as wellin fact, it may be better at it than human players. While playing rounds of capture the flag in the classic first-person shooter Quake III Arena, DeepMind was able to outperform human teammates and with the reaction time slowed down to that of a typical human player. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Stephen Hawking was on to something when, in 1974, he proposed that black holes emit small streams of particles at their event horizons. These particles became know as Hawking radiation, and based on the physicists predictions, a black holes mass should determine its temperature. Researchers from the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology tested his theory, but by creating a different kind of black hole one that absorbs sound in the lab, and measuring the temperature of its Hawking radiation. The measurements matched what Hawking had predicted 45 years ago but we wont know for sure if his theory holds up in space until were able to test the theory on the light-absorbing black holes populating our universe. Tap the link in our bio to learn more
