Have you ever heard of parthenogenesis? Well, a snake at the New England Aquarium just did it: an anaconda named Anna had a "virgin birth" in which she produced offspring without ever having mated. Scientists at the New England Aquarium confirmed last week that one of their snakes gave birth without ever mating with a male, producing three little anacondas with identical DNA to their mother. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this fascinating genetic fluke

If startups selling alleged brain-enhancing wearables are to be believed, their brain-zapping headsets will help you rapidly learn new skills, stave off neurological disease, and become an elite athlete. But because thats not the case, scientists and ethicists are urging the companies to dial back their bold claims because the science, they say, simply doesnt hold up. Tap the link in our bio to learn more

Plasma is the most common form of matter in our universe, but it's extremely difficult to study. But there's good news: by studying the plasma in the Suns atmosphere its gases exist primarily in plasma form since, obviously, its extremely hot researchers say we could learn how to control the plasma here on Earth and finally make fusion energy a reality. EDIT: The missing link to this article has now been added! Tap the url in our bio to read more

Bad news, people. The Earths oceans are gradually leaking into the interior of the planet. Thats according to new research by Norwegian scientists who say the Earths water is slowly draining into the planets crust though nowhere near fast enough to cancel out the sea level rises were currently experiencing because of climate change. Tap the link in our bio to read more

For a $1.2 million dollar bid, you could own a 2008 Samsung laptop containing six of the most infamous computer viruses in history. The infectious computer is an art project titled The Persistence of Chaos, created in collaboration between Chinese internet artist Guo O Dong and cybersecurity company Deep Instinct. Guo explained the reasoning behind his creation as a kind of bestiary, a catalogue of historical threats. Malware is "one of the most tangible ways that the internet can jump out of your monitor and bite you, Guo said. Tap the link in our bio to read more

In order to combat superbugs bacteria that have evolved to survive even the most potent antibiotics doctors have started to gene-hack viruses to hunt and kill dangerous strains. Scientists have tried to use CRISPR gene-editing tools to modify viruses to kill off dangerous bacteria and ignore healthy gut bacteria for several years. But now a company called Locus Biosciences developed a mixture of three CRISPR-edited viruses that can infect and kill dangerous bacteria like a living antibiotic a promising new weapon in the fight against antibiotic resistance. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Here's a new one: a flirting chatbot aptly named "Slutbot" was created to teach people how to responsibly and respectfully flirt and sext through an iOS app called Juicebox. The idea of getting intimate with a chatbot might seem odd, but the goal is for Slutbot to help people learn to navigate conversations around sexuality and consent without the risk of alienating or insulting another person. As a queer woman collaborating with sex educators and erotic fiction writers, we were the right people to think through these concerns, Juicebox founder Brianna Rader told . Tap the link in our bio to read more

For the first time, police in the U.K. are going to have to defend their use of facial recognition tech in court. British office worker Ed Bridges is claiming that South Wales Police scanned his face at least twice without his permission. He believes these scans violated his human rights, an assertion he will present during a three-day court hearing that kicked off in Cardiff on Tuesday and if the court agrees with Bridges, the ruling could profoundly alter future use of facial recognition tech by law enforcement. Tap the link in our bio to learn more

A team from the University of Cambridge unveiled a video featuring a fleet of mini robot cars capable of autonomously switching lanes while navigating a two-lane track. The cars had a special ability: they could communicate with each other via WiFi. According to the experiments, that capability dramatically improved traffic flow evidence that well need to teach autonomous vehicles to talk to one another if we want to take full advantage of self-driving tech. Tap the link in our bio to see them navigate

Its sadly ironic: If Earth becomes uninhabitable and we look to other planets for a new home, the only way to ensure the long term survival of the human species might be to become a completely different species. Scientists have set their sights on getting humans to Mars and maybe even terraforming the Red Planetbut despite the resources being funneled into technology to transport us to Mars, we dont yet understand the evolutionary implications the move will have on the human body. Evolutionary biologist Scott Solomon thinks its worth asking what will happen to Martian colonists in the long term as mutations start to cascade through the gene pool. Tap the link in our bio to read more

UN officials are very worried about the possibility of radioactive waste leaking from a "coffin" in the ocean. Between 1946 and 1958, the U.S. government tested 67 nuclear weapons in the Marshall Islands. It later dumped radioactive waste from the tests into a crater on one of the islands, placing an 18-inch-thick concrete dome over the horrifying sludge. Because the crater was only supposed to be a temporary storage solution, the bottom of it was unlined. Thats led to recent concerns that the coffin is leaking radioactive waste into the Pacific Ocean a potentially devastating blow to both the environment and the people of the region. Tap the link in our bio to read more

In the coming years, scientists plan to grow human embryos in a lab using high-tech artificial wombs. Doctors at the Childrens Hospital of Philadelphia are in talks with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to begin testing artificial wombs on human embryos within the next two years, according to Metro. If theyre successful, the research could radically change the way we view pregnancy, childbirth, and perhaps even human evolution. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Scientists say that something mysterious punched gigantic, cosmic bullet holes in parts of the Milky Way. Theres a string of holes in a long stream of stars called GD-1 that suggests that some yet-undiscovered thing blasted its way through, according to research presented to the American Physical Society last month. Harvard-Smithsonian astrophysicist Ana Bonaca, the scientist who discovered the cosmic crime scene, suspects that the gigantic bullet holes may have been carved out by invisible dark matter. Tap the link in our bio to read more

San Francisco is preemptively shooting down the use of facial recognition. On Tuesday, the California metropolis Board of Supervisors voted 8-to-1 to ban its government agencies from using facial recognition tech despite the fact that none of the agencies currently use the technology. That makes San Francisco the first city in the United States to pass such a ban and the decision could inspire others to follow suit. Tap the link in our bio to read more

R.I.P. to the grumpiest cat there ever was. The famously dour-looking internet sensation Grumpy Cat has passed away, according to obituaries by CNN and the New York Times. We could mourn the feline and move on to the next weird internet animal. Or we could embrace the latest in genetic technology and clone her like iconic singer Barbra Streisand famously did with her dog. But is that the legacy wed want for Grumpy Cat, who reportedly had a sweet personality that clashed with her perpetually ticked-off facial expression? Tap the link in our bio to read more

When stars explode and die, they tend to swallow and incinerate everything around them. But sometimes exoplanets survive, left to drift the galaxy as celestial orphans. Now, a team of astronomers from the U.S. and Europe determined which planets are most likely to survive the deaths of the white dwarf stars they orbit, according to new research. Small, dense, and distant exoplanets have the best odds, which could help astronomers pinpoint even more planets in the remote cosmos. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Have you seen this man? Or, at least, have you seen his look-a-like? The New York Police Department used photos of the acclaimed actor Woody Harrelson to catch his Doppelgngerwho was a suspected shoplifter. According to a new report, NYPD detectives noticed that a suspected shoplifter resembled Harrelson, so when the grainy surveillance footage didnt result in any useful matches in their facial recognition system, they decided to try a high-quality photo of the actor. It came up with a match, and they later arrested the look-alike for petty larcenyadding to the mounting evidence that police are using facial recognition technology however they see fit. Tap the link in our bio to read more

CRISPR: Not for playing around. Josiah Zayner rose to internet fame after performing various biohacking stunts on himself including a livestreamed attempt to edit his own genes using CRISPR. Those antics are coming to haunt Zayner. Now, the California Department of Consumer Affairs is investigating a complaint of unlicensed practice of medicine filed against him a strange development that could have implications for the future of biohacking. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Did you know that about 10 percent of people are left-handed, but among great pond snails lefties are even rarer? Only two percent are born with shells that are left-coiling, spiraling counter-clockwise from their smallest point. But in 2016, a Japanese scientist posited that a single gene controlled whether a snail would be right- or left-coiled. Now, she and her team have seemingly proved that the theory is correct by using CRISPR to create lefty snails a discovery that could one day help unravel the mysteries of human biology. Tap the link in our bio to read more
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

Parked Teslas keep catching fire for seemingly no reason a disturbing pattern for which the company appears to have no explanation. On April 21, a Tesla Model S burst into flames in a Shanghai parking garage. Less than two weeks later, one of the vehicles caught fire in a San Francisco parking garage. Now, Hong Kong-based newspaper Apple Daily is reporting yet another Tesla fire, and once again the vehicle was parked at the time of ignition. Tap the link in our bio to read more

Weve all seen heartbreaking pictures of dolphins trapped in plastic six-pack rings. But new research suggests that plastic pollution is hurting marine life in far subtler ways that could have dire consequences for the entire world ecosystem and threatening ten percent of the Earth's supply of breathable air. A sea-dwelling, photosynthetic bacteria called Prochlorococcus generates a tenth of the oxygen we breathe, but according to research published Tuesday in the journal Nature Communications Biology, chemicals leaching into the water from waste plastic are stunting the bacterias growth at a genetic level and potentially depriving the Earth of a precious source of breathable air. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this startling discovery

When Starlink, the planned constellation of SpaceX satellites that will blanket the planet, goes live in the mid 2020s, CEO Elon Musk will have a chance to give the world the gift of a free and open internet. When the satellites start beaming down high-speed internet, Musk could decide to blanket the planet with free, unrestricted internet access, returning some semblance of net neutrality to the planet something the United States has arguably been missing since the FCC gutted American net neutrality protections last year. Will Musk decide to support a free, neutral internet? Tap the link in our bio to read more

Could re-freezing Earth's melting North and South Poles be the key to stopping the rise of our sea levels? Scientists from Cambridge University are launching a new research center to investigate possible solutions for how to re-engineer the planet to prevent or reduce the worst effects of climate change. David King, the former chief scientific adviser to the U.K. government, is among them and he says some of the solutions the research center will investigate may be considered drastic. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their efforts

These are neurons grown from the reprogrammed skin cells of science writer Philip Ball. When Ball donated some flesh from his arm to a neuroscience lab growing mini brains, he originally intended to contribute to research into the biological mechanisms of dementia. Instead, he ended up with a simplified genetic replica of his own brain growing in a petri dish and found himself questioning what makes us human, according to Ball's upcoming book "How to Grow a Human: Adventures in Who We Are and How We Are Made." Tap the link in our bio to read more

Ever since Einstein posited that space and time were inextricably linked, scientists have wondered where the cosmic web called spacetime comes from. Now, ongoing research in quantum physics may finally arrive at an explanation: A bizarre phenomenon called quantum entanglement could be the underlying basis for the four dimensions of space and time in which we all live, according to a deep dive by Knowable Magazine. In fact, in a mind-boggling twist, our reality could be a hologram of this quantum state. Tap the link in our bio to learn more

Jeff Bezos finally revealed the long-awaited plans for his private space company Blue Origin to send a lander to the Moon at a mysterious press event Thursday. Bezos showed off the brand new design of a Blue Moon lander, which is designed to carry 6.5 tons to the surface of the Moon, and took three years to build. A very fundamental long-range problem is that we will run out of energy on Earth, Bezos said at the event. This is just arithmetic. It will happen. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Bezos's big announcement

Chris Hughes helped Mark Zuckerberg launch Facebook. But times have changed. In a New York Times op-ed titled Its Time to Break Up Facebook, Hughes argues that Facebook has gained too much power and that it should be broken up and regulated. Its been 15 years since I co-founded Facebook at Harvard, and I havent worked at the company in a decade, Hughes wrote. But I feel a sense of anger and responsibility. Tape the link in our bio to read more
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

Well give you the bad news first: A newly-discovered gene gives infectious bacteria the ability to survive even the strongest antibiotics. Oh, and it's highly mobile. Cornell University biologists found the bacterial gene mcr-9, which when activated makes bacteria resistant to an antibiotic of last resort called colistin. If bacteria with the gene were to spread, doctors could find themselves facing a dangerous and perhaps untreatable superbug. Click the link in our bio to learn more

Criminals are going to have a tougher time using the dark web for illegal activity. On Tuesday, the FBI announced the seizure of Deep Dot Web, a website that provided links to dark web marketplaces the latest example of law enforcement cracking down on the shadowy side of the internet. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the FBI's fight against the dark web

Who's that Pokmon? Seasoned Pokmon masters likely know the original 151 like the back of their hand. And now, new research reveals how thats possible: brain scans show the region of the brain responsible for storing information about Pokmon. It doesn't quite suggest that our brains have a truly hard-wired"Pokmon region" but rather, researchers found, may suggest that our brains categorize information in similar ways. Given the unique style of Pokmon it's likely gamers' brains developed similar systems for pattern recognition which serves to teach us about the ways humans learn. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

What you're seeing here is a 3D printed "lung" the size of a penny. Scientists just took a major step forward in 3D printed organs with a new lung-like system full of air sacs that can expand and contract pumping oxygen into blood just like normal lungs do. Bioprinted organs could someday help people who are waiting, and sometimes dying, on the organ transplant waitlist. Tap the link in our bio to see a video of the lung "breathing" and learn more

An extensive HIV study has yielded a groundbreaking discovery: antiretroviral therapy completely eliminates gay mens risk of transmitting HIV through sex. Our findings provide conclusive evidence for gay men that the risk of HIV transmission with suppressive ART is zero, researcher Alison Rodger said in a press release, adding that this powerful message can help end the HIV pandemic by preventing HIV transmission and tackling the stigma and discrimination that many people with HIV face. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this pivotal new research

Fifty years ago, astronaut Buzz Aldrin became the second human to walk on the Moon. Now, hes urging the United States to make putting people on Mars a national priority and hes not talking about just a few lucky astronauts. The United States eyes and our unified commitment should focus on opening the door, in our time, to the great migration of humankind to Mars, Aldrin wrote in an op-ed for The Washington Post. Tap the link in our bio to hear more from Buzz

Google might not be listening through your microphone, but the company can simulate with remarkable accuracy the conversations you're likely to have. Tristan Harris, a former Google design ethicist, says those eerily hyper-targeted ads for the very product you just talked about arent popping up because your phones mic is spying on you. Instead, Google and Facebook have gathered so much data about you and your habits that they can simulate what Harris calls a little voodoo doll, avatar-like version of people in order to predict which ads they might click or products they might buy. Click the link in our bio to read more about the futility of digital privacy
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

In November, Chinese scientist He Jiankui announced that hed genetically edited a human embryo that was implanted into a woman who then gave birth to twin girls, making them the worlds first gene-edited humans. Almost immediately, the scientific community derided the experiment as unethical and risky. Now, some are saying he demonstrated a troubling lack of the requisite understanding of genetics and gene editing meaning the twin girls might not even benefit from the risky procedure. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Marijuana is now legal in California, but an estimated one million people in the state still suffer the consequences of past cannabis convictions. Now, a new algorithm is making it far easier for Californians to have those convictions stricken from their records thereby eliminating the barriers that accompany a criminal record. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

Black holes are already one of the most peculiar phenomena in the universe, but V404 Cygni takes strangeness to the next level. Instead of spewing jets of plasma from its poles, like most black holes, astronomers caught this black hole almost 8,000 light-years from Earth shooting jets in rapidly changing directions all while its gravitational pull dragged the fabric of spacetime itself. We were gobsmacked by what we saw in this system it was completely unexpected." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

"What if we could expand your capabilities beyond what we as humans have ever had before?" Find out in I Am Human a new documentary from @futurismstudios, premiering at the Tribeca Film Festival on May 2nd.

New data from the Hubble Space Telescope confirms that the universe is expanding nine percent more rapidly than theoretical calculations predicted. The new data suggests that the universe could be substantially younger than previously believed perhaps by as much as a billion years! We're going to need to rethink our earlier calculations in order to explain this, but, as Johns Hopkins University astronomer Adam Riess put it, Hey, its good news, everybody likes to look younger. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Researchers have created a nanofiber yarn that they say could help repair damaged muscles and tendons. Essentially biotech sutures, the nanofiber yarn, produced by researchers from MIT and Beihang University, is made by creating tight coils out of hundreds of thousands of aligned nanofibers made from biocompatible materials. The fibers are then seeded with different types of live cells, like muscle cells, which continue to grow on the fiber. The team hopes the material could one day eliminate the need for restrictive boots currently used to help tissue injuries heal. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

This time, artificial intelligence is literally taking jobs. Documents obtained by The Verge show how Amazon used a computer system to automatically track and fire hundreds of fulfillment center employees between for failing to meet productivity quotas a grim glimpse of a future in which AI is your boss. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Amazon's AI automation.

I Spy... Your internet-connected devices share a lot of the information that they collect about you, even when youre not actively using them. Thankfully, a new app will tell you when your smart speaker is spying on you. The Princeton IoT Inspector, built by a team of Princeton University scientists, uses a common hacking technique to track every transmission that a smart home device, such as an Amazon Echo or a smart TV, sends out. Tap the link in our bio to read more.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

Armed with CRISPR gene-editing technology, scientists are trying to move away from performing experiments on common model organisms, like fruit flies and zebrafish, which have long defined biological research by crafting new ones at the genetic level. But scientists developing new organisms are running into a challenging dilemma. The genetic changes made to organisms are taking hold, but it is difficult for researchers to keep the organisms alive for long afterward... Tap the link in our bio to read more.

US airports will scan 97% of outbound flyers faces within four years. That's according to a recent Department of Homeland Security report, which says that U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) plans to dramatically expand its Biometric Exit program to cover 97 percent of outbound air passengers within four years. The goal of the program is purportedly to catch people who have overstayed their visas but some civil liberties experts aren't so enthused... Tap the link in our bio to read more.

There are many things you can will for your remains when you die. Soon, residents of Washington state may have one more option. The state government is one signature away from legalizing the composting of human remains. The process outlined in the legislation, pending the governor's signature, is called recomposition, which involves placing a body in a chamber that accelerates decomposition. Over time the remains are broken down into nutrient-rich soil which can then be safely used for planting purposes adding a more green and sustainable option for your afterlife. What would you like to will for your remains? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Scientists created a new material with artificial metabolism Is it alive? Well, maybe not technically. Even so, it is one step closer to creating a living machine or machines that mimic life as we know it. The new biomaterial built in a Cornell University bioengineering lab uses synthetic DNA to continuously and autonomously organize, assemble, and restructure itself in a process so similar to how biological cells and tissues grow that the researchers are calling artificial metabolism." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

An amazing new rocket engine sucks up atmospheric oxygen for fuel. The potentially revolutionary rocket engine is being prepared for real-world testing within the next 18 months. Reportedly the futuristic hypersonic engines being manufactured by Reaction Engines could be used to cut the journey from London to Sydney to just four hours. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

In 2011 disaster struck the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan when an earthquake-triggered tsunami caused a loss of power leading to three nuclear meltdowns. Apart from being concerned about the potential risk of fallout reaching U.S. soil, the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission turned its attention to another frightening possibility. Could a similar fate affect a U.S. power plant? According to a Bloomberg review of correspondence between the commission and plant owners, 54 of the nuclear plants operating in the U.S. werent designed to handle the flood risk they face. Fifty-three werent built to withstand their current risk from intense precipitation; 25 didnt account for current flood projections from streams and rivers; 19 werent designed for their expected maximum storm surge. Nineteen face three or more threats that they werent designed to handle. And as sea levels continue to rising the risks are only getting greater. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

It's not the East Coast hyperloop Musk envisioned, but it's a start. Nearly two years after Elon Musk first claimed his Boring Company had permission to build an East Coast hyperloop, the project is finally starting to come to fruition. Tap the link in bio to read more.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorites and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @futurismcartoons for more!

In March 2018, Yale neuroscientist Nenad Sestan shared a remarkable bit of news with his peers at a National Institutes of Health (NIH) meeting: he was able to keep pigs brains alive outside their bodies for up to 36 hours. The news quickly made its way from that meeting to the media. And now, more than a year later, the details of the radical study have finally been published in the highly respected journal Nature, confirming that what sounded initially like science-fiction was actually sound science and raising startling questions about what it really means to be dead. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

The U.S. has officially started using CRISPR on humans. Back in June 2016, the National Institutes of Health gave a University of Pennsylvania (UPenn) research team the go-ahead to begin a human CRISPR trial. Now those trials have officially begun. The research team hopes to investigate the potential use of CRISPR as a cancer treatment in which immune cells were removed from the patients, CRISPR edited to target tumors, and then returned to the patients bodies. Only time will tell whether the treatment proves effective or not. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Scientists might have just figured out where nightmares come from... and no, they don't hide in the dark or lurk under your bed. New research, expected to be published Tuesday in the journal JNeurosci, tracks down which part of the brain is responsible for generating feelings of anger in sleeping people. Participants in a study who reported feeling angry during their dreams had increased neural activity in the right half of their frontal cortex, suggesting that that part of the brain is responsible for dreaming up a bad time. Tap the link in our bio to read more about where bad dreams come from.

In an interview with MIT researcher Lex Fridman, Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk reiterated his belief that were all living inside a simulation. When Fridman asked him what his first question would be for the first-ever artificial general intelligence system, Musk replied: Whats outside the simulation? Is our reality just a simulation? If so, as Musk speculated, what awaits us outside of it? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Scientists at Tel Aviv University have 3D printed a small heart using human tissue that includes vessels, collagen, and biological molecules a breakthrough, according to Haaretz, that they hope could one day render organ donation obsolete. The process isn't quite ready for transplants yet, however, but it's a start. The cells need to form a pumping ability; they can currently contract, but we need them to work together, said lead scientist Tal Dvir. Tap the link our bio to read more.
Scientifically speaking, how might we fight threats to life as we know it? How can we safeguard humanity's future? These are the questions we must ask ourselves. Tap the link in our to watch more.

New research suggests that fecal transplants can reduce the severity of conditions associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and that the changes last several years after the transplants. The study, published Tuesday in the journal Scientific Reports, shows that the reduction in symptoms persisted for two years after the fact, further demonstrating the link between the gut microbiome and the brain. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

The first-ever black hole photo is even more amazing when you zoom out. While the Event Horizon Telescope was focused on the event horizon of the black hole at the center of M87, NASAs Chandra X-ray Observatory was taking a wider view of the same target and the image produced through those observations puts the black hole photo into stunning context. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this wide angle view.

Sometimes, organs donated to science don't always end up where they should. Not only were a father and son team from Michigan just charged for illegally selling human body parts which had been donated for scientific purposes but the duo also failed to disclose that the corpses carried infectious diseases. Strangely enough, selling body parts isn't always illegal but with more than meets the eye involved in these sales, these two body part pilferers face several criminal charges. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

A new quantum material could one day transfer information directly from human brains to a computer. Like a backup hard drive for your brain, if your natural brain functions began to falter, it could allow you to continue remembering things like normal. Although the device is in early stages still, it seems we are one step closer to true brain-computer interfaces. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the new quantum material scientists say could download your brain."
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

This is the first-ever image of a black hole. On Wednesday, an international coalition of scientists that came together to form the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) more on that later announced via livestream that they had captured direct images of a supermassive black hole in the M87 galaxy. These images signify that scientists have finally seen, first hand, celestial bodies that up until recently were only assumed to exist. Because the light observed by the EHT has warped around the black hole before traveling to Earth, the shadow we see is actually the entire surface of the black hole, as though it had been ripped open and flattened like a pancake, surrounded by a disk of orbiting light. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this world first and what the discovery means in scientific communities.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

The organ shortage will soon get worse. Animal organs could help. Nearly 75,000 Americans need an organ transplant. Of those, an estimated 18 will die today because they didnt get one soon enough. The bottom line is that there just arent enough donor organs available to meet the nations need. Soon, in a strange twist, self-driving cars could exacerbate the problem by reducing the number of car accidents, which is currently one of the primary sources of donor organs. Researchers across the globe are hunting for ways to save patients. And now, an idea previously relegated to the realm of science fiction is starting to look like a viable option: transplanting organs from animals into humans. The growing crisis means that when it comes to such a radical idea, "Its no longer a question of if. Its just a question of when." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Scientists say new cyborg plants could someday grow on Mars. In new research, Australian scientists show how plants can be augmented with nanomaterials that make them better at absorbing sunlight and may help them survive on futuristic Martian farms. We've long been able to introduce other materials to plants, but by introducing new nanomaterials called Metal-Organic Frameworks (MFOs) we amplify plants' natural abilities. Tap the link in our bio to read more about so-called "superplants."

This company is gamifying books to make them more like Fortnite. If old-fashioned books are too boring for you, ebook distributor OverDrive wants to gamify them with interactive elements and video game-inspired achievements and badges for kids who finish their reading homework. OverDrives student-focused reading app, Sora, takes notes from the same elements that help make Fortnite so addictive. How else is OverDrive changing the script on the future of reading? Tap the link in our bio to read this Futurism exclusive.
This weekend, brought to you by climate change.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

So-called evolutionary roboticists raise the question: why go to the trouble of building a new and improved machine when current robots could do it for you? The idea invokes a high-tech Darwinism, in which researchers ultimate goal is to design artificial intelligence and robots that can analyze their own source code and mate with others by combining bits and pieces of their code with that of other robots to create offspring, much like organic life. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what happens when robotics takes biologic inspiration.

"Fake alcohol" which induces a buzzed sensation without the state of being drunk may soon be hitting store shelves. For more than a decade, scientist David Nutt had been developing a synthetic alcohol substitute he calls Alcarelle. He claims his creation has the potential to allow drinkers to enjoy all the benefits of alcohol and none of the drawbacks meaning it could bring an end to everything from hangovers to alcohol-related cancers. (You'll still need to drink responsibly though!) Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of "fake alcohol."

Tech-savvy DJs have a whole new way to drop a beat. Instead of using sequencers and turntables, some DJs are writing code that generates sounds and beats in real time, assembling new tracks on the fly during whats become known as an algorave. "Hey, DJ! Code us a beat." Tap the link in our bio to read more about the "algorave."

Ready to take a journey to the center of our galaxy? Strap in and hold tight youre about to be teleported into a 360-degree rendering of the center of the Milky Way galaxy. The ultra-high-definition visualization comes courtesy of data collected by the Chandra X-ray Observatory, a space observatory that launched into orbit in 1999. NASAs Ames supercomputer rendered the data as a stunning simulation you can experience from the comfort of home. Tap the link in our bio to sail through the stars.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

Chinese officials have cloned a top-performing police dog, state media announced, with the goal of "mass producing" genetically identical dog cops. The pup, Kunxun, just started police dog training, to see whether the original dogs aptitude for drug detection and crowd control have carried over. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this case of a doubled dog.

Cambridge scientists say they've grown a miniature brain in a petri dish that seizes control of biological material around it. Unlike previous lab-grown brains, this one actively will send out "tendrils" to connect to a spinal cord removed from a mouse and can then use its new spine to control a mouse muscle attached to it. There are many questions left unanswered, but the novel approach could open doors to new surgeries and new avenues of research. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this newly grown brain.

As always, weve got some news about the future. Except this time, its about us. Were about to enter the next chapter of Futurism, one that will usher in a new era for this site. Itll come with new ways well be able to deliver on everything youve grown to read, watch, subscribe to, and love about what we do here. And also, more in volume of what we do, with larger ambitions, and ultimately, a higher level of quality with which were able to bring those ambitions to fruition. As of today, Futurism Media is proud to announce that were joining operations with Singularity University. Tap the link in bio to read more about what this change means for our future.

Get ready, this is wild. Russian scientists used a quantum computer to turn back time. Before you get carried away, the finding is unlikely to lead to a time machine that would work on people. But the team of physicists managed to restore IBMs public quantum computer to the state it had been in just a moment earlier, according to research published Wednesday in the journal Nature Scientific Reports a nuanced result, but one that could have striking implications for the future of computing, quantum physics, and our understanding of time itself. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this quantum time turner.

NASA engineers have captured the first images of the interaction between shockwaves from a pair of flying supersonic aircraft and they are stunning. Were seeing a level of physical detail here that I dont think anybody has ever seen before, senior research engineer Dan Banks said in a NASA press release. Just looking at the data for the first time, I think things worked out better than wed imagined. We never dreamt that it would be this clear, this beautiful, physical scientist J.T. Heineck added.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

All bots go to heaven. Jibo, the company selling anthropomorphic dancing smart home assistants that were meant to make your life at home easier, laid off most of its employees last year. And now the bot itself is ready to say goodbye forever. I want to say Ive really enjoyed our time together, the robot says in a video posted by tech reporter Dylan Martin. Thank you very very much for having me around. Tap the link in our bio to see Jibo's fond farewell.

Startups that sequence your DNA to help piece together your ancestry have a new target market, according to a story in The Atlantic: your long-dead ancestors, who may have inadvertently left behind genetic material when they licked stamps and envelopes. Maybe our ancestors did not realize it, MyHeritage founder Gilad Japhet said at an industry conference last year, according to The Atlantic, but when they were licking those stamps and the envelope flats, they were sealing their precious DNA for you forever. Tap the link in our bio to read more about DNA and the deceased.

The European Union is displeased with tech giants Google, Facebook, and Twitter because all three corporations have failed to prevent the spread of fake news. In October, the three companies agreed to a voluntary pledge to fight the political misinformation that proliferated on their platforms, as an alternative to harsher legislation being enacted against them in Europe. But after months of progress, it seems EU officials feel the three companies aren't doing enough. Tap the link in our bio to read more.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

Chemists grew a synthetic brain that stores memories in silver and one of its creators thinks it could usher in "the post-human revolution." In the ongoing quest to build an artificial human brain, scientists from UCLA may have just taken a big step forward. While a real synthetic brain is still far away, a team of chemical engineers found out how to grow self-assembling circuitry that resembles the structure and electrical activity of parts of a brain. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this "thinking machine".

The United States used to send about 40 percent of the recyclables it collected to China for processing. But in early 2018, China decided to stop importing much of this foreign garbage, and that decision has left U.S. cities struggling to process mountains of recyclables so now, in a bleak twist, theyre sometimes just burning them. The resulting emissions can have lasting health and environmental impacts. Tap the link in our bio to read more about a situation which generally just stinks.

The people who moderate Facebook spend their days reading and watching conspiracy theories, violent murders, and hate speech, often hundreds of times per day. The sheer volume of intense content they see can have lasting social and psychological consequences so severe that many moderators are coping by getting high and having sex during work. The revelations beg the question, who should be responsible for moderating and how can they themselves be supported? Tap the link in our bio to read more about Facebook's freaked out moderators.

Soon, researchers will launch a clinical trial in which theyll attempt to bathe the brains of people with the increased-risk version of the gene linked to Alzheimer's disease (APOE4) with viruses carrying the lowered-risk version of the same gene (APOE2) and it could lead to a novel gene therapy for one of the worlds most devastating diseases. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this "brainwashing" approach to an Alzheimer's treatment.

When infamous Chinese scientist He Jiankui edited the genes of human twin babies last year, he was reportedly trying to make them immune to HIV. But researchers familiar with the genetic changes he made are now saying that the specific manipulation he performed may have broader consequences. The CCR5 gene is linked to HIV susceptibility, but research published Thursday in the journal Cell shows that it also enhances cognition in mouse studies. In short, it's possible that the first two enhanced humans with genetically boosted cognition and memory... may already be born. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these gene-hacked twins.

We still have a lot of questions to answer before autonomous vehicles can go mainstream: Whos at fault if an AV has an accident? Should people need licenses to ride in a self-driving car? How should an AV decide between running over a dog or a cat? Now we have yet another question how should AVs interact with law enforcement? and the solution might involve ceding control of your car to cops. Tap the link in our bio to read more AVs, PDs, and the future of law enforcement.
Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

Tomorrow's farms will look nothing like the rolling fields we know today. In fact, there's a good chance the future of farming may take place indoors. Tap the link in our bio to watch more about the vertical future of farming.

Elon Musk is talking cryptocurrency. The real Elon Musk, not one of those Twitter scammers. On Tuesday, Teslas CEO sat down for a podcast interview with ARK Invest, a tech investment firm. In addition to chatting about electric vehicles and self-driving cars, the interviewers decided to throw Musk an off-topic question about cryptocurrencies. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Bitcoin through Musks's eyes.

Californians may soon get a cut of the proceeds when tech giants like Facebook sell their personal data. During his State of the State address on Tuesday, Governor Gavin Newsom announced his support for an initiative which would require tech companies to pay people for their personal data a move that could permanently upset the balance of power between the worlds biggest tech corporations and their users. Tap the link in our bio to read more future of your data.

Amazon has chosen Valentines Day to break up with New York. On Thursday the massive e-retailer announced it was pulling out of its deal to open a second headquarters, referred to as HQ2, after facing resistance from NYC residents and lawmakers. It's unclear what the company's next moves may be, but withdrawing now may help create a more welcoming climate for Amazon to move into New York at a later date. An international team of scientists has claimed to discovery the "neurological signature" of consciousness within the brain. The quest to discover the source of consciousness is one that spans decades. Many researchers have ventured guesses but now we may finally know the answer. Rather than a specific chunk of the brain thats responsible for consciousness, the researchers say theyve located a brain-wide pattern of activity thats only present when people are awake and responsive. Self-propelling pills that work like tiny speedboats could mean the end of needle vaccines. A new type of tiny motor could help shuttle medicine to wherever it needs to be within the body. Is the US being a bad space roommate? Russian media is reporting that the American toilet on the International Space Station burst late last week, spilling gallons of fluid that astronauts had to catch with towels. Over 10 liters (roughly 2.5 gallons) of water leaked before the problem was fixed. Navigating the bathroom situation between you and your roommate can be high stakes enough, but it's a whole other level when bathroom negotiations also involve international relations. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the roommate issue.

The Russian Navy has outfitted two warships with a weapon that it says makes enemies hallucinate and become disoriented. It may also induce dizziness and nausea. The weapon works using high-powered flashes of light that disrupt night vision and rangefinder devices. Despite the frightful sounding side effects, some have pointed out that a light based weapon might be easy to counter. Tap the link in bio to read more.

Before his passing, Gerry Cotten, the founder of crypto exchange QuadrigaCX, amassed $137 million worth of Bitcoin safely tucked away in an encrypted cold wallet. The only problem is that Cotten was the only one who knew who knew how to access these funds. Now the fortune, which accounts for most of the company's funds, is inaccessible and QuadrigaCX's business practices have come under fire. It's a prime example of the way in which blockchain technology, which can help promote accountability and transparency, can also allow companies to operate without legal oversight a glaring problem when it comes to financial matters. For some, climate change won't be all that bad. Despite extreme weather events occurring more frequently and global temperatures continuing to rise, Apple hasn't begun to sweat just yet. In fact the iconic electronics company says that as the climate worsens, the iPhones utility at keeping people connected will instill a greater sense of brand loyalty among its customers. Nature dealt SpaceX a powerful blow on Tuesday night as hurricane-force gusts tore through southern Texas. The strength of the wind caused SpaceX's Starship to break free of its mooring blocks and sent it toppling over, causing damage that will take "a few weeks" to repair, according to Elon Musk. Though undoubtedly a setback, the damage probably won't keep SpaceX from continuing to reach for the stars. Tap the link in our bio to see more of what's become of the once mighty Starship.

Organ donor waitlists are horrifically long. To cut down the wait time for those in need, many scientists have explored 3D-printed organs as an option. The trouble with things like lungs and hearts is that they break so easily. No, seriously, the complex structures tend to collapse under their own weight when printed in labs. That's why 3D printing startup Techshot is teaming up with NASA to send a biological 3D printer to space where research will focus extensively on printing heart tissue. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of 3D-printing organs in space.

In a real life "I don't feel so good" moment, astronomers are watching as a Neptune-sized planet disintegrates. About 800 light years away, K2-22b is literally having a hard time keeping itself together. The Neptune-sized rocky planet has been crumbling into pieces since before astronomers first discovered it back in 2015. Scientists hope to learn as much as they can about how and why planets fall apart before the doomed planet meets its inevitable fate. Tap the link in bio to read more about the exoplanet that has our newsroom saying, "Mr. Stark..."

Lab rats paralyzed from spinal cord injuries regained the ability to walk after scientists gave them 3D-printed implants loaded up with stem cells. The implants were biocompatible scaffolds full of minuscule channels through which stem cells could grow. They bridged across the injured section of the rats spinal cord and restored function to the rats back legs, according to research published Monday in the journal Nature Medicine. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

The human brain reconstructs memories in reverse order. According to new research, the brain works in reverse order to reconstruct memories it starts big and moves on to the small and this discovery could help us understand everything from how aging affects our memories to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Tap the link in our bio to read more about the mind and memory.

A former US senator wants congress to listen to UFO reports. In about 10 billion years, our sun will harden into a giant crystal. According to new research published in the journal "Nature", white dwarf stars in their old age will cool into enormous and super-heavy crystal orbs the likely fate of our Sun, in about 10 billion years. It's possible that billions of white dwarf stars in our galaxy have already gone through this process. The findings confirm a longstanding theory among astronomers. On this day, May 15, 1857, Scottish-American astronomer Williamina Fleming was born. Fleming trained a generation of all-women human "computers" at Harvard College Observatory and recorded observations of thousands of stars using a system she devised. She is credited with discovering 310+ stars, 10 novae, and 10 nebulae, including the Horsehead Nebula. Much of Fleming's work was credited to her male colleagues at the time but, thankfully, is recognized today. In 1906, Fleming was made an honorary member of the Royal Astronomical Society of London, the first American woman to receive the honor.

On this day, May 2, 1880, the S.S. Columbia became the first U.S. ship lit by light bulbs instead of oil lamps. It was also the first commercial application of light bulbs. At the time, the Scientific American called the lights "the greatest innovation" on-board the ship and noted that to passengers the lights were "a most agreeable" innovation.

On this day, April 25, 1953, Rosalind Franklin's x-ray diffraxtion images of DNA enabled the University of Cambridge's Francis Crick and James Watson to identify the molecule's double helix structure. Discovering the structure of DNA gave humanity a new understanding of the nature of life and opened the door to the modern era of biology.

On this day, April 23, 1867, William E. Lincoln patented his zoetrope. By spinning a drum with viewing slits, successive static images inside the drum seem to move. The faster the drum is spun the smoother the animation appears. GIFs could be considered a form of modern zoetrope successor.

On this day, April 20, 1964, the first video telephone call was made. Debuted at the 1964 World Fair, the "Picturephone" became commercially available one month later in New York City, Washington D.C., and Chicago. It cost $16 to place a 3-minute video call. Accounting for inflation that would be about $120 today!

On this day, April 13, 1970, disaster struck the Apollo 13 mission when one of the craft's oxygen tanks exploded. The crew of three were forced to use the Lunar Module as a makeshift lifeboat. After four tense days and a few course corrections the craft touched down safely back on Earth.Lead Flight Director Gene Kranz later called the rescue operation "NASA's finest hour."
After the Cambridge Analytica scandal, Facebook must meet the demand for increased transparency or risk losing users. Here's one way Facebook may address its privacy issue.

On this day, April 12, 1898, Marie Curie's early research on the radioactivity of thorium is presented at the Acadmie des Sciences. Her work was presented by a male professor, as women were not allowed to present research at the time. Madame Curie would go on to discover polonium and radium, coin the term "radioactivity", develop radiography devices for field hospitals in WWI, and become the first woman to receive the Nobel Prize for her work.

Pictured here is Margaret Hamilton, one of the world's first software engineers. In the 1960s, she led the team that wrote the code that got Apollo 11 to the moon. In fact, their programming saved the mission itself. Moments before landing on July 20 1969, the guidance computer experienced an overload of data, endangering the mission. Hamilton's code allowed the computer to recognize the overload, restart its tasks, and prioritize the landing sequence, which brought the Eagle safely to the lunar surface. Thanks, Margaret

Here's a question: Why is Motorola selling the Razr buy-one-get-one-free? Maybe its because consumers thought the $1,500 price on the companys revitalized flip-phone was too high. Or maybe it's a plot to offload a device that they cant get out of the warehouse... Maybe its both. Maybe its neither! Anyone's guess, really. The debate rages on in the latest episode of the Noise Cancelling Podcast, brought to you gleefully by the gadget-lovers of TechRadar and LaptopMag! New episodes every Friday!
Are you tired of drawn out open world games? Listen to the full episode of The Noise Cancelling Podcast from TechRadar with the link in our bio.

In the latest episode of the Noise Cancelling podcast, we talk about a dreamboat of a Chrome OS laptop the Galaxy Chromebook from Samsung. . We call it the sexiest thing moving at CES 2020, which tracks: its got a gorgeous red aluminum body, a breathtakingly clear 4K OLED screen and a wispy wafer-thin chassis. . However and this is a big however this beaut of a Chromebook survived just 6 hours on the standardized battery test our friends at LaptopMag run on every laptop they test. In a world where PCs of similar build and price last upwards of 10 hours, thats just, woof, very disappointing. (Even more so when you consider they run a more demanding OS like Windows). Whats worse, the Galaxy Chromebook, which costs ya $999, lasted just 3 to 4 hours during our personal use! You cant see us in the podcast, but we were shaking our heads. . For more news on Chromebooks, iPhones, smart watches, digital security, and way, way, way more, listen to new episodes of Noise Cancelling every Friday!

Is this what the PS5 will look like? Watch the full video on the TechRadar Youtube channel! Sony has now revealed the DualSense PS5 controller, the gamepad we'll be using with the PlayStation 5 when the console releases in late 2020. The PS5 controller's look provides a few clues about what we can expect the PS5 design to be like so, based on what we know about the next-gen console, and the DualSense's design, we got a designer to create a PS5 design render.

Heres what we think of the iPhone SE 2. . . . Its the phone to get if you just want a new iPhone, but dont want to pay a lot for it. Double true if you want one that will last you a few years. If youre after decent but not top-end performance, then thats what the iPhone SE 2020 will offer you: theres a good camera, enough power, a great App Store to plunder and a lighter-weight design than the current crop of iPhone 11 models. . . . Battery life could be better, the screen tech is starting to age, and some upgraders will miss the headphone jack; but overall, the smart improvements make this for the price one of the best iPhones Apple has ever made. . . . FOR Lightweight frame Low price for iPhone . AGAINST Battery life could be better Old screen technology . . . . Theres way more iPhone SE 2 details to unpack in our full review. Thats where we share all our in-hand tests, photo samples, and comparisons with other iPhones. Waiting for you via the link in our bio or at TechRadar.com

Whats a 108MP phone camera with 100x digital zoom get you? These 6 shots. . . We tested the @samsungus Galaxy S20 Ultra and its 108MP camera for an hour Friday night and we can tell you were impressed. . . The 48MP telephoto lens allowed us to get up close and personal with far away subjects thanks to a 10x optical and 100x digital zoom. For context, it far surpasses the 2x optical and 10x digital zoom of previous Samsung phones, and the limited 8x digital zoom on the Google Pixel 4. At 100x, we were able to examine our videographers nostrils from 50 feet away yes, it gets really close. . . We spared you the ENT examination, but heres a close up (followed by a closer up, followed by a CLOSER UP) of Grand Central train station in New York City

The Galaxy S20 Ultra is in our lab! . . . And, as you read this, we are putting Samsung's new flagship through our gauntlet of benchmarks. . . 108MP camera? We're testing it. . . 6.9-inch display with a 20:9 aspect ratio and 3200x1440-pixel resolution? We're testing it. . . Glass-aluminum body. We're testing it. But, gentle-like. . . Keep an eye out for our full review

The Samsung Galaxy Z Flip is the best modern-day foldable flip phone I've tested. . So says @techradar managing editor @mattswider after flipping and un-flipping (and doing much more with) the brand-new device for 24 hours this weekend. . Motorolas equally-fresh Razr wins on nostalgia, but its our job to tell you that Samsungs Z Flip has a larger 3,300mAh battery (the Razr has a capacity of 2,510mAh). And it's much easier to recommend a phone with battery power that will actually get you through a whole day. . Where did Matt struggle the most with the Razr? The cameras. . In the poor light of a dim restaurant, the autofocus just refused to work. Moto's Night Vision mode helped brighten things up, but when a lot of shots came out blurry, that really didn't matter. . The Galaxy Z Flip has three cameras (front, rear wide and rear ultra-wide), and all of them take superb photos, even if they aren't going to match the quality of more full-featured phones. The Z Flip also includes Samsung's new 'single-take' mode, which captures a variety of photos and videos at the same time over 10 seconds. It's useful, even if it does result in a lot of so-so shots along with a few keepers

This house-sized display stopped CES in its tracks... . . . Two-hundred 4K OLED TVs assembled like a rolling tsunami of bright pixels, all twirling brightly ABOVE your head, will do that. LG told us that 172 of the 200 OLED TVs in this cavernous theater are curved to fit the undulating design of the space. . . . Will you hold this concept phone in your hands? No, not anytime soon. But is its visibility-shifting glass panel a piece of remarkable engineering that could impact future phone designs? Absolutely. . . . Heres @OnePlus: The rear camera lenses are hidden behind a rear glass panel and only reveal themselves when theyre in use. The rest of the time the glass is darkened to present a clean surface. . . . If you need to ask yourself why thats important, we ask you to take a look at the backs of the Nokia 9 PureView or the iPhone 11 Pro. . . . Check out third video above to see how this OnePlus concept phone was inspired by the tint-shifting sunroof designed by @McLaren

Recognize these, @nurasound fans? . . . Nurasound's headphones are popular with music lovers for their incredibly deep sound customization: wearers specify if they like their music with emphasis on bass, higher-than-high midtones, well-pitched orchestral elements, or singers' voices dialed up above all that grungy low-end production. Once the details are in, Nurasound's technology works its magic to play back audio fitted perfectly to the listener's tastes. . . . The Nuraphones, a pair of Bluetooth over-ear headphones powered by the same technology, were released in 2017 to almost ubiquitous critical satisfaction (read: they sounded f#$king amazing), and the Nuraloops, a wireless earbud alternative to the 'phones, was slated for release in late 2018. . . . Somehow, late 2018 turned to 2019 and here we are with an exclusive look at hotly awaited audio devices for people who love great audio quality. . . . Want to know anything before we start testing them
Never touch a toilet seat again, thanks to @kohler

New alert! . . . Meet the Elite 45h (on-ear headphones) and Elite Active 75t (earbuds), two wireless headphone sets from @jabra . . . . We couldn't try on the Elite 75t's yet, but when we slipped on the 45h, the 'phones passive noise-cancellation significantly lowered the den of chatter from the crowded show floor at CES Unveiled. Obviously, we can't speak to the sound quality of these creamy-colored ear cans just yet, but you best believe we'll be testing them further when they go on sale in February. . . . Tell then, just know that the on-ears will cost you a cool $100, while the Active Elites will cost $199

Yes, the phone everyone had 15 years ago is now the new ... . . Tech Radar mobile editor David Lumb explains: . . The Razr 2019 is a chance to...challenge the industrys assumptions about what the smartphone future could look like. We assumed that foldables would bridge the gap between phones and tablets by unfolding horizontally into a wider display; Motorolas take has other ideas, and flips open to reveal an elongated touchscreen, one thats just a bit longer than the iPhone 11 display. . . So no, you dont get much more screen real estate. The novelty lies in what you can do with it closed, as theres a smaller display on the outside for checking texts, calls, music, emails, and such much like the preview youd get on a smartwatch. Below that quick-look screen is the rear camera, which when the Razr is closed becomes a selfie camera, while the small display shows what its looking at. . . The Razr 2019 can be handled with one hand when flipped open (as much as any plus-sized smartphone can), but more importantly, when clamped shut it fits in your palm and your pocket. . . That small footprint is what makes the Razr special youre essentially pulling out an enlarged pager when you want to check notifications or glance at the time, which is much easier than tugging a smartphone out of your pocket or bag dozens of times a day. And theres no denying that flipping a phone open and snapping it closed (say, to hang up on a call) is just as fun today as it was in the original Razrs heyday. . . The new Razr can, and will, turn heads, and it is, undeniably, enjoyable to use . . Want to know . . 1 When the Razr is coming to the U.K. and the rest of the world? . 2 Why the new Razr is slightly harder to open than the older model? . 3 How Motorola plans to help if the screen breaks prematurely? . 4 The size of the Razrs battery and what that means for day-to-day use? . . Follow us and check out the full review at TechRadar.com

Two screens *are* indeed better than one . . Who knew that LG would find a way to succeed where Samsung all but failed. This phone, the G8X, is a medium-tier LG smartphone that fits into get this! a case that has a second display. Slip in the primary phone with its Snapdragon 855 processor, 6GB of RAM, 128GB memory starter pack and 2TB-ready microSD card slot and voil, youve got a pretty clever folding phone. . . And were pretty excited by what we could do with this surprisingly capable device. Simply put, its a great tool for anyone who uses their phone for entertainment. . . Want to fold it into tent mode and watch movies? Check. . . Want to play video games on one screen and customize your controls on the other? Check. . . Want to watch an episode of the @nbcthegoodplace and play @callofduty at the same (damn) time? Double check marks, baby! . . Like we said, were pretty pleased with the @lgmobileglobal G8X, but we do have to warn you that its not all headshots and froyo. For one, the sound is lacking just a smidge. For a device thats great for gaming and movies, the sound coming from the speakers is just fine, not exceptional. . . And if youre the kind of phone die-hard that wants top-tier specs, a great camera and days of battery life, skip this device. Its not as powerful as the flagship Android phones from Samsung and OnePlus (they offer more RAM) and its camera system (a pair of 12MP f/1.8 lenses and with a third ultrawide 13MP f/2.4 lens) required lots of light to nail our test shots. Low-light photos were fuzzy and noisy. The battery life got us through the day during testing but we had to apply a little elbow grease by tightly managing the secondary displays on-time. That kind of manual labor might not be for everyone. . . If youre interested in the G8X, theres loads and loads more detail in our complete review. You know where to find us

Like the new Oh So Orange Pixel 4? . . We wont say were not fans, but we did notice that new Pixel 4s body is built with a metal frame that runs round its circumference and is finished with a rubberized black coating. It doesnt feel as luxe as the Pixel 3, but we give it points for grippiness. This slender device ain't slipping. . . Round back youll notice the heavily rumored two-camera system. While other big-name phones build in three or even five cameras, Androids opted, again, to rely on strong programming to propel its photo system forward. . . Well share more details (and some sample photos) later. For now, heres what else you should know. . . 90 Hz screen - Like the latest phone from OnePlus, the Pixel 4 offers a max refresh rate of 90 Hz, which makes gaming and video playback *noticeably* smoother. Everyone says that once you have this feature, its hard to go back... We'll see about that. . . No more fingerprint reader - The Pixel 4 nixes the fingerprint scanner in lieu of a new face-based unlock tool not too different from what youll find on an iPhone. That could be a significant adjustment for Pixel 3 owners who want to upgrade. . . Loads of new camera tech - Theres HDR+ with on-screen preview *before* you snap you pic, Dual Exposure for adjusting background brightness and subject brightness separately, improved Night Sight that could rival the iPhone 11s new tricks, and an all-new astrophotography mode for capturing richer, long-exposure shots of the stars at night. . . You might not believe it, but theres even more to the Pixel 4, including a cheaper price point and wider availability at more carriers than ever before. Check TechRadar.com for all the specs and details

You may have missed it, but Microsofts pulled back the curtain on two game-changing devices. . . . The first is the Surface Neo, a PC composed of two displays that works with a magnetic detachable keyboard. The other, a phone called the Duo, is a mini version of the Neo (minus the keyboard). . . . Whereas the Surface Neo is a larger tablet-sized device, the Duo is intentionally handheld, with two 5.6-inch displays split by a very visible center hinge that unfolds flat into an 8.3-inch (diagonal) working surface. . . . In that sense, it isn't quite the seamless experience as the Huawei Mate X or the just-launched Samsung Galaxy Fold - but with Gorilla Glass screens, the Surface Duo might avoid the ways the Galaxy Fold's plastic display is still breaking, even after its refinements. . . . Do you like what you see? If the answers yes, brace yourself for quite a wait. Neither of these devices will be available before the end of 2020

Like clockwork, after the debut of each new iPhone, we hear the same cry from readers: Is it going to be good enough to upgrade from my iPhone 6/iPhone 8/iPhone X/iPhone XS? . . There are approximately 14,000,605 opinions on whether or not an older iPhone benefits from an upgrade, so we won't get into a model-by-model discussion here. But after a week of testing the iPhone 11, we came up with a helpful way to determine if the new entry-level phone is for you, or if you should skip this generation altogether . . So here goes. Get the iPhone 11 if . . You want a slightly cheaper 2019 iPhone... The is the most cost-effective phone weve seen from Apple since the iPhone SE, and it has the added benefit of packing way more power. . . You want longer-lasting battery life The iPhone XR, the closest previous-generation iPhone to the new 11, had great battery life. The trends continues on the iPhone 11. . . You want a phone with a very strong camera Night mode, two lenses, Deep Fusion all will combine to make a very competent picture-snapping, video-shooting camera. . . Need to know who *shouldnt* buy the new iPhone? Our full report, complete with benchmarks, sample photos and the nitty-gritty details of iOS 13, is linked in our bio @apple

Dell's made a key change to its latest XPS 15 laptop. Do you know what it is? . . . . We know you're not objectively pouring over the engineering decisions that go into every computer on Amazon. (Don't get us wrong, you *should not*. As dedicated tech-lovers who test and review all the latest, greatest gadgets, that's *our* job.) . . . . But previous versions of the @Dell XPS 15 all placed the webcam in a terrible position: along the bottom bezel of the screen, where typing fingers take up the foreground and the angle points directly up the user's nose. (See an example up top.) Who wants to make video calls like that? . . . . . Luckily, Dell's changed things. The webcam now sits above the screen and video calls take place at a proper perspective. . . . . . But that doesn't mean the Dell XPS 15 is the perfect laptop. It's just a good candidate for the right type of laptop user. So, is the Dell XPS 15 a good match for you? Find out at TechRadar.com

The OnePlus 7 Pro has a few surprises you might not expect. . First and foremost, its stunning all-screen front hides a novel pop-up selfie camera. (No notch or cut-out hole, see?) And the display itself plays movies and video games with a velvety smooth 90Hz refresh rate. . Here's the next surprise: while OnePlus is known for selling highly-capable phones at price points that are cheaper than the competition, the 7 Pro actually costs as much as the iPhone XR and Galaxy S10e. . So does the unusually high price point make sense for this phone's pop-up selfie-shooter and rich, speedy display? Read our full review at Techradar.com to find out. The link's in our bio
